project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This corresponds to areas with mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces, in the locality of Ati Gumake, within the humid tropical zonobiome, in a mid-altitudinal band between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, in the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, Palomino River basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. This land cover has been mainly enriched with timber species such as oak (Tabebuia sp.) and mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla). To a lesser extent, the following species have been promoted: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp.), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Similarly, species important for agro-food security such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), soursop (Annona muricata), and pear (Syzygium malaccense) are also found associated with these land covers.Corresponds to areas with a predominance of secondary vegetation or in transition, in the locality of Atygumake, within the humid tropical zone, in a medium altitudinal range between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, within the Palomino River basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The following species are found in this cover: abarco (Cariniana sp. ), aceituno (Vitex cymosa), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), red kapok (Pachira quinata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), laurel (Nectandra sp. ), roble (Tabebuia rosea) and sambocedron (Guarea guidonia). Likewise, associated with these hedges, the planting of some species of food importance such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), guamo (Inga sp.), wild guamo (Inga edulis) and Moringa (Moringa oleifera) has been promoted. The plant enrichment in terms of abundance of this cover is remarkable through the promotion of species such as the campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla) and in smaller quantities but equally important the planting of the guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum) and the bitter palm (Sabal mauritiformis).
history_site:
The Ati Gumake sector is one of the first Arhuaco territories reestablished on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada, thanks to the cultural and political efforts of the four peoples of the Sierra. This process made possible the partial recovery of the territory known as the “exit to the sea” of the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, located between the Don Diego and Palomino rivers, during the final decades of the twentieth century. The community is situated where the Lucuici River, El Puerco stream, and the Palomino River joint, between 250 and 1000 meters above sea level.

The most affected areas by deforestation in recent decades are concentrated in the northern, central, and western parts of this terriroty. However, it is important to note that this zone was heavily impacted by the presence of illicit crops until the first decade of the 21st century. Fires, cattle ranching and the expansion of the agricultural frontier remain historical drivers of change in the region. Around the populated center, there are areas of clean and weedy pastures, as well as mosaics of crops, pastures, and natural spaces. The presence of large trees to the northwest of the populated area offers an opportunity to establish seed banks of late-successional and pioneer timber species, oriented the ecological restoration of this area with a long-term vision.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This corresponds to areas with mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces, in the locality of Ati Gumake, within the humid tropical zonobiome, in a mid-altitudinal band between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, in the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, Palomino River basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. This land cover has been mainly enriched with timber species such as oak (Tabebuia sp.) and mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla). To a lesser extent, the following species have been promoted: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp.), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Similarly, species important for agro-food security such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), soursop (Annona muricata), and pear (Syzygium malaccense) are also found associated with these land covers.Corresponds to areas of dense forest and/or forests with signs of fragmentation, in the town of Bunkwimake, in the average altitudinal range between 280 and 340 meters above sea level, associated with the expansion of the agricultural and livestock frontier in the humid tropical zone of the Don Diego river basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, plant enrichment with species of great timber value and constructive use stands out, including species that are threatened at the regional and local levels, such as: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), roble (Tabebuia sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), and palma amarga (Sabal mauritiformis). Other species of importance for soil recovery and as food for fauna have also been promoted, including guamo (Inga sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), among others.

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: Corresponds to areas with clean and/or weeded pasture cover in the locality of Ati Gumake, within the humid tropical zone, in an average altitudinal range between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, in the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Reserve, Palomino river basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, the following species stand out for their frequency and density: roble (Tabebuia sp.), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla) and cedro (Cedrela odorata). At lower densities, algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp. ), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), palma amarga (Sabal mauritiformis) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). In some polygons of this vegetation cover, species of agrifood importance for the Arhuaca community have been planted, such as: avocado (Persea americana), árbol del pan (Artocarpus altilis), cañandonga (Cassia grandis), marañon (Anacardium occidentale), moringa (Moringa oleifera) and pera (Syizigyum malaccense). This corresponds to areas with mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces, in the locality of Ati Gumake, within the humid tropical zonobiome, in a mid-altitudinal band between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, in the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, Palomino River basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. This land cover has been mainly enriched with timber species such as oak (Tabebuia sp.) and mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla). To a lesser extent, the following species have been promoted: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp.), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). In this coverage, plant enrichment with species of great timber value and constructive use stands out, including species that are threatened at the regional and local levels, such as: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), roble (Tabebuia sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), and palma amarga (Sabal mauritiformis). Other species of importance for soil recovery and as food for fauna have also been promoted, including guamo (Inga sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), among others.

To a lesser extent, the following species have been promoted: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp.), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Similarly, species important for agro-food security such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), soursop (Annona muricata), and pear (Syzygium malaccense) are also found associated with these land covers.It corresponds to vegetation cover associated with aquatic ecosystems featuring a permanent water body, either static or flowing, in the locality of Aty Gumake﻿, within the cuenca del río Palomino﻿, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿.

In this hydrobiome, vegetation enrichment is characterized by the following species: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guamo (Inga sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), and oak (Tabebuia sp.).

Occasionally associated with this hydrobiome in the locality of Aty Gumake﻿ are species such as: avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cascarillo (Protium sp.), cedar (Cedrela odorata), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and bitter palm (Sabal mauritiformis).
It corresponds to vegetation cover associated with aquatic ecosystems featuring a permanent water body, either static or flowing, in the locality of Aty Gumake﻿, within the cuenca del río Palomino﻿, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿.

In this hydrobiome, vegetation enrichment is characterized by the following species: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guamo (Inga sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), and oak (Tabebuia sp.).

Occasionally associated with this hydrobiome in the locality of Aty Gumake﻿ are species such as: avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cascarillo (Protium sp.), cedar (Cedrela odorata), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and bitter palm (Sabal mauritiformis).
Corresponds to areas with a predominance of secondary vegetation or in transition, in the locality of Atygumake, within the humid tropical zone, in a medium altitudinal range between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, within the Palomino River basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The following species are found in this cover: abarco (Cariniana sp. ), aceituno (Vitex cymosa), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), red kapok (Pachira quinata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), laurel (Nectandra sp. ), roble (Tabebuia rosea) and sambocedron (Guarea guidonia). Likewise, associated with these hedges, the planting of some species of food importance such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), guamo (Inga sp.), wild guamo (Inga edulis) and Moringa (Moringa oleifera) has been promoted. The plant enrichment in terms of abundance of this cover is remarkable through the promotion of species such as the campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla) and in smaller quantities but equally important the planting of the guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum) and the bitter palm (Sabal mauritiformis).It corresponds to riparian vegetation cover associated with rivers in the locality of Aty Gumake, within the Palomino River basin, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The main planted species associated with this cover include avocado (Persea americana), jatobá (Hymenaea courbaril), caney (Aspidosperma polyneuron), pink shower tree (Cassia grandis), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemono (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp.), and oak (Tabebuia sp.). Less frequent and less dense individuals include abarco (Cariniana sp.), aceituno (Vitex cymosa), clementino, laurel (Nectandra sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), campano (Samanea saman), cascariillo (Protium sp.), and red ceiba (Pachira quinata).It corresponds to vegetation cover associated with aquatic ecosystems featuring a permanent water body, either static or flowing, in the locality of Aty Gumake﻿, within the cuenca del río Palomino﻿, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿.

In this hydrobiome, vegetation enrichment is characterized by the following species: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guamo (Inga sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), and oak (Tabebuia sp.).

Occasionally associated with this hydrobiome in the locality of Aty Gumake﻿ are species such as: avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cascarillo (Protium sp.), cedar (Cedrela odorata), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and bitter palm (Sabal mauritiformis).
history_site:
The Ati Gumake sector is one of the first Arhuaco territories reestablished on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada, thanks to the cultural and political efforts of the four peoples of the Sierra. This process made possible the partial recovery of the territory known as the “exit to the sea” of the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, located between the Don Diego and Palomino rivers, during the final decades of the twentieth century. The community is situated where the Lucuici River, El Puerco stream, and the Palomino River joint, between 250 and 1000 meters above sea level.

The most affected areas by deforestation in recent decades are concentrated in the northern, central, and western parts of this terriroty. However, it is important to note that this zone was heavily impacted by the presence of illicit crops until the first decade of the 21st century. Fires, cattle ranching and the expansion of the agricultural frontier remain historical drivers of change in the region. Around the populated center, there are areas of clean and weedy pastures, as well as mosaics of crops, pastures, and natural spaces. The presence of large trees to the northwest of the populated area offers an opportunity to establish seed banks of late-successional and pioneer timber species, oriented the ecological restoration of this area with a long-term vision.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

description_site: Corresponds to areas with clean and/or weeded pasture cover in the locality of Ati Gumake, within the humid tropical zone, in an average altitudinal range between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, in the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Reserve, Palomino river basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The following species are found in this cover: abarco (Cariniana sp. ), aceituno (Vitex cymosa), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), red kapok (Pachira quinata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), laurel (Nectandra sp. ), roble (Tabebuia rosea) and sambocedron (Guarea guidonia). Likewise, associated with these hedges, the planting of some species of food importance such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), guamo (Inga sp.), wild guamo (Inga edulis) and Moringa (Moringa oleifera) has been promoted. The plant enrichment in terms of abundance of this cover is remarkable through the promotion of species such as the campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla) and in smaller quantities but equally important the planting of the guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum) and the bitter palm (Sabal mauritiformis).
history_site:
The Ati Gumake sector is one of the first Arhuaco territories reestablished on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada, thanks to the cultural and political efforts of the four peoples of the Sierra. This process made possible the partial recovery of the territory known as the “exit to the sea” of the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, located between the Don Diego and Palomino rivers, during the final decades of the twentieth century. The community is situated where the Lucuici River, El Puerco stream, and the Palomino River joint, between 250 and 1000 meters above sea level.

The most affected areas by deforestation in recent decades are concentrated in the northern, central, and western parts of this terriroty. However, it is important to note that this zone was heavily impacted by the presence of illicit crops until the first decade of the 21st century. Fires, cattle ranching and the expansion of the agricultural frontier remain historical drivers of change in the region. Around the populated center, there are areas of clean and weedy pastures, as well as mosaics of crops, pastures, and natural spaces. The presence of large trees to the northwest of the populated area offers an opportunity to establish seed banks of late-successional and pioneer timber species, oriented the ecological restoration of this area with a long-term vision.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

Similarly, species important for agro-food security such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), soursop (Annona muricata), and pear (Syzygium malaccense) are also found associated with these land covers.

Similarly, species important for agro-food security such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), soursop (Annona muricata), and pear (Syzygium malaccense) are also found associated with these land covers.Corresponds to areas of dense forest and/or forests with signs of fragmentation, in the town of Bunkwimake, in the average altitudinal range between 280 and 340 meters above sea level, associated with the expansion of the agricultural and livestock frontier in the humid tropical zone of the Don Diego river basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, plant enrichment with species of great timber value and constructive use stands out, including species that are threatened at the regional and local levels, such as: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), roble (Tabebuia sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), and palma amarga (Sabal mauritiformis). Other species of importance for soil recovery and as food for fauna have also been promoted, including guamo (Inga sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), among others.

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to vegetation covers of the Sub-Andean Orobiome, which include secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural spaces in the locality of Serankwa, within the Aracataca River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra. The following species are common across all covers of the Sub-Andean biome, reported with a frequency of 80 to 100% in disturbed areas: cedar (Cedrela odorata), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Species reported with more than 50% but less than 80% frequency include: guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria) and pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.). Species reported with lower frequency include: dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), cascarillo (Protium sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.) and moringa (Moringa oleifera).﻿
history_site:
Serankwa is an Arhuaco community located between 1,400 and 2,500 m.a.s.l, within the Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The populated center is situated near the Corván River, a major tributary of the Aracataca River. The area contains an extensive block of sub-Andean forest, covering more than 100 hectares, with no signs of anthropic intervention or accumulated deforestation over the past 20 years.

This forest block, located to the north and east of the settlement, represents an important reference ecosystem and germplasm bank for guiding ecological restoration processes. The conserved mountain area is steep and characterized by surface rock outcrops. In contrast, zones under greater territorial pressure are found toward the northwest, west, and south of the area, comprising open patches ranging from 20 to 40 hectares, where overgrown pastures, clean pastures, and some subsistence crops predominate. The main community cultivation area is located along the foothills of the forest block.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

Species reported with more than 50% but less than 80% frequency include: guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria) and pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.). Species reported with lower frequency include: dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), cascarillo (Protium sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.) and moringa (Moringa oleifera).﻿
history_site:
Serankwa is an Arhuaco community located between 1,400 and 2,500 m.a.s.l, within the Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The populated center is situated near the Corván River, a major tributary of the Aracataca River. The area contains an extensive block of sub-Andean forest, covering more than 100 hectares, with no signs of anthropic intervention or accumulated deforestation over the past 20 years.

This forest block, located to the north and east of the settlement, represents an important reference ecosystem and germplasm bank for guiding ecological restoration processes. The conserved mountain area is steep and characterized by surface rock outcrops. In contrast, zones under greater territorial pressure are found toward the northwest, west, and south of the area, comprising open patches ranging from 20 to 40 hectares, where overgrown pastures, clean pastures, and some subsistence crops predominate. The main community cultivation area is located along the foothills of the forest block.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to areas with mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces, in the locality of Ati Gumake﻿, within the tropical humid zonobiome, in a mid-altitudinal strip between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, in the Resguardo Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco﻿, watershed of the río Palomino﻿, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿. This coverage has been mainly enriched with timber species such as oak (Tabebuia sp.﻿) and mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla﻿). To a lesser extent, with the following species: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril﻿), campano (Samanea saman﻿), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum﻿), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum﻿), cedar (Cedrela odorata﻿), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria﻿), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia﻿), guamo (Inga sp.﻿), gusanero (Astronium graveolens﻿), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum﻿) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia﻿). Likewise, associated with these coverages, species of agro-food importance can be found such as avocado (Persea americana﻿), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis﻿), soursop (Annona muricata﻿) and Perra (Zyzygium malaccence﻿). It corresponds to vegetation coverages associated with aquatic ecosystems with a permanent water mirror, static or flowing, in the locality of Aty Gumake﻿, watershed of the río Palomino﻿, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿. In this hydrobiome, notable vegetation enrichment includes the following species: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum﻿), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla﻿), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria﻿), guamo (Inga sp.﻿), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia﻿) and oak (Tabebuia sp.﻿). Occasionally associated with this hydrobiome of the locality of Aty Gumake﻿ can be found avocado (Persea americana﻿), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril﻿), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis﻿), campano (Samanea saman﻿), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum﻿), cascarillo (Protium sp.﻿), cedar (Cedrela odorata﻿), laurel (Nectandra sp.﻿) and bitter palm (Sabal mauritiformis﻿).
history_site:
The Ati Gumake sector is one of the first Arhuaco territories reestablished on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada, thanks to the cultural and political efforts of the four peoples of the Sierra. This process made possible the partial recovery of the territory known as the “exit to the sea” of the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, located between the Don Diego and Palomino rivers, during the final decades of the twentieth century. The community is situated where the Lucuici River, El Puerco stream, and the Palomino River joint, between 250 and 1000 meters above sea level.

The most affected areas by deforestation in recent decades are concentrated in the northern, central, and western parts of this terriroty. However, it is important to note that this zone was heavily impacted by the presence of illicit crops until the first decade of the 21st century. Fires, cattle ranching and the expansion of the agricultural frontier remain historical drivers of change in the region. Around the populated center, there are areas of clean and weedy pastures, as well as mosaics of crops, pastures, and natural spaces. The presence of large trees to the northwest of the populated area offers an opportunity to establish seed banks of late-successional and pioneer timber species, oriented the ecological restoration of this area with a long-term vision.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This corresponds to areas with mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces, in the locality of Ati Gumake, within the humid tropical zonobiome, in a mid-altitudinal band between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, in the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, Palomino River basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. This land cover has been mainly enriched with timber species such as oak (Tabebuia sp.) and mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla). To a lesser extent, the following species have been promoted: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp.), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Similarly, species important for agro-food security such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), soursop (Annona muricata), and pear (Syzygium malaccense) are also found associated with these land covers.This corresponds to areas with mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces, in the locality of Ati Gumake, within the humid tropical zonobiome, in a mid-altitudinal band between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, in the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, Palomino River basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. This land cover has been mainly enriched with timber species such as oak (Tabebuia sp.) and mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla). To a lesser extent, the following species have been promoted: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp.), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Similarly, species important for agro-food security such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), soursop (Annona muricata), and pear (Syzygium malaccense) are also found associated with these land covers.Corresponds to areas of dense forest and/or forests with signs of fragmentation, in the town of Bunkwimake, in the average altitudinal range between 280 and 340 meters above sea level, associated with the expansion of the agricultural and livestock frontier in the humid tropical zone of the Don Diego river basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, plant enrichment with species of great timber value and constructive use stands out, including species that are threatened at the regional and local levels, such as: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), roble (Tabebuia sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), and palma amarga (Sabal mauritiformis). Other species of importance for soil recovery and as food for fauna have also been promoted, including guamo (Inga sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), among others. Corresponds to areas with a predominance of secondary vegetation or in transition, in the locality of Atygumake, within the humid tropical zone, in a medium altitudinal range between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, within the Palomino River basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The following species are found in this cover: abarco (Cariniana sp. ), aceituno (Vitex cymosa), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), red kapok (Pachira quinata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), laurel (Nectandra sp. ), roble (Tabebuia rosea) and sambocedron (Guarea guidonia). Likewise, associated with these hedges, the planting of some species of food importance such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), guamo (Inga sp.), wild guamo (Inga edulis) and Moringa (Moringa oleifera) has been promoted. The plant enrichment in terms of abundance of this cover is remarkable through the promotion of species such as the campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla) and in smaller quantities but equally important the planting of the guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum) and the bitter palm (Sabal mauritiformis).It corresponds to riparian vegetation cover associated with rivers in the locality of Aty Gumake, within the Palomino River basin, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The main planted species associated with this cover include avocado (Persea americana), jatobá (Hymenaea courbaril), caney (Aspidosperma polyneuron), pink shower tree (Cassia grandis), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemono (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp.), and oak (Tabebuia sp.). Less frequent and less dense individuals include abarco (Cariniana sp.), aceituno (Vitex cymosa), clementino, laurel (Nectandra sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), campano (Samanea saman), cascariillo (Protium sp.), and red ceiba (Pachira quinata).

The Ati Gumake sector is one of the first Arhuaco territories reestablished on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada, thanks to the cultural and political efforts of the four peoples of the Sierra. This process made possible the partial recovery of the territory known as the “exit to the sea” of the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, located between the Don Diego and Palomino rivers, during the final decades of the twentieth century. The community is situated where the Lucuici River, El Puerco stream, and the Palomino River joint, between 250 and 1000 meters above sea level.

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site:
It corresponds to vegetation cover associated with aquatic ecosystems featuring a permanent water body, either static or flowing, in the locality of Aty Gumake﻿, within the cuenca del río Palomino﻿, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿.

In this hydrobiome, vegetation enrichment is characterized by the following species: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guamo (Inga sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), and oak (Tabebuia sp.).

Occasionally associated with this hydrobiome in the locality of Aty Gumake﻿ are species such as: avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cascarillo (Protium sp.), cedar (Cedrela odorata), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and bitter palm (Sabal mauritiformis).
This corresponds to areas with mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces, in the locality of Ati Gumake, within the humid tropical zonobiome, in a mid-altitudinal band between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, in the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, Palomino River basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. This land cover has been mainly enriched with timber species such as oak (Tabebuia sp.) and mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla). To a lesser extent, the following species have been promoted: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp.), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Similarly, species important for agro-food security such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), soursop (Annona muricata), and pear (Syzygium malaccense) are also found associated with these land covers.

planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site:
It corresponds to vegetation covers associated with high mountain aquatic ecosystems, featuring a permanent water body, either static or flowing, in the locality of Serankwa, within the Aracataca River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.

In this hydrobiome, vegetation enrichment is mainly represented by the following species: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia).

To a lesser extent, the following species have also been recorded: mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cascarillo (Protium sp.), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), and higuerón (Ficus sp.).It corresponds to vegetation covers of the Sub-Andean Orobiome, which include secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural spaces in the locality of Serankwa, within the Aracataca River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra. The following species are common across all covers of the Sub-Andean biome, reported with a frequency of 80 to 100% in disturbed areas: cedar (Cedrela odorata), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Species reported with more than 50% but less than 80% frequency include: guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria) and pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.). Species reported with lower frequency include: dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), cascarillo (Protium sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.) and moringa (Moringa oleifera).﻿It corresponds to vegetation covers associated with high mountain aquatic ecosystems, featuring a permanent water body, either static or flowing, in the locality of Serankwa, within the Aracataca River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site:
It corresponds to vegetation cover associated with aquatic ecosystems featuring a permanent water body, either static or flowing, in the locality of Aty Gumake﻿, within the cuenca del río Palomino﻿, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿.

In this hydrobiome, vegetation enrichment is characterized by the following species: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guamo (Inga sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), and oak (Tabebuia sp.).

Occasionally associated with this hydrobiome in the locality of Aty Gumake﻿ are species such as: avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cascarillo (Protium sp.), cedar (Cedrela odorata), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and bitter palm (Sabal mauritiformis).
This corresponds to areas with mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces, in the locality of Ati Gumake, within the humid tropical zonobiome, in a mid-altitudinal band between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, in the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, Palomino River basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. This land cover has been mainly enriched with timber species such as oak (Tabebuia sp.) and mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla). To a lesser extent, the following species have been promoted: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp.), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Similarly, species important for agro-food security such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), soursop (Annona muricata), and pear (Syzygium malaccense) are also found associated with these land covers.It corresponds to riparian vegetation cover associated with rivers in the locality of Aty Gumake, within the Palomino River basin, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The main planted species associated with this cover include avocado (Persea americana), jatobá (Hymenaea courbaril), caney (Aspidosperma polyneuron), pink shower tree (Cassia grandis), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemono (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp.), and oak (Tabebuia sp.). Less frequent and less dense individuals include abarco (Cariniana sp.), aceituno (Vitex cymosa), clementino, laurel (Nectandra sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), campano (Samanea saman), cascariillo (Protium sp.), and red ceiba (Pachira quinata).It corresponds to vegetation cover associated with aquatic ecosystems featuring a permanent water body, either static or flowing, in the locality of Aty Gumake﻿, within the cuenca del río Palomino﻿, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿.

In this hydrobiome, vegetation enrichment is characterized by the following species: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guamo (Inga sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), and oak (Tabebuia sp.).

Occasionally associated with this hydrobiome in the locality of Aty Gumake﻿ are species such as: avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cascarillo (Protium sp.), cedar (Cedrela odorata), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and bitter palm (Sabal mauritiformis).
history_site:
The Ati Gumake sector is one of the first Arhuaco territories reestablished on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada, thanks to the cultural and political efforts of the four peoples of the Sierra. This process made possible the partial recovery of the territory known as the “exit to the sea” of the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, located between the Don Diego and Palomino rivers, during the final decades of the twentieth century. The community is situated where the Lucuici River, El Puerco stream, and the Palomino River joint, between 250 and 1000 meters above sea level.

The most affected areas by deforestation in recent decades are concentrated in the northern, central, and western parts of this terriroty. However, it is important to note that this zone was heavily impacted by the presence of illicit crops until the first decade of the 21st century. Fires, cattle ranching and the expansion of the agricultural frontier remain historical drivers of change in the region. Around the populated center, there are areas of clean and weedy pastures, as well as mosaics of crops, pastures, and natural spaces. The presence of large trees to the northwest of the populated area offers an opportunity to establish seed banks of late-successional and pioneer timber species, oriented the ecological restoration of this area with a long-term vision.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

description_site: This corresponds to areas with mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces, in the locality of Ati Gumake, within the humid tropical zonobiome, in a mid-altitudinal band between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, in the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, Palomino River basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. This land cover has been mainly enriched with timber species such as oak (Tabebuia sp.) and mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla). To a lesser extent, the following species have been promoted: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp.), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Similarly, species important for agro-food security such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), soursop (Annona muricata), and pear (Syzygium malaccense) are also found associated with these land covers.Corresponds to areas of dense forest and/or forests with signs of fragmentation, in the town of Bunkwimake, in the average altitudinal range between 280 and 340 meters above sea level, associated with the expansion of the agricultural and livestock frontier in the humid tropical zone of the Don Diego river basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, plant enrichment with species of great timber value and constructive use stands out, including species that are threatened at the regional and local levels, such as: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), roble (Tabebuia sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), and palma amarga (Sabal mauritiformis). Other species of importance for soil recovery and as food for fauna have also been promoted, including guamo (Inga sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), among others.

Occasionally associated with this hydrobiome in the locality of Aty Gumake﻿ are species such as: avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cascarillo (Protium sp.), cedar (Cedrela odorata), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and bitter palm (Sabal mauritiformis).
Corresponds to areas of dense forest and/or forests with signs of fragmentation, in the town of Bunkwimake, in the average altitudinal range between 280 and 340 meters above sea level, associated with the expansion of the agricultural and livestock frontier in the humid tropical zone of the Don Diego river basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, plant enrichment with species of great timber value and constructive use stands out, including species that are threatened at the regional and local levels, such as: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), roble (Tabebuia sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), and palma amarga (Sabal mauritiformis). Other species of importance for soil recovery and as food for fauna have also been promoted, including guamo (Inga sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), among others.
history_site:
The Ati Gumake sector is one of the first Arhuaco territories reestablished on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada, thanks to the cultural and political efforts of the four peoples of the Sierra. This process made possible the partial recovery of the territory known as the “exit to the sea” of the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, located between the Don Diego and Palomino rivers, during the final decades of the twentieth century. The community is situated where the Lucuici River, El Puerco stream, and the Palomino River joint, between 250 and 1000 meters above sea level.

The most affected areas by deforestation in recent decades are concentrated in the northern, central, and western parts of this terriroty. However, it is important to note that this zone was heavily impacted by the presence of illicit crops until the first decade of the 21st century. Fires, cattle ranching and the expansion of the agricultural frontier remain historical drivers of change in the region. Around the populated center, there are areas of clean and weedy pastures, as well as mosaics of crops, pastures, and natural spaces. The presence of large trees to the northwest of the populated area offers an opportunity to establish seed banks of late-successional and pioneer timber species, oriented the ecological restoration of this area with a long-term vision.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

description_site: This corresponds to areas with mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces, in the locality of Ati Gumake, within the humid tropical zonobiome, in a mid-altitudinal band between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, in the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, Palomino River basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. Similarly, species important for agro-food security such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), soursop (Annona muricata), and pear (Syzygium malaccense) are also found associated with these land covers.Corresponds to areas with a predominance of secondary vegetation or in transition, in the locality of Atygumake, within the humid tropical zone, in a medium altitudinal range between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, within the Palomino River basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The following species are found in this cover: abarco (Cariniana sp. ), aceituno (Vitex cymosa), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), red kapok (Pachira quinata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), laurel (Nectandra sp. ), roble (Tabebuia rosea) and sambocedron (Guarea guidonia). Likewise, associated with these hedges, the planting of some species of food importance such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), guamo (Inga sp.), wild guamo (Inga edulis) and Moringa (Moringa oleifera) has been promoted. The plant enrichment in terms of abundance of this cover is remarkable through the promotion of species such as the campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla) and in smaller quantities but equally important the planting of the guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum) and the bitter palm (Sabal mauritiformis).

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site:
It corresponds to vegetation covers associated with high mountain aquatic ecosystems, featuring a permanent water body, either static or flowing, in the locality of Serankwa, within the Aracataca River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.

In this hydrobiome, vegetation enrichment is mainly represented by the following species: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia).

To a lesser extent, the following species have also been recorded: mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cascarillo (Protium sp.), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), and higuerón (Ficus sp.).It corresponds to vegetation covers of the Sub-Andean Orobiome, which include secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural spaces in the locality of Serankwa, within the Aracataca River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra. The following species are common across all covers of the Sub-Andean biome, reported with a frequency of 80 to 100% in disturbed areas: cedar (Cedrela odorata), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Species reported with more than 50% but less than 80% frequency include: guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria) and pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.). Species reported with lower frequency include: dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), cascarillo (Protium sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.) and moringa (Moringa oleifera).﻿It corresponds to vegetation covers associated with high mountain aquatic ecosystems, featuring a permanent water body, either static or flowing, in the locality of Serankwa, within the Aracataca River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.

In this hydrobiome, vegetation enrichment is mainly represented by the following species: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia).

To a lesser extent, the following species have also been recorded: mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cascarillo (Protium sp.), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), and higuerón (Ficus sp.).
history_site:
Serankwa is an Arhuaco community located between 1,400 and 2,500 m.a.s.l, within the Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The populated center is situated near the Corván River, a major tributary of the Aracataca River. The area contains an extensive block of sub-Andean forest, covering more than 100 hectares, with no signs of anthropic intervention or accumulated deforestation over the past 20 years.

This forest block, located to the north and east of the settlement, represents an important reference ecosystem and germplasm bank for guiding ecological restoration processes. The conserved mountain area is steep and characterized by surface rock outcrops. In contrast, zones under greater territorial pressure are found toward the northwest, west, and south of the area, comprising open patches ranging from 20 to 40 hectares, where overgrown pastures, clean pastures, and some subsistence crops predominate. The main community cultivation area is located along the foothills of the forest block.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This corresponds to mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces in the locality of Bunkwimake, within the mid-altitudinal band between 280 and 340 meters above sea level, in the humid tropical zonobiome, Don Diego River basin, Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this land cover, enrichment with plant species of high timber value and construction utility stands out, such as: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), oak (Tabebuia sp.), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), laurel (Nectandra sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). To a lesser extent, but with good frequency, species such as algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), kamaleandra (Calliandra sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), among others, have been associated. Likewise, other species important for food security have been promoted, such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), pear (Syzygium malaccense), guamo (Inga sp.), and moringa (Moringa oleifera).
history_site:
Bunkwimake is an Arhuaco territory located near the Don Dieguito River, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada, in the area known as the “exit to the sea” of the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve. It is currently one of the main consolidated population centers in the northern sector of the Sierra. The area lies between 200 and 500 m.a.s.l and is part of the Tropical Humid Zonobiome, which was severely impacted in the late 20th and early 21st centuries thorugh illicit crops.

Nevertheless, through the Plan Colombia—which promoted manual eradication and aerial control of such crops, along with land legislation in favor of the Indigenous Reserve—progress has been made to natural recovery and productive reconversion. Cocoa farming and other semi-permanent crops have become key strategies to gradually improve ecological connectivity indicators and strengthen the local economy.

Burning and deforestation are other historical drivers of transformation that continue their influence in the region, particularly on the southern side of the populated center. Likewise, areas impacted by deforestation in recent decades are highly noticeable in all four cardinal directions; however, some key remnants of dense forest and tall secondary vegetation remain, especially toward the northeastern sector of the populated area.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

description_site: This corresponds to mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces in the locality of Bunkwimake, within the mid-altitudinal band between 280 and 340 meters above sea level, in the humid tropical zonobiome, Don Diego River basin, Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. To a lesser extent, but with good frequency, species such as algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), kamaleandra (Calliandra sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), among others, have been associated. Likewise, other species important for food security have been promoted, such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), pear (Syzygium malaccense), guamo (Inga sp.), and moringa (Moringa oleifera).Corresponds to areas of dense forest and/or forests with signs of fragmentation in the locality of Atygumake, within the humid tropical zone, in an average altitudinal range between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, within the Palomino River basin, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage there is an enrichment of vegetation with species of timber importance, especially with constructive use value, among which stand out: laurel (Nectandra sp. ), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), roble (Tabebuia sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), camapano (Samanea saman). Likewise, in some of these cover crops, the planting of other species of community importance has been promoted, such as avocado (Persea americana) and Moringa (Moringa oleifera), which favor the expectations of the Arhuaca population's own economy and food security.

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This corresponds to mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces in the locality of Bunkwimake, within the mid-altitudinal band between 280 and 340 meters above sea level, in the humid tropical zonobiome, Don Diego River basin, Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this land cover, enrichment with plant species of high timber value and construction utility stands out, such as: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), oak (Tabebuia sp.), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), laurel (Nectandra sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). To a lesser extent, but with good frequency, species such as algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), kamaleandra (Calliandra sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), among others, have been associated. Likewise, other species important for food security have been promoted, such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), pear (Syzygium malaccense), guamo (Inga sp.), and moringa (Moringa oleifera).This corresponds to mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces in the locality of Bunkwimake, within the mid-altitudinal band between 280 and 340 meters above sea level, in the humid tropical zonobiome, Don Diego River basin, Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this land cover, enrichment with plant species of high timber value and construction utility stands out, such as: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), oak (Tabebuia sp.), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), laurel (Nectandra sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). To a lesser extent, but with good frequency, species such as algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), kamaleandra (Calliandra sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), among others, have been associated. Likewise, other species important for food security have been promoted, such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), pear (Syzygium malaccense), guamo (Inga sp.), and moringa (Moringa oleifera).Corresponds to areas of dense forest and/or forests with signs of fragmentation in the locality of Atygumake, within the humid tropical zone, in an average altitudinal range between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, within the Palomino River basin, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage there is an enrichment of vegetation with species of timber importance, especially with constructive use value, among which stand out: laurel (Nectandra sp. ), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), roble (Tabebuia sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), camapano (Samanea saman). Likewise, in some of these cover crops, the planting of other species of community importance has been promoted, such as avocado (Persea americana) and Moringa (Moringa oleifera), which favor the expectations of the Arhuaca population's own economy and food security.
history_site:
Bunkwimake is an Arhuaco territory located near the Don Dieguito River, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada, in the area known as the “exit to the sea” of the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve. It is currently one of the main consolidated population centers in the northern sector of the Sierra. The area lies between 200 and 500 m.a.s.l and is part of the Tropical Humid Zonobiome, which was severely impacted in the late 20th and early 21st centuries thorugh illicit crops.

Nevertheless, through the Plan Colombia—which promoted manual eradication and aerial control of such crops, along with land legislation in favor of the Indigenous Reserve—progress has been made to natural recovery and productive reconversion. Cocoa farming and other semi-permanent crops have become key strategies to gradually improve ecological connectivity indicators and strengthen the local economy.

Burning and deforestation are other historical drivers of transformation that continue their influence in the region, particularly on the southern side of the populated center. Likewise, areas impacted by deforestation in recent decades are highly noticeable in all four cardinal directions; however, some key remnants of dense forest and tall secondary vegetation remain, especially toward the northeastern sector of the populated area.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds mainly to clean and/or eventually weeded pasture cover in the locality of Bunkwimake, in the average altitudinal strip between 280 and 340 meters above sea level, in the humid tropical zone of the Don Diego river basin, Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco indigenous reservation, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, there is an enrichment of vegetation with species of great timber value and constructive use, including species in the threatened category at the regional and local levels, such as: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracoli (Anacardium excelsum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), roble (Tabebuia sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), and palma amarga (Sabal mauritiformis). There is also the planting of an almost extinct species known locally as Clementino and other key species in the protection of ecosystems such as algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), ceiba roja (Pachira quinata), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), guácimo (GUazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp. ), laurel (Nectandra sp.), perehuetano (Parinari pachyphylla) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Other species of agrifood importance have also been promoted, including avocado (Persea americana), árbol del pan (Artocarpus altilis) and moringa (Moringa oleifera).This corresponds to mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces in the locality of Bunkwimake, within the mid-altitudinal band between 280 and 340 meters above sea level, in the humid tropical zonobiome, Don Diego River basin, Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this land cover, enrichment with plant species of high timber value and construction utility stands out, such as: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), oak (Tabebuia sp.), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), laurel (Nectandra sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). To a lesser extent, but with good frequency, species such as algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), kamaleandra (Calliandra sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), among others, have been associated. Likewise, other species important for food security have been promoted, such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), pear (Syzygium malaccense), guamo (Inga sp.), and moringa (Moringa oleifera).

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds mainly to clean and/or eventually weeded pasture cover in the locality of Bunkwimake, in the average altitudinal strip between 280 and 340 meters above sea level, in the humid tropical zone of the Don Diego river basin, Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco indigenous reservation, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, there is an enrichment of vegetation with species of great timber value and constructive use, including species in the threatened category at the regional and local levels, such as: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracoli (Anacardium excelsum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), roble (Tabebuia sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), and palma amarga (Sabal mauritiformis). There is also the planting of an almost extinct species known locally as Clementino and other key species in the protection of ecosystems such as algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), ceiba roja (Pachira quinata), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), guácimo (GUazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp. ), laurel (Nectandra sp.), perehuetano (Parinari pachyphylla) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Other species of agrifood importance have also been promoted, including avocado (Persea americana), árbol del pan (Artocarpus altilis) and moringa (Moringa oleifera).This corresponds to mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces in the locality of Bunkwimake, within the mid-altitudinal band between 280 and 340 meters above sea level, in the humid tropical zonobiome, Don Diego River basin, Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds mainly to clean and/or eventually weeded pasture cover in the locality of Bunkwimake, in the average altitudinal strip between 280 and 340 meters above sea level, in the humid tropical zone of the Don Diego river basin, Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco indigenous reservation, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, there is an enrichment of vegetation with species of great timber value and constructive use, including species in the threatened category at the regional and local levels, such as: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracoli (Anacardium excelsum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), roble (Tabebuia sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), and palma amarga (Sabal mauritiformis). There is also the planting of an almost extinct species known locally as Clementino and other key species in the protection of ecosystems such as algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), ceiba roja (Pachira quinata), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), guácimo (GUazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp. ), laurel (Nectandra sp.), perehuetano (Parinari pachyphylla) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Other species of agrifood importance have also been promoted, including avocado (Persea americana), árbol del pan (Artocarpus altilis) and moringa (Moringa oleifera).

In this land cover, enrichment with plant species of high timber value and construction utility stands out, such as: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), oak (Tabebuia sp.), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), laurel (Nectandra sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). To a lesser extent, but with good frequency, species such as algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), kamaleandra (Calliandra sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), among others, have been associated. Likewise, other species important for food security have been promoted, such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), pear (Syzygium malaccense), guamo (Inga sp.), and moringa (Moringa oleifera).
history_site:
Bunkwimake is an Arhuaco territory located near the Don Dieguito River, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada, in the area known as the “exit to the sea” of the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve. It is currently one of the main consolidated population centers in the northern sector of the Sierra. The area lies between 200 and 500 m.a.s.l and is part of the Tropical Humid Zonobiome, which was severely impacted in the late 20th and early 21st centuries thorugh illicit crops.

Nevertheless, through the Plan Colombia—which promoted manual eradication and aerial control of such crops, along with land legislation in favor of the Indigenous Reserve—progress has been made to natural recovery and productive reconversion. Cocoa farming and other semi-permanent crops have become key strategies to gradually improve ecological connectivity indicators and strengthen the local economy.

Burning and deforestation are other historical drivers of transformation that continue their influence in the region, particularly on the southern side of the populated center. Likewise, areas impacted by deforestation in recent decades are highly noticeable in all four cardinal directions; however, some key remnants of dense forest and tall secondary vegetation remain, especially toward the northeastern sector of the populated area.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site:
It corresponds to vegetation cover associated with aquatic ecosystems featuring a permanent water body, either static or flowing, in the locality of Bunkwimake﻿, within the cuenca del río Don Diego﻿, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿.

In this hydrobiome, vegetation enrichment is characterized by the following species: aguacate (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), moringa (Moringa oleifera), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), roble (Tabebuia sp.), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia).

Occasionally, species such as guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), guanabana (Annona muricata), guamo (Inga sp.), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), higuerón (Ficus sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and pera (Syzygium malaccense) are associated within some of the covers of this hydrobiome.

In this land cover, enrichment with plant species of high timber value and construction utility stands out, such as: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), oak (Tabebuia sp.), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), laurel (Nectandra sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). To a lesser extent, but with good frequency, species such as algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), kamaleandra (Calliandra sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), among others, have been associated. Likewise, other species important for food security have been promoted, such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), pear (Syzygium malaccense), guamo (Inga sp.), and moringa (Moringa oleifera).

Likewise, other species important for food security have been promoted, such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), pear (Syzygium malaccense), guamo (Inga sp.), and moringa (Moringa oleifera).Corresponds to areas with a predominance of secondary vegetation or in transition, in the town of Bunkwimake, in the average altitudinal strip between 280 and 340 meters above sea level, once affected by the expansion of the agricultural and livestock frontier in the humid tropical zone, in the basin of the Don Diego River, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, there is an enrichment of vegetation with species of great timber value and constructive use, including species that are threatened at the regional and local levels, such as: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum),caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), roble (Tabebuia sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guasimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), laurel (Nectandra sp), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Other species of importance for food security have also been promoted, such as avocado (Persea americana), guamo (Inga sp.), Moringa (Moringa oleifera) and pear (Syzygium malaccense).

It corresponds mainly to clean and/or eventually weeded pasture cover in the locality of Bunkwimake, in the average altitudinal strip between 280 and 340 meters above sea level, in the humid tropical zone of the Don Diego river basin, Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco indigenous reservation, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, there is an enrichment of vegetation with species of great timber value and constructive use, including species in the threatened category at the regional and local levels, such as: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracoli (Anacardium excelsum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), roble (Tabebuia sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), and palma amarga (Sabal mauritiformis). There is also the planting of an almost extinct species known locally as Clementino and other key species in the protection of ecosystems such as algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), ceiba roja (Pachira quinata), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), guácimo (GUazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp. ), laurel (Nectandra sp.), perehuetano (Parinari pachyphylla) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Other species of agrifood importance have also been promoted, including avocado (Persea americana), árbol del pan (Artocarpus altilis) and moringa (Moringa oleifera).It corresponds to vegetation cover associated with aquatic ecosystems featuring a permanent water body, either static or flowing, in the locality of Bunkwimake﻿, within the cuenca del río Don Diego﻿, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿.
