project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site:
This corresponds to areas dominated by mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces, in the locality of Bunkwamake, within the mid-altitudinal band between 650 and 800 meters above sea level, in the humid tropical zonobiome, Fundación River basin, western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. This land cover is notable for vegetation enrichment with species such as aguacate macho (Persea caerulea), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), cedar (Cedrela odorata), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), laurel (Nectandra sp.), lechoso (Brosimum sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), an unidentified palm, oak (Tabebuia sp.), and tabaco (Pseudosamanea sp.).It mainly corresponds to a mosaic cover of pastures, crops, and natural areas and/or secondary or transitional vegetation, sometimes associated with remnants of dense forest, clean or weedy pastures, and rivers, within the Orobiome of the Sub-Andean Forest in the Bunkwamake sector, in the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.

The main species recorded in this orobiome include: aguacate macho (Ocotea calophylla), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), palm (Palma sp.), oak (Tabebuia sp.), and tabaco (Pseudosamanea sp.).

Less frequently or in smaller proportions, the following species are associated: campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and lechosa (Nectandra sp. 2).
It mainly corresponds to a mosaic cover of pastures, crops, and natural areas and/or secondary or transitional vegetation, sometimes associated with remnants of dense forest, clean or weedy pastures, and rivers, within the Orobiome of the Sub-Andean Forest in the Bunkwamake sector, in the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.

The main species recorded in this orobiome include: aguacate macho (Ocotea calophylla), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), palm (Palma sp.), oak (Tabebuia sp.), and tabaco (Pseudosamanea sp.).

Less frequently or in smaller proportions, the following species are associated: campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and lechosa (Nectandra sp. 2).
It corresponds to riparian vegetation cover associated with rivers in the locality of Bunkwamake, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The main planted species associated with this cover include campano (Samanea saman), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), laurel (Nectandra sp.), lechoso (Brosimum sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), palm, oak (Tabebuia sp.), and tabaco (Pseudosamanea sp.), among others. Less frequent and less dense individuals include aceituno (Vitex cymosa), avocado (Persea americana), aguacatillo (Persea caerulea), jatobá (Hymenaea courbaril), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), and tambor (Schyzolobium parahyba).
history_site:
Bunkwamuke, also popularly known as Galaxia, is a territory of the Arhuaco Indigenous people located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, near the Nabusimake River, within the larger Fundación River. It lies between 700 and 1,250 meters above sea level and shows high signs of landscape fragmentation caused by cumulative deforestation over recent decades. The creation and expansion of gardens or slash-and-burn plots within forest and secondary vegetation areas, along with vegetation burning events, are among the practices driving the observed fragmentation pattern.

The presence of eroded soils, areas affected by terracing, and overgrown pastures are indicators of the progressive deterioration of the landscape associated with livestock farming impacts. These livestock-use areas generally cover polygons with an average size ranging between 4 and 8 hectares. The best-preserved remnants of vegetation correspond to tall secondary growth located near natural drainage systems, which constitute potential germ-plasm banks that could support ecological restoration processes.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site:
It mainly corresponds to a mosaic cover of pastures, crops, and natural areas and/or secondary or transitional vegetation, sometimes associated with remnants of dense forest, clean or weedy pastures, and rivers, within the Orobiome of the Sub-Andean Forest in the Bunkwamake sector, in the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.

The main species recorded in this orobiome include: aguacate macho (Ocotea calophylla), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), palm (Palma sp.), oak (Tabebuia sp.), and tabaco (Pseudosamanea sp.).

history_site:
Bunkwamuke, also popularly known as Galaxia, is a territory of the Arhuaco Indigenous people located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, near the Nabusimake River, within the larger Fundación River. It lies between 700 and 1,250 meters above sea level and shows high signs of landscape fragmentation caused by cumulative deforestation over recent decades. The creation and expansion of gardens or slash-and-burn plots within forest and secondary vegetation areas, along with vegetation burning events, are among the practices driving the observed fragmentation pattern.

The presence of eroded soils, areas affected by terracing, and overgrown pastures are indicators of the progressive deterioration of the landscape associated with livestock farming impacts. These livestock-use areas generally cover polygons with an average size ranging between 4 and 8 hectares. The best-preserved remnants of vegetation correspond to tall secondary growth located near natural drainage systems, which constitute potential germ-plasm banks that could support ecological restoration processes.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site:
It mainly corresponds to a mosaic cover of pastures, crops, and natural areas and/or secondary or transitional vegetation, sometimes associated with remnants of dense forest, clean or weedy pastures, and rivers, within the Orobiome of the Sub-Andean Forest in the Bunkwamake sector, in the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.

The main species recorded in this orobiome include: aguacate macho (Ocotea calophylla), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), palm (Palma sp.), oak (Tabebuia sp.), and tabaco (Pseudosamanea sp.).

Less frequently or in smaller proportions, the following species are associated: campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and lechosa (Nectandra sp. 2).

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site:
This corresponds to areas dominated by mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces, in the locality of Bunkwamake, within the mid-altitudinal band between 650 and 800 meters above sea level, in the humid tropical zonobiome, Fundación River basin, western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. This land cover is notable for vegetation enrichment with species such as aguacate macho (Persea caerulea), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), cedar (Cedrela odorata), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), laurel (Nectandra sp.), lechoso (Brosimum sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), an unidentified palm, oak (Tabebuia sp.), and tabaco (Pseudosamanea sp.).It mainly corresponds to a mosaic cover of pastures, crops, and natural areas and/or secondary or transitional vegetation, sometimes associated with remnants of dense forest, clean or weedy pastures, and rivers, within the Orobiome of the Sub-Andean Forest in the Bunkwamake sector, in the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.

The main species recorded in this orobiome include: aguacate macho (Ocotea calophylla), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), palm (Palma sp.), oak (Tabebuia sp.), and tabaco (Pseudosamanea sp.).

Less frequently or in smaller proportions, the following species are associated: campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and lechosa (Nectandra sp. 2).
It corresponds to riparian vegetation cover associated with rivers in the locality of Bunkwamake, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The main planted species associated with this cover include campano (Samanea saman), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), laurel (Nectandra sp.), lechoso (Brosimum sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), palm, oak (Tabebuia sp.), and tabaco (Pseudosamanea sp.), among others. Less frequent and less dense individuals include aceituno (Vitex cymosa), avocado (Persea americana), aguacatillo (Persea caerulea), jatobá (Hymenaea courbaril), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), and tambor (Schyzolobium parahyba).

Corresponds to areas with a predominance of secondary vegetation or in transition, in the town of Bunkwimake, in the average altitudinal strip between 280 and 340 meters above sea level, once affected by the expansion of the agricultural and livestock frontier in the humid tropical zone, in the basin of the Don Diego River, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, there is an enrichment of vegetation with species of great timber value and constructive use, including species that are threatened at the regional and local levels, such as: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum),caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), roble (Tabebuia sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guasimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), laurel (Nectandra sp), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Other species of importance for food security have also been promoted, such as avocado (Persea americana), guamo (Inga sp.), Moringa (Moringa oleifera) and pear (Syzygium malaccense).It mainly corresponds to a mosaic cover of pastures, crops, and natural areas and/or secondary or transitional vegetation, sometimes associated with remnants of dense forest, clean or weedy pastures, and rivers, within the Orobiome of the Sub-Andean Forest in the Bunkwamake sector, in the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.

Less frequently or in smaller proportions, the following species are associated: campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and lechosa (Nectandra sp. 2).
It corresponds to riparian vegetation cover associated with rivers in the locality of Bunkwamake, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The main planted species associated with this cover include campano (Samanea saman), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), laurel (Nectandra sp.), lechoso (Brosimum sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), palm, oak (Tabebuia sp.), and tabaco (Pseudosamanea sp.), among others. Less frequent and less dense individuals include aceituno (Vitex cymosa), avocado (Persea americana), aguacatillo (Persea caerulea), jatobá (Hymenaea courbaril), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), and tambor (Schyzolobium parahyba).
history_site:
Bunkwamuke, also popularly known as Galaxia, is a territory of the Arhuaco Indigenous people located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, near the Nabusimake River, within the larger Fundación River. It lies between 700 and 1,250 meters above sea level and shows high signs of landscape fragmentation caused by cumulative deforestation over recent decades. The creation and expansion of gardens or slash-and-burn plots within forest and secondary vegetation areas, along with vegetation burning events, are among the practices driving the observed fragmentation pattern.

The presence of eroded soils, areas affected by terracing, and overgrown pastures are indicators of the progressive deterioration of the landscape associated with livestock farming impacts. These livestock-use areas generally cover polygons with an average size ranging between 4 and 8 hectares. The best-preserved remnants of vegetation correspond to tall secondary growth located near natural drainage systems, which constitute potential germ-plasm banks that could support ecological restoration processes.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site:
It mainly corresponds to a mosaic cover of pastures, crops, and natural areas and/or secondary or transitional vegetation, sometimes associated with remnants of dense forest, within the Orobiome of the Sub-Andean Forest in the Dwanawimaku sector, in the Aracataca River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.

The main species recorded in this orobiome include: aguacatillo (Persea caerulea), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), laurel (Nectandra sp.), pepa de loro (Nectandra sp. 2), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia).

Less frequently, species such as avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), fruto de mico, gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guamo de piedra (Zygia longifolia), soursop (Annona sp.), moringa (Moringa oleifera), walnut (Cordia sp.), sapote (Pouteria sapota), and trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia) are recorded.
history_site:
Dwanawimaku, more commonly known as Campamento, is a territory of the Arhuaco Indigenous people located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, between the Chinchorro stream and the main channel of the Aracataca River. This territory lies between 600 and 1,400 m.a.s.l and shows moderate signs of landscape fragmentation. Accumulated deforestation is mainly concentrated on the right bank—downstream—of the Aracataca River, as well as in the northern and eastern areas of the populated center.

In contrast, the southern side of the locality contains a block of forest with very low levels of intervention and/or deforestation over the past three decades, thus serving as a reference ecosystem to guide medium- and long-term ecological restoration objectives. The eastern slope, where the populated center is located, presents eroded and degraded soils caused by livestock activity, associated with a matrix of clean and overgrown pastures on polygons larger than 4 hectares. Similarly, the largest degraded areas affected by burning and agricultural frontier expansion are found in the upper zones and along the right bank—downstream—of the Chinchorro stream.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site:
It mainly corresponds to a mosaic cover of pastures, crops, and natural areas and/or secondary or transitional vegetation, sometimes associated with remnants of dense forest, within the Orobiome of the Sub-Andean Forest in the Dwanawimaku sector, in the Aracataca River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.

The main species recorded in this orobiome include: aguacatillo (Persea caerulea), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), laurel (Nectandra sp.), pepa de loro (Nectandra sp. 2), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia).

Less frequently, species such as avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), fruto de mico, gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guamo de piedra (Zygia longifolia), soursop (Annona sp.), moringa (Moringa oleifera), walnut (Cordia sp.), sapote (Pouteria sapota), and trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia) are recorded.
history_site:

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site:
It corresponds to vegetation cover associated with aquatic ecosystems featuring a permanent water body, either static or flowing, in the locality of Dwanawimaku, within the Aracataca River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.

In this hydrobiome, vegetation enrichment is characterized by the following species: aguacatillo (Persea sp.), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guamo (Inga sp.), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), laurel (Nectandra sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia).

Occasionally, species such as caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), walnut (Cordia sp.), and sula (Trema sp.) are associated with the mosaics of crops, pastures, and natural areas within this hydrobiome.

Less frequently, species such as avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), fruto de mico, gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guamo de piedra (Zygia longifolia), soursop (Annona sp.), moringa (Moringa oleifera), walnut (Cordia sp.), sapote (Pouteria sapota), and trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia) are recorded.
history_site:
Dwanawimaku, more commonly known as Campamento, is a territory of the Arhuaco Indigenous people located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, between the Chinchorro stream and the main channel of the Aracataca River. This territory lies between 600 and 1,400 m.a.s.l and shows moderate signs of landscape fragmentation. Accumulated deforestation is mainly concentrated on the right bank—downstream—of the Aracataca River, as well as in the northern and eastern areas of the populated center.

In contrast, the southern side of the locality contains a block of forest with very low levels of intervention and/or deforestation over the past three decades, thus serving as a reference ecosystem to guide medium- and long-term ecological restoration objectives. The eastern slope, where the populated center is located, presents eroded and degraded soils caused by livestock activity, associated with a matrix of clean and overgrown pastures on polygons larger than 4 hectares. Similarly, the largest degraded areas affected by burning and agricultural frontier expansion are found in the upper zones and along the right bank—downstream—of the Chinchorro stream.

Accumulated deforestation is mainly concentrated on the right bank—downstream—of the Aracataca River, as well as in the northern and eastern areas of the populated center.

In contrast, the southern side of the locality contains a block of forest with very low levels of intervention and/or deforestation over the past three decades, thus serving as a reference ecosystem to guide medium- and long-term ecological restoration objectives. The eastern slope, where the populated center is located, presents eroded and degraded soils caused by livestock activity, associated with a matrix of clean and overgrown pastures on polygons larger than 4 hectares. Similarly, the largest degraded areas affected by burning and agricultural frontier expansion are found in the upper zones and along the right bank—downstream—of the Chinchorro stream.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site:
It mainly corresponds to a mosaic cover of pastures, crops, and natural areas and/or secondary or transitional vegetation, sometimes associated with remnants of dense forest, within the Orobiome of the Sub-Andean Forest in the Dwanawimaku sector, in the Aracataca River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.

The main species recorded in this orobiome include: aguacatillo (Persea caerulea), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), laurel (Nectandra sp.), pepa de loro (Nectandra sp. 2), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia).

Less frequently, species such as avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), fruto de mico, gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guamo de piedra (Zygia longifolia), soursop (Annona sp.), moringa (Moringa oleifera), walnut (Cordia sp.), sapote (Pouteria sapota), and trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia) are recorded.

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This corresponds to areas dominated by mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces, in the locality of Gunmaku﻿, at the boundaries of the basins of the ríos Tucurinca y Aracataca﻿, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿, within a mid-altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this land cover, vegetation enrichment stands out with species among which are notable: algarrobo (Samanea saman)﻿, campano (Samanea saman)﻿, caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum)﻿, caoba (Swietenia macrophylla)﻿, caracolí (Anacardium excelsum)﻿, cedro (Cedrela odorata)﻿, ceiba roja (Pachira quinata)﻿, cuchillito (Senna sp.)﻿, dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria)﻿, dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria)﻿, fruto de mico﻿, guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum)﻿, guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia)﻿, gusanero (Astronium graveolens)﻿, laulel (Nectandra sp.)﻿, malambo (Croton malambo)﻿, orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum)﻿, pepa de loro (Nectandra sp2)﻿, roble (Tabebuia sp.)﻿, trompito (Lafoensia puncifolia)﻿, and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia)﻿. In the crops, species of agro-food importance such as: aguacate (Persea americana)﻿, cañandonga (Cassia grandis)﻿, pera (Zyzygium malaccense)﻿, guamo (Inga sp.)﻿, gualanday (Jacaranda sp.)﻿, and moringa (Moringa oleifera)﻿ have been associated.Corresponds to areas with a predominance of gallery forest cover in the locality of Gunmaku, in the limits of the Tucurinca and Aracataca river basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this coverage, the vegetation is enriched with important timber species, especially with constructive use value, among which stand out: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril),caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedro (Cedrela odorata), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guacimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), roble (Tabebuia sp.) and trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia). In addition, other species of community importance such as avocado (Persea americana) and Moringa (Moringa oleifera) have been planted in association with these cover crops, which favor the Arhuaca population's expectations for their own economy and food security.It corresponds to areas with a predominance of shrub cover in the Gunmaku locality, on the limits of the Tucurinca and Aracataca river basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this coverage, the vegetation is enriched with important timber species such as: caoba (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedro (Cedrela odorata), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guasimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), roble (Tabebuia sp.) and granadillo (Lafoensia punicifolia). Some fruit species of agrifood importance have also been associated with this cover, such as avocado (Persea americana), cañandonga (Cassia grandis), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guamo (Inga sp.) and moringa (Moringa oleifera).
history_site:
Gunmaku is an Arhuaco Indigenous settlement located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, between the Tucurinca River and the Tres Vueltas stream. This territory lies between 350 and 600 ma.s.l, with a significant presence of areas degraded by overgrazing, particularly north of the populated center, on the right bank—downstream—of the Tucurinca River, where a polygon of more than 100 hectares with bare and degraded soils, as well as open grasslands with scattered trees can be observed.

The historical intensity of livestock activity in this area is evident from the terracing scars visible on the hillside and hilltop landscapes. Although scarce, secondary vegetation is mainly found to the south and southeast of the populated center. The abundance of wine palm (Attalea butyracea) standing out in the landscape on the western side of Gunmaku suggests that these areas have been historically subjected to disturbance through burning.

The gallery forest belt is moderately interrupted by the presence of agricultural crops; however, it maintains an average width of 30 to 50 meters in the best-preserved corridors.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to areas dominated by clean pastures in the locality of Gunmaku, on the boundaries of the Tucurinca and Aracataca river basins, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, within a mid-altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this land cover, vegetation enrichment with species of timber importance stands out, especially those with constructive uses, among which the following are notable: aguacatillo (Persea sp.), campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), cuchillito (Senna sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), fruto de mico (unspecified), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), guamito de piedra (Zygia longifolia), guamo (Inga sp.), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.), oak (Tabebuia sp.), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), and trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia). A remarkable feature in this land cover is the planting of a species considered almost exclusive to this area of the Sierra, locally known as pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.).Corresponds to areas with a predominance of gallery forest cover in the locality of Gunmaku, in the limits of the Tucurinca and Aracataca river basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this coverage, the vegetation is enriched with important timber species, especially with constructive use value, among which stand out: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril),caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedro (Cedrela odorata), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guacimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), roble (Tabebuia sp.) and trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia). In addition, other species of community importance such as avocado (Persea americana) and Moringa (Moringa oleifera) have been planted in association with these cover crops, which favor the Arhuaca population's expectations for their own economy and food security.

description_site:
It corresponds to vegetation cover associated with aquatic ecosystems featuring a permanent water body, either static or flowing, in the locality of Gunmaku, between the Aracataca and Tucurinca river basins, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.

In this hydrobiome, vegetation enrichment is characterized by the following species: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), cañandonga (Cassia grandis), cedar (Cedrela odorata), laurel (Nectandra sp.), palm (Palma sp.), pear tree (Syzygium malaccense), oak (Tabebuia sp.), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia).This corresponds to areas dominated by mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces, in the locality of Gunmaku﻿, at the boundaries of the basins of the ríos Tucurinca y Aracataca﻿, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿, within a mid-altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In the crops, species of agro-food importance such as: aguacate (Persea americana)﻿, cañandonga (Cassia grandis)﻿, pera (Zyzygium malaccense)﻿, guamo (Inga sp.)﻿, gualanday (Jacaranda sp.)﻿, and moringa (Moringa oleifera)﻿ have been associated.It corresponds to the vegetation cover associated with the river in the locality of Gunmaku, at the boundary between the Tucurinca and Aracataca river basins, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this cover, vegetation enrichment stands out with the following species: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), cañandonga (Cassia grandis), cedar (Cedrela odorata), laurel (Nectandra sp.), unspecified palm, pear (Syzygium malaccense), oak (Tabebuia sp.), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Among all the mentioned species, palm is the most abundant element.It corresponds to vegetation cover associated with aquatic ecosystems featuring a permanent water body, either static or flowing, in the locality of Gunmaku, between the Aracataca and Tucurinca river basins, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.

In this hydrobiome, vegetation enrichment is characterized by the following species: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), cañandonga (Cassia grandis), cedar (Cedrela odorata), laurel (Nectandra sp.), palm (Palma sp.), pear tree (Syzygium malaccense), oak (Tabebuia sp.), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia).
history_site:
Gunmaku is an Arhuaco Indigenous settlement located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, between the Tucurinca River and the Tres Vueltas stream. This territory lies between 350 and 600 ma.s.l, with a significant presence of areas degraded by overgrazing, particularly north of the populated center, on the right bank—downstream—of the Tucurinca River, where a polygon of more than 100 hectares with bare and degraded soils, as well as open grasslands with scattered trees can be observed.

The historical intensity of livestock activity in this area is evident from the terracing scars visible on the hillside and hilltop landscapes. Although scarce, secondary vegetation is mainly found to the south and southeast of the populated center. The abundance of wine palm (Attalea butyracea) standing out in the landscape on the western side of Gunmaku suggests that these areas have been historically subjected to disturbance through burning.

The gallery forest belt is moderately interrupted by the presence of agricultural crops; however, it maintains an average width of 30 to 50 meters in the best-preserved corridors.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site:
It mainly corresponds to a mosaic coverage of pastures, crops, and natural areas and/or secondary or transitional vegetation, sometimes associated with remnants of dense forest, clean or weedy pastures, and rivers within the Sub-Andean Forest orobiome of the Gunmaku sector, bordering the Aracataca and Tucurinca river basins on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.

The main species associated with this orobiome include: aguacatillo (Persea caerulea), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), guamo (Inga sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), laurel (Nectandra sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), oak (Tabebuia sp.), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia).

With moderate representativeness, one can also find species such as Brosimum alicastrum (breadnut), Jacaranda sp. (gualanday), Zygia longifolia (stone guamo), Moringa oleifera (moringa), and various palms. Less commonly associated species include Aspidosperma polyneuron (carreto), Erythrina edulis (mountain immortelle or chachafruto), Ochroma pyramidale (balsa), Senna sp. (cuchillito), Persea americana (avocado), Handroanthus chrysantha (yellow ipe or guayacán), Calophyllum sp. (guayabito), Cordia sp. (nogal), Lafoensia punicifolia (trompito), Miconia sp. (tuno), and Nectandra sp. (pepa de loro), among others.

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to areas dominated by clean pastures in the locality of Gunmaku, on the boundaries of the Tucurinca and Aracataca river basins, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, within a mid-altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this land cover, vegetation enrichment with species of timber importance stands out, especially those with constructive uses, among which the following are notable: aguacatillo (Persea sp.), campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), cuchillito (Senna sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), fruto de mico (unspecified), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), guamito de piedra (Zygia longifolia), guamo (Inga sp.), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.), oak (Tabebuia sp.), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), and trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia). A remarkable feature in this land cover is the planting of a species considered almost exclusive to this area of the Sierra, locally known as pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.).Corresponds to areas with a predominance of secondary vegetation in the locality of Gunmaku, in the limits of the Tucurinca and Aracataca river basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this coverage, there are important timber species such as: aguacatillo (Persea caerulea), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedro (Cedrela odorata), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), fruta de mico (Bursera simaruba), guamo de piedra (Zygia longifolia), guasimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), roble (Tabebuia sp.), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia) and granadillo (Lafoensia punicifolia).

(gualanday), Zygia longifolia (stone guamo), Moringa oleifera (moringa), and various palms. Less commonly associated species include Aspidosperma polyneuron (carreto), Erythrina edulis (mountain immortelle or chachafruto), Ochroma pyramidale (balsa), Senna sp. (cuchillito), Persea americana (avocado), Handroanthus chrysantha (yellow ipe or guayacán), Calophyllum sp. (guayabito), Cordia sp. (nogal), Lafoensia punicifolia (trompito), Miconia sp. (tuno), and Nectandra sp. (pepa de loro), among others.
history_site:
Gunmaku is an Arhuaco Indigenous settlement located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, between the Tucurinca River and the Tres Vueltas stream. This territory lies between 350 and 600 ma.s.l, with a significant presence of areas degraded by overgrazing, particularly north of the populated center, on the right bank—downstream—of the Tucurinca River, where a polygon of more than 100 hectares with bare and degraded soils, as well as open grasslands with scattered trees can be observed.

The historical intensity of livestock activity in this area is evident from the terracing scars visible on the hillside and hilltop landscapes. Although scarce, secondary vegetation is mainly found to the south and southeast of the populated center. The abundance of wine palm (Attalea butyracea) standing out in the landscape on the western side of Gunmaku suggests that these areas have been historically subjected to disturbance through burning.

The gallery forest belt is moderately interrupted by the presence of agricultural crops; however, it maintains an average width of 30 to 50 meters in the best-preserved corridors.

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to areas dominated by clean pastures in the locality of Gunmaku, on the boundaries of the Tucurinca and Aracataca river basins, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, within a mid-altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this land cover, vegetation enrichment with species of timber importance stands out, especially those with constructive uses, among which the following are notable: aguacatillo (Persea sp.), campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), cuchillito (Senna sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), fruto de mico (unspecified), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), guamito de piedra (Zygia longifolia), guamo (Inga sp.), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.), oak (Tabebuia sp.), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), and trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia). A remarkable feature in this land cover is the planting of a species considered almost exclusive to this area of the Sierra, locally known as pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.).Corresponds to areas with a predominance of secondary vegetation in the locality of Gunmaku, in the limits of the Tucurinca and Aracataca river basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this coverage, there are important timber species such as: aguacatillo (Persea caerulea), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedro (Cedrela odorata), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), fruta de mico (Bursera simaruba), guamo de piedra (Zygia longifolia), guasimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), roble (Tabebuia sp.), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia) and granadillo (Lafoensia punicifolia).

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This corresponds to areas dominated by mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces, in the locality of Gunmaku﻿, at the boundaries of the basins of the ríos Tucurinca y Aracataca﻿, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿, within a mid-altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this land cover, vegetation enrichment stands out with species among which are notable: algarrobo (Samanea saman)﻿, campano (Samanea saman)﻿, caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum)﻿, caoba (Swietenia macrophylla)﻿, caracolí (Anacardium excelsum)﻿, cedro (Cedrela odorata)﻿, ceiba roja (Pachira quinata)﻿, cuchillito (Senna sp.)﻿, dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria)﻿, dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria)﻿, fruto de mico﻿, guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum)﻿, guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia)﻿, gusanero (Astronium graveolens)﻿, laulel (Nectandra sp.)﻿, malambo (Croton malambo)﻿, orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum)﻿, pepa de loro (Nectandra sp2)﻿, roble (Tabebuia sp.)﻿, trompito (Lafoensia puncifolia)﻿, and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia)﻿. In the crops, species of agro-food importance such as: aguacate (Persea americana)﻿, cañandonga (Cassia grandis)﻿, pera (Zyzygium malaccense)﻿, guamo (Inga sp.)﻿, gualanday (Jacaranda sp.)﻿, and moringa (Moringa oleifera)﻿ have been associated.Corresponds to areas with a predominance of secondary vegetation in the locality of Gunmaku, in the limits of the Tucurinca and Aracataca river basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this coverage, there are important timber species such as: aguacatillo (Persea caerulea), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedro (Cedrela odorata), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), fruta de mico (Bursera simaruba), guamo de piedra (Zygia longifolia), guasimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), roble (Tabebuia sp.), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia) and granadillo (Lafoensia punicifolia).

history_site:
Gunmaku is an Arhuaco Indigenous settlement located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, between the Tucurinca River and the Tres Vueltas stream. This territory lies between 350 and 600 ma.s.l, with a significant presence of areas degraded by overgrazing, particularly north of the populated center, on the right bank—downstream—of the Tucurinca River, where a polygon of more than 100 hectares with bare and degraded soils, as well as open grasslands with scattered trees can be observed.

The historical intensity of livestock activity in this area is evident from the terracing scars visible on the hillside and hilltop landscapes. Although scarce, secondary vegetation is mainly found to the south and southeast of the populated center. The abundance of wine palm (Attalea butyracea) standing out in the landscape on the western side of Gunmaku suggests that these areas have been historically subjected to disturbance through burning.

The gallery forest belt is moderately interrupted by the presence of agricultural crops; however, it maintains an average width of 30 to 50 meters in the best-preserved corridors.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site:
It mainly corresponds to a mosaic coverage of pastures, crops, and natural areas and/or secondary or transitional vegetation, sometimes associated with remnants of dense forest, clean or weedy pastures, and rivers within the Sub-Andean Forest orobiome of the Gunmaku sector, bordering the Aracataca and Tucurinca river basins on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.

The main species associated with this orobiome include: aguacatillo (Persea caerulea), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), guamo (Inga sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), laurel (Nectandra sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), oak (Tabebuia sp.), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia).

With moderate representativeness, one can also find species such as Brosimum alicastrum (breadnut), Jacaranda sp. (gualanday), Zygia longifolia (stone guamo), Moringa oleifera (moringa), and various palms. Less commonly associated species include Aspidosperma polyneuron (carreto), Erythrina edulis (mountain immortelle or chachafruto), Ochroma pyramidale (balsa), Senna sp. (cuchillito), Persea americana (avocado), Handroanthus chrysantha (yellow ipe or guayacán), Calophyllum sp. (guayabito), Cordia sp. (nogal), Lafoensia punicifolia (trompito), Miconia sp. (tuno), and Nectandra sp. (pepa de loro), among others.

This territory lies between 350 and 600 ma.s.l, with a significant presence of areas degraded by overgrazing, particularly north of the populated center, on the right bank—downstream—of the Tucurinca River, where a polygon of more than 100 hectares with bare and degraded soils, as well as open grasslands with scattered trees can be observed.

The historical intensity of livestock activity in this area is evident from the terracing scars visible on the hillside and hilltop landscapes. Although scarce, secondary vegetation is mainly found to the south and southeast of the populated center. The abundance of wine palm (Attalea butyracea) standing out in the landscape on the western side of Gunmaku suggests that these areas have been historically subjected to disturbance through burning.

The gallery forest belt is moderately interrupted by the presence of agricultural crops; however, it maintains an average width of 30 to 50 meters in the best-preserved corridors.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site:
It mainly corresponds to a mosaic coverage of pastures, crops, and natural areas and/or secondary or transitional vegetation, sometimes associated with remnants of dense forest, clean or weedy pastures, and rivers within the Sub-Andean Forest orobiome of the Gunmaku sector, bordering the Aracataca and Tucurinca river basins on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.

The main species associated with this orobiome include: aguacatillo (Persea caerulea), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), guamo (Inga sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), laurel (Nectandra sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), oak (Tabebuia sp.), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia).

With moderate representativeness, one can also find species such as Brosimum alicastrum (breadnut), Jacaranda sp. (gualanday), Zygia longifolia (stone guamo), Moringa oleifera (moringa), and various palms. Less commonly associated species include Aspidosperma polyneuron (carreto), Erythrina edulis (mountain immortelle or chachafruto), Ochroma pyramidale (balsa), Senna sp. (cuchillito), Persea americana (avocado), Handroanthus chrysantha (yellow ipe or guayacán), Calophyllum sp. (guayabito), Cordia sp. (nogal), Lafoensia punicifolia (trompito), Miconia sp. (tuno), and Nectandra sp. (pepa de loro), among others.

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This corresponds to areas dominated by mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces, in the locality of Gunmaku﻿, at the boundaries of the basins of the ríos Tucurinca y Aracataca﻿, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿, within a mid-altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this land cover, vegetation enrichment stands out with species among which are notable: algarrobo (Samanea saman)﻿, campano (Samanea saman)﻿, caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum)﻿, caoba (Swietenia macrophylla)﻿, caracolí (Anacardium excelsum)﻿, cedro (Cedrela odorata)﻿, ceiba roja (Pachira quinata)﻿, cuchillito (Senna sp.)﻿, dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria)﻿, dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria)﻿, fruto de mico﻿, guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum)﻿, guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia)﻿, gusanero (Astronium graveolens)﻿, laulel (Nectandra sp.)﻿, malambo (Croton malambo)﻿, orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum)﻿, pepa de loro (Nectandra sp2)﻿, roble (Tabebuia sp.)﻿, trompito (Lafoensia puncifolia)﻿, and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia)﻿. In the crops, species of agro-food importance such as: aguacate (Persea americana)﻿, cañandonga (Cassia grandis)﻿, pera (Zyzygium malaccense)﻿, guamo (Inga sp.)﻿, gualanday (Jacaranda sp.)﻿, and moringa (Moringa oleifera)﻿ have been associated.Corresponds to areas with a predominance of gallery forest cover in the locality of Gunmaku, in the limits of the Tucurinca and Aracataca river basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this coverage, the vegetation is enriched with important timber species, especially with constructive use value, among which stand out: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril),caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedro (Cedrela odorata), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guacimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), roble (Tabebuia sp.) and trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia). In addition, other species of community importance such as avocado (Persea americana) and Moringa (Moringa oleifera) have been planted in association with these cover crops, which favor the Arhuaca population's expectations for their own economy and food security.

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: Corresponds to areas with a predominance of secondary vegetation cover or in transition, in the locality of Kankawarwa, in the basin of the Fundación River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In this coverage, the vegetation is enriched with important timber species, including: carob (Hymenaea courbaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), carob (Aspidosperma polyneuron), cedar (Cedrela odorata), kapok (Ceiba pentandra), red kapok (Pachira quinata), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guacimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and oak (Tabebuia sp.). In the same way, the planting of important food crops such as avocado (Persea americana) and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum) has been promoted, which favors the Arhuaca population's expectations for their own economy and food security. The planting of an unspecified palm has been promoted in these areas.It mainly corresponds to a cover mosaic of pastures, crops, and natural spaces and/or secondary or transitional vegetation, eventually associated with remnants of dense forest, clean or weedy pastures, and rivers in the Sub-Andean rainforest orobiome of the Kankawarwa sector, Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The representative species associated with the covers of this Orobiome include: cedar (Cedrela odorata) and oak (Tabebuia sp.). Common species include: avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), and mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla). Occasionally associated species include: cachimbo (Erythrina sp.), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), red ceiba (Pachira quinata), cuchillito (Senna sp.), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guáimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guamo (Inga sp.), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), palm, and perehuétano (Parinari pachyphylla).﻿
history_site:
Kankawarwa is located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, in the Fundación River basin, within the lower La Cristalina area, between 250 and 500 m.a.s.l. This village was founded in 2009 on a 114-hectare property purchased by the Governor’s Office of Magdalena as part of the establishment of the so-called "pueblos talanquera", within the strategic project known as the “Environmental and Traditional Belt of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.”

It is an area of environmental and cultural importance situated in the lower part of the Sierra Nevada, between La Cristalina stream and the Nabusimake River, where the Arhuaco people have designated one sector for community services and another for traditional living. The region has been affected by historical colonization processes that have led to high levels of landscape fragmentation, mainly linked to cattle farming activities. The relictual state of original forest cover and the loss of native, high-value timber species are some of the visible outcomes of this colonization.

The northern part of the populated center was particularly deforested between 2013 and 2017, according to data from the Global Forest Change observatory and geoportal.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site:
This corresponds to a land cover identified as discontinuous urban fabric in the locality of Kankawarwa, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in a mid-altitudinal band between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In this land cover, vegetation enrichment is notable with timber species, especially those valued for construction use, among which cedar (Cedrela odorata), red ceiba (Pachira quinata), and gusanero (Astronium graveolens) stand out. To a lesser extent but of equal importance, associated species include avocado (Persea americana), cachimbo (Erythrina sp.), guayacán (Tabebuia chrysanthus), moringa (Moringa oleifera), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), an unidentified palm, and oak (Tabebuia sp.).It corresponds to vegetation cover associated with aquatic ecosystems featuring a permanent water body, either static or flowing, in the locality of Kankawarwa, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.

In this hydrobiome, vegetation enrichment is primarily represented by the following species: oak (Tabebuia sp.), avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), guamo (Inga sp.), and orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum).

To a lesser extent, the following species are also associated: aceituno (Vitex cymosa), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cascarillo (Protium sp.), tambor (Schyzolobium parahyba), and zapote cachaco (Matisia cordata).It corresponds to vegetation cover associated with aquatic ecosystems featuring a permanent water body, either static or flowing, in the locality of Kankawarwa, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.

In this hydrobiome, vegetation enrichment is primarily represented by the following species: oak (Tabebuia sp.), avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), guamo (Inga sp.), and orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum).

To a lesser extent, the following species are also associated: aceituno (Vitex cymosa), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cascarillo (Protium sp.), tambor (Schyzolobium parahyba), and zapote cachaco (Matisia cordata).This corresponds to areas dominated by mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces in the locality of Kankawarwa﻿, in the cuenca del río Fundación﻿, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿, within a mid-altitudinal band between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In this land cover, vegetation enrichment is notable with timber species of constructive value, among which the following stand out: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril)﻿, campano (Samanea saman)﻿, caoba (Swietenia macrophylla)﻿, carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron)﻿, cedro (Cedrela odorata)﻿, ceiba (Ceiba pentandra)﻿, ceiba roja (Pachira quinata)﻿, cuchillito (Senna sp.)﻿, dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria)﻿, dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria)﻿, guácimo (Guazuma ulmofolia)﻿, guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus)﻿, gusanero (Astronium graveolens)﻿, orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum)﻿, roble (Tabebuia sp.)﻿, and tabaco (Pseudosamanea sp.)﻿. Similarly, the planting of other species of agro-food importance has been promoted, such as aguacate (Persea americana)﻿, pera (Zyzygium malaccense)﻿, zapote (Pouteria zapota)﻿, and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum)﻿, which support the economic expectations and food security of the población arhuaca﻿. In these land covers, the planting of an unspecified palm and another species locally known as cachimbo (Erythrina sp.)﻿ has also been promoted.Gallery forest and/or fragmented forest cover predominates in the Kankawarwa locality, in the Fundación river basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in a medium altitudinal range between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In this cover, plant enrichment stands out with timber species of importance, especially with constructive use value, including notable species such as: caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), cuchillito (Senna sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guacimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), oak (Tabebuia sp.), tambor (Schizolobium parahyba) and totumo (Crescentia cujete). Similarly associated with these covers, the planting of other species of community importance such as avocado (Persea americana) and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum) has been promoted, which favor the expectations of the Arhuaco population's own economy and food security. In these covers, the planting of an unspecified palm and another species locally known as cachimbo (Erythrina sp) has also been promoted.Corresponds to areas with a predominance of secondary vegetation cover or in transition, in the locality of Kankawarwa, in the basin of the Fundación River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In this coverage, the vegetation is enriched with important timber species, including: carob (Hymenaea courbaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), carob (Aspidosperma polyneuron), cedar (Cedrela odorata), kapok (Ceiba pentandra), red kapok (Pachira quinata), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guacimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and oak (Tabebuia sp.). In the same way, the planting of important food crops such as avocado (Persea americana) and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum) has been promoted, which favors the Arhuaca population's expectations for their own economy and food security. The planting of an unspecified palm has been promoted in these areas.It corresponds to the vegetation cover associated with the river in the locality of Kankawarwa, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this cover, vegetation enrichment stands out with the following species: mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), and oak (Tabebuia sp.). Additionally, the establishment of other species of timber and agroforestry importance has been promoted, including avocado (Persea americana), cachimbo (Erythrina sp.), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), red ceiba (Pachira quinata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), palm, and tobacco (Pseudosamanea sp.).It corresponds to vegetation cover associated with aquatic ecosystems featuring a permanent water body, either static or flowing, in the locality of Kankawarwa, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.

In this hydrobiome, vegetation enrichment is primarily represented by the following species: oak (Tabebuia sp.), avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), guamo (Inga sp.), and orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum).

To a lesser extent, the following species are also associated: aceituno (Vitex cymosa), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cascarillo (Protium sp.), tambor (Schyzolobium parahyba), and zapote cachaco (Matisia cordata).
history_site:
Kankawarwa is located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, in the Fundación River basin, within the lower La Cristalina area, between 250 and 500 m.a.s.l. This village was founded in 2009 on a 114-hectare property purchased by the Governor’s Office of Magdalena as part of the establishment of the so-called "pueblos talanquera", within the strategic project known as the “Environmental and Traditional Belt of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.”

It is an area of environmental and cultural importance situated in the lower part of the Sierra Nevada, between La Cristalina stream and the Nabusimake River, where the Arhuaco people have designated one sector for community services and another for traditional living. The region has been affected by historical colonization processes that have led to high levels of landscape fragmentation, mainly linked to cattle farming activities. The relictual state of original forest cover and the loss of native, high-value timber species are some of the visible outcomes of this colonization.

The northern part of the populated center was particularly deforested between 2013 and 2017, according to data from the Global Forest Change observatory and geoportal.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It mainly corresponds to a cover mosaic of pastures, crops, and natural spaces and/or secondary or transitional vegetation, eventually associated with remnants of dense forest, clean or weedy pastures, and rivers in the Sub-Andean rainforest orobiome of the Kankawarwa sector, Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The representative species associated with the covers of this Orobiome include: cedar (Cedrela odorata) and oak (Tabebuia sp.). Common species include: avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), and mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla). Occasionally associated species include: cachimbo (Erythrina sp.), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), red ceiba (Pachira quinata), cuchillito (Senna sp.), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guáimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guamo (Inga sp.), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), palm, and perehuétano (Parinari pachyphylla).﻿

In these covers, the planting of an unspecified palm and another species locally known as cachimbo (Erythrina sp) has also been promoted.

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This corresponds to areas dominated by mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces in the locality of Kankawarwa﻿, in the cuenca del río Fundación﻿, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿, within a mid-altitudinal band between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In this land cover, vegetation enrichment is notable with timber species of constructive value, among which the following stand out: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril)﻿, campano (Samanea saman)﻿, caoba (Swietenia macrophylla)﻿, carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron)﻿, cedro (Cedrela odorata)﻿, ceiba (Ceiba pentandra)﻿, ceiba roja (Pachira quinata)﻿, cuchillito (Senna sp.)﻿, dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria)﻿, dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria)﻿, guácimo (Guazuma ulmofolia)﻿, guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus)﻿, gusanero (Astronium graveolens)﻿, orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum)﻿, roble (Tabebuia sp.)﻿, and tabaco (Pseudosamanea sp.)﻿. Similarly, the planting of other species of agro-food importance has been promoted, such as aguacate (Persea americana)﻿, pera (Zyzygium malaccense)﻿, zapote (Pouteria zapota)﻿, and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum)﻿, which support the economic expectations and food security of the población arhuaca﻿. In these land covers, the planting of an unspecified palm and another species locally known as cachimbo (Erythrina sp.)﻿ has also been promoted.

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: Corresponds to areas with a predominance of secondary vegetation cover or in transition, in the locality of Kankawarwa, in the basin of the Fundación River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In this coverage, the vegetation is enriched with important timber species, including: carob (Hymenaea courbaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), carob (Aspidosperma polyneuron), cedar (Cedrela odorata), kapok (Ceiba pentandra), red kapok (Pachira quinata), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guacimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and oak (Tabebuia sp.). In the same way, the planting of important food crops such as avocado (Persea americana) and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum) has been promoted, which favors the Arhuaca population's expectations for their own economy and food security. The planting of an unspecified palm has been promoted in these areas.It mainly corresponds to a cover mosaic of pastures, crops, and natural spaces and/or secondary or transitional vegetation, eventually associated with remnants of dense forest, clean or weedy pastures, and rivers in the Sub-Andean rainforest orobiome of the Kankawarwa sector, Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The representative species associated with the covers of this Orobiome include: cedar (Cedrela odorata) and oak (Tabebuia sp.). Common species include: avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), and mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla). Occasionally associated species include: cachimbo (Erythrina sp.), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), red ceiba (Pachira quinata), cuchillito (Senna sp.), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guáimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guamo (Inga sp.), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), palm, and perehuétano (Parinari pachyphylla).﻿

history_site:
Kankawarwa is located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, in the Fundación River basin, within the lower La Cristalina area, between 250 and 500 m.a.s.l. This village was founded in 2009 on a 114-hectare property purchased by the Governor’s Office of Magdalena as part of the establishment of the so-called "pueblos talanquera", within the strategic project known as the “Environmental and Traditional Belt of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.”

It is an area of environmental and cultural importance situated in the lower part of the Sierra Nevada, between La Cristalina stream and the Nabusimake River, where the Arhuaco people have designated one sector for community services and another for traditional living. The region has been affected by historical colonization processes that have led to high levels of landscape fragmentation, mainly linked to cattle farming activities. The relictual state of original forest cover and the loss of native, high-value timber species are some of the visible outcomes of this colonization.

The northern part of the populated center was particularly deforested between 2013 and 2017, according to data from the Global Forest Change observatory and geoportal.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: Gallery forest and/or fragmented forest cover predominates in the Kankawarwa locality, in the Fundación river basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in a medium altitudinal range between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In this cover, plant enrichment stands out with timber species of importance, especially with constructive use value, including notable species such as: caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), cuchillito (Senna sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guacimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), oak (Tabebuia sp.), tambor (Schizolobium parahyba) and totumo (Crescentia cujete). Similarly associated with these covers, the planting of other species of community importance such as avocado (Persea americana) and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum) has been promoted, which favor the expectations of the Arhuaco population's own economy and food security. In these covers, the planting of an unspecified palm and another species locally known as cachimbo (Erythrina sp) has also been promoted.Corresponds to areas with a predominance of secondary vegetation cover or in transition, in the locality of Kankawarwa, in the basin of the Fundación River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In this coverage, the vegetation is enriched with important timber species, including: carob (Hymenaea courbaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), carob (Aspidosperma polyneuron), cedar (Cedrela odorata), kapok (Ceiba pentandra), red kapok (Pachira quinata), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guacimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and oak (Tabebuia sp.). In the same way, the planting of important food crops such as avocado (Persea americana) and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum) has been promoted, which favors the Arhuaca population's expectations for their own economy and food security. The planting of an unspecified palm has been promoted in these areas.

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This corresponds to areas dominated by mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces in the locality of Kankawarwa﻿, in the cuenca del río Fundación﻿, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿, within a mid-altitudinal band between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In this land cover, vegetation enrichment is notable with timber species of constructive value, among which the following stand out: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril)﻿, campano (Samanea saman)﻿, caoba (Swietenia macrophylla)﻿, carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron)﻿, cedro (Cedrela odorata)﻿, ceiba (Ceiba pentandra)﻿, ceiba roja (Pachira quinata)﻿, cuchillito (Senna sp.)﻿, dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria)﻿, dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria)﻿, guácimo (Guazuma ulmofolia)﻿, guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus)﻿, gusanero (Astronium graveolens)﻿, orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum)﻿, roble (Tabebuia sp.)﻿, and tabaco (Pseudosamanea sp.)﻿. Similarly, the planting of other species of agro-food importance has been promoted, such as aguacate (Persea americana)﻿, pera (Zyzygium malaccense)﻿, zapote (Pouteria zapota)﻿, and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum)﻿, which support the economic expectations and food security of the población arhuaca﻿. In these land covers, the planting of an unspecified palm and another species locally known as cachimbo (Erythrina sp.)﻿ has also been promoted.

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This refers to areas predominantly covered by clean or weedy pastures in the locality of Kankawarwa, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in a mid-altitudinal strip ranging between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In this land cover, the enrichment with timber species is notable, especially those valued for construction uses, among which the following stand out: mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), and oak (Tabebuia sp.). To a lesser extent, but equally important, the planting of abarco (Cariniana sp.), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), and orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) has been promoted. Likewise, associated with these land covers, the planting of other species of community importance has been encouraged, such as avocado (Persea americana), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), caimito (Pouteria caimito), and pear (Syzygium malaccense), which supports the Arhuaco population's expectations for self-sustained economy and food security. In these land covers, the planting of a species locally known as cachimbo (Erythrina sp.) has also been promoted.Gallery forest and/or fragmented forest cover predominates in the Kankawarwa locality, in the Fundación river basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in a medium altitudinal range between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In this cover, plant enrichment stands out with timber species of importance, especially with constructive use value, including notable species such as: caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), cuchillito (Senna sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guacimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), oak (Tabebuia sp.), tambor (Schizolobium parahyba) and totumo (Crescentia cujete). Similarly associated with these covers, the planting of other species of community importance such as avocado (Persea americana) and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum) has been promoted, which favor the expectations of the Arhuaco population's own economy and food security. In these covers, the planting of an unspecified palm and another species locally known as cachimbo (Erythrina sp) has also been promoted.

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It mainly corresponds to a cover mosaic of pastures, crops, and natural spaces and/or secondary or transitional vegetation, eventually associated with remnants of dense forest, clean or weedy pastures, and rivers in the Sub-Andean rainforest orobiome of the Kankawarwa sector, Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The representative species associated with the covers of this Orobiome include: cedar (Cedrela odorata) and oak (Tabebuia sp.). Common species include: avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), and mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla). Occasionally associated species include: cachimbo (Erythrina sp.), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), red ceiba (Pachira quinata), cuchillito (Senna sp.), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guáimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guamo (Inga sp.), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), palm, and perehuétano (Parinari pachyphylla).﻿
