description_site: Gallery forest and/or fragmented forest cover predominates in the Kankawarwa locality, in the Fundación river basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in a medium altitudinal range between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In this cover, plant enrichment stands out with timber species of importance, especially with constructive use value, including notable species such as: caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), cuchillito (Senna sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guacimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), oak (Tabebuia sp.), tambor (Schizolobium parahyba) and totumo (Crescentia cujete). Similarly associated with these covers, the planting of other species of community importance such as avocado (Persea americana) and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum) has been promoted, which favor the expectations of the Arhuaco population's own economy and food security. In these covers, the planting of an unspecified palm and another species locally known as cachimbo (Erythrina sp) has also been promoted.Corresponds to areas with a predominance of secondary vegetation cover or in transition, in the locality of Kankawarwa, in the basin of the Fundación River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In this coverage, the vegetation is enriched with important timber species, including: carob (Hymenaea courbaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), carob (Aspidosperma polyneuron), cedar (Cedrela odorata), kapok (Ceiba pentandra), red kapok (Pachira quinata), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guacimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and oak (Tabebuia sp.). In the same way, the planting of important food crops such as avocado (Persea americana) and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum) has been promoted, which favors the Arhuaca population's expectations for their own economy and food security. The planting of an unspecified palm has been promoted in these areas.
history_site:
Kankawarwa is located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, in the Fundación River basin, within the lower La Cristalina area, between 250 and 500 m.a.s.l. This village was founded in 2009 on a 114-hectare property purchased by the Governor’s Office of Magdalena as part of the establishment of the so-called "pueblos talanquera", within the strategic project known as the “Environmental and Traditional Belt of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.”

It is an area of environmental and cultural importance situated in the lower part of the Sierra Nevada, between La Cristalina stream and the Nabusimake River, where the Arhuaco people have designated one sector for community services and another for traditional living. The region has been affected by historical colonization processes that have led to high levels of landscape fragmentation, mainly linked to cattle farming activities. The relictual state of original forest cover and the loss of native, high-value timber species are some of the visible outcomes of this colonization.

The northern part of the populated center was particularly deforested between 2013 and 2017, according to data from the Global Forest Change observatory and geoportal.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This corresponds to areas dominated by mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces in the locality of Kankawarwa﻿, in the cuenca del río Fundación﻿, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿, within a mid-altitudinal band between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In this land cover, vegetation enrichment is notable with timber species of constructive value, among which the following stand out: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril)﻿, campano (Samanea saman)﻿, caoba (Swietenia macrophylla)﻿, carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron)﻿, cedro (Cedrela odorata)﻿, ceiba (Ceiba pentandra)﻿, ceiba roja (Pachira quinata)﻿, cuchillito (Senna sp.)﻿, dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria)﻿, dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria)﻿, guácimo (Guazuma ulmofolia)﻿, guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus)﻿, gusanero (Astronium graveolens)﻿, orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum)﻿, roble (Tabebuia sp.)﻿, and tabaco (Pseudosamanea sp.)﻿. Similarly, the planting of other species of agro-food importance has been promoted, such as aguacate (Persea americana)﻿, pera (Zyzygium malaccense)﻿, zapote (Pouteria zapota)﻿, and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum)﻿, which support the economic expectations and food security of the población arhuaca﻿. In these land covers, the planting of an unspecified palm and another species locally known as cachimbo (Erythrina sp.)﻿ has also been promoted.Gallery forest and/or fragmented forest cover predominates in the Kankawarwa locality, in the Fundación river basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in a medium altitudinal range between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In this cover, plant enrichment stands out with timber species of importance, especially with constructive use value, including notable species such as: caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), cuchillito (Senna sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guacimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), oak (Tabebuia sp.), tambor (Schizolobium parahyba) and totumo (Crescentia cujete). Similarly associated with these covers, the planting of other species of community importance such as avocado (Persea americana) and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum) has been promoted, which favor the expectations of the Arhuaco population's own economy and food security. In these covers, the planting of an unspecified palm and another species locally known as cachimbo (Erythrina sp) has also been promoted.

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: Corresponds to areas with a predominance of secondary vegetation cover or in transition, in the town of Kantinurwa, in the basin of the Fundación River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this coverage, the vegetation is enriched with important timber species, including: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril),  caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), cedro (Cedrela odorata), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), ceiba roja (Pachira quinata), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guacimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and oak (Tabebuia sp.). In the same way, the planting of important food crops such as avocado (Persea americana) and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum) has been promoted, which favors the Arhuaca population's expectations for their own economy and food security. The planting of an unspecified palm has been promoted in these areas.
history_site:
Kantinurwa is a populated Arhuaco settlement located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, at the confluence of the Ariguaní River and the Los Curos stream, between 350 and 750 m.a.s.l. This settlement was founded as a pueblo talanquera in 2009, within the framework of the strategic project known as the “Environmental and Traditional Belt of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.”

The areas most affected by environmental degradation due to vegetation loss are found to the north and west of the populated center, while forested zones with low to minimal intervention are located toward the south and east of the territory. On the right bank—downstream—of the Ariguaní River, north of the settlement, there are degraded and/or clean lands with a history of significant overgrazing pressure.

Meanwhile, agricultural production areas (crops) are located in valley or floodplain zones near the Ariguaní River, within the community’s area of influence. Some areas affected by slash-and-burn practices, located farther from the main settlement, impact areas ranging from 3 to 5 hectares.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: Corresponds to secondary vegetation, in transition or with the presence of pasture mosaic with natural spaces associated with the Sub-Andean Orobioma, in the locality of Kantinurwa, Fundación river basin. Eventually they are associated with clean or weeded pasture cover. Among the representative species of this biome for all covers are: algarrobo (Swietenia macrophylla), caracoli (Anacardium excelsum), cedro (Cedrela odorata), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), palm, moringa (Moringa oleifera),roble (Tabebuia sp. ), tobacco (Pseudosamanea sp.), tambor (Schyzolobium parahyba) and trébol (Platymyscium pinnatum). In smaller porportion the following species can be found in association: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), camajón (Sterculia apetala), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), cuchillito (Senna sp.), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), laurel (Nectandra sp. ), achotillo (Vismia sp.), avocado (Persea americana), cananeo (Peltogyne purpurea), cañaguate (Handroanthus chrysantha), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), jobo (Spondias mombim) and socano.

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site:
It corresponds to cover with predominance of secondary or transitional vegetation and/or shrublands near rivers in the Zonobioma Tropical Alternohígrico﻿, in the locality of Kantinurwa﻿, within the cuenca del río Fundación﻿.

In these covers, the presence of species such as cañaguate﻿ (Handroanthus chrysanthus), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), oak (Tabebuia sp.), tabaco (Pseudosamanea sp.), and palm (Palma sp.) is common.

In shrublands, associated timber species such as cananeo (Peltogyne purpurea), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), and dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria) can be found.

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to areas with a predominance of crop and/or pasture mosaics and/or natural spaces, in the town of Kantinurwa, in the basin of the Fundación River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this coverage, the vegetation is enriched with important timber species, including: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cañaguate (Handroanthus chrysanthus), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedro (Cedrela odorata), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), wormwood (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), roble (Tabebuia sp.), socano, tobacco (Pseudosamanea sp.) and tambor (Schyzolobium parahyba).  In some of these coverages, the planting of an unspecified palm has been promoted. In one of the polygons, priority was given to planting the carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), a species categorized as endangered at the regional level. It corresponds to the vegetation cover associated with the river in the locality of Kantinurwa, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this cover, vegetation enrichment stands out with the following species: mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), palm, oak (Tabebuia sp.), socano, and tobacco (Pseudosamanea sp.). In smaller proportions but equally important are the following species: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), cananeo (Peltogyne purpurea), cañaguate (Handroanthus chrysanthus), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cuchillito (Senna sp.), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), moringa (Moringa oleifera), and orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum). The most promoted species in this polygon is cedar (Cedrela odorata).

description_site: It corresponds to areas with a predominance of crop and/or pasture mosaics and/or natural spaces, in the town of Kantinurwa, in the basin of the Fundación River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this coverage, the vegetation is enriched with important timber species, including: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cañaguate (Handroanthus chrysanthus), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedro (Cedrela odorata), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), wormwood (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), roble (Tabebuia sp.), socano, tobacco (Pseudosamanea sp.) and tambor (Schyzolobium parahyba).  In some of these coverages, the planting of an unspecified palm has been promoted. In one of the polygons, priority was given to planting the carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), a species categorized as endangered at the regional level.
history_site:
Kantinurwa is a populated Arhuaco settlement located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, at the confluence of the Ariguaní River and the Los Curos stream, between 350 and 750 m.a.s.l. This settlement was founded as a pueblo talanquera in 2009, within the framework of the strategic project known as the “Environmental and Traditional Belt of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.”

The areas most affected by environmental degradation due to vegetation loss are found to the north and west of the populated center, while forested zones with low to minimal intervention are located toward the south and east of the territory. On the right bank—downstream—of the Ariguaní River, north of the settlement, there are degraded and/or clean lands with a history of significant overgrazing pressure.

Meanwhile, agricultural production areas (crops) are located in valley or floodplain zones near the Ariguaní River, within the community’s area of influence. Some areas affected by slash-and-burn practices, located farther from the main settlement, impact areas ranging from 3 to 5 hectares.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to areas with a predominance of crop and/or pasture mosaics and/or natural spaces, in the town of Kantinurwa, in the basin of the Fundación River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this coverage, the vegetation is enriched with important timber species, including: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cañaguate (Handroanthus chrysanthus), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedro (Cedrela odorata), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), wormwood (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), roble (Tabebuia sp.), socano, tobacco (Pseudosamanea sp.) and tambor (Schyzolobium parahyba).  In some of these coverages, the planting of an unspecified palm has been promoted. In one of the polygons, priority was given to planting the carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), a species categorized as endangered at the regional level. Corresponds to areas with a predominance of secondary vegetation cover or in transition, in the town of Kantinurwa, in the basin of the Fundación River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this coverage, the vegetation is enriched with important timber species, including: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril),  caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), cedro (Cedrela odorata), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), ceiba roja (Pachira quinata), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guacimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and oak (Tabebuia sp.). In the same way, the planting of important food crops such as avocado (Persea americana) and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum) has been promoted, which favors the Arhuaca population's expectations for their own economy and food security. The planting of an unspecified palm has been promoted in these areas.

planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: Corresponds to secondary vegetation, in transition or with the presence of pasture mosaic with natural spaces associated with the Sub-Andean Orobioma, in the locality of Kantinurwa, Fundación river basin. Eventually they are associated with clean or weeded pasture cover. Among the representative species of this biome for all covers are: algarrobo (Swietenia macrophylla), caracoli (Anacardium excelsum), cedro (Cedrela odorata), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), palm, moringa (Moringa oleifera),roble (Tabebuia sp. ), tobacco (Pseudosamanea sp.), tambor (Schyzolobium parahyba) and trébol (Platymyscium pinnatum). In smaller porportion the following species can be found in association: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), camajón (Sterculia apetala), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), cuchillito (Senna sp.), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), laurel (Nectandra sp. ), achotillo (Vismia sp.), avocado (Persea americana), cananeo (Peltogyne purpurea), cañaguate (Handroanthus chrysantha), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), jobo (Spondias mombim) and socano.

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site:
It corresponds to cover with predominance of secondary or transitional vegetation and/or shrublands near rivers in the Zonobioma Tropical Alternohígrico﻿, in the locality of Kantinurwa﻿, within the cuenca del río Fundación﻿.

In these covers, the presence of species such as cañaguate﻿ (Handroanthus chrysanthus), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), oak (Tabebuia sp.), tabaco (Pseudosamanea sp.), and palm (Palma sp.) is common.

In shrublands, associated timber species such as cananeo (Peltogyne purpurea), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), and dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria) can be found.It corresponds to cover with predominance of secondary or transitional vegetation and/or shrublands near rivers in the Zonobioma Tropical Alternohígrico﻿, in the locality of Kantinurwa﻿, within the cuenca del río Fundación﻿.

In these covers, the presence of species such as cañaguate﻿ (Handroanthus chrysanthus), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), oak (Tabebuia sp.), tabaco (Pseudosamanea sp.), and palm (Palma sp.) is common.

In shrublands, associated timber species such as cananeo (Peltogyne purpurea), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), and dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria) can be found.

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to a mosaic of pastures and/or crops and/or natural spaces located in a coastal plain in the process of natural and assisted restoration, near the mouth of the Don Diego River, in the town of Kutunsama, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. Enrichment with native species such as caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cascarillo (Protium sp. ), roble (Tabebuia sp), palma amarga (Sabal mauritiformis), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guayabo león (Terminalia amazonica), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and, to a lesser extent, campano (Samanea saman). Vegetation cover located in a coastal plain in the process of natural and assisted restoration in soils historically affected by intensive cattle ranching, near the mouth of the Don Diego River, in the town of Katunsuma, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. A large proportion of native species of high timber value such as caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), roble (Tabebuia sp) and algarrobo (Swietenia macrophylla) have been planted. To a lesser extent, species such as palma amarga (Sabal mauritiformis), guamo de piedra (Zygia longifolia) and guayabo león (Terminalia amazonica) have been planted. These species are associated with guarumos (Cecropia sp.), balsos (Ochroma pyramidale), venturosas (Lantana camara) and cordoncillos (Piper sp.).
history_site:
Katunsuma is an Arhuaco community settlement located on the coastal plain, at the foothills of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, between the mouths of the Don Diego River and the Perico Aguao stream. Its physical construction began less than ten years ago as part of the process of territorial recovery and consolidation in the area known as the “exit to the sea” of the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve.

This area has been historically affected by intensive cattle farming, characterized by a matrix of Guinea or Mombaza grass (Panicum maximum) and other weedy grasses in wooded pastures that once supported more than a hundred head of cattle. This livestock activity was discontinued following an asset expropiation process carried out by the now-dissolved National Directorate of Narcotics—currently the Special Assets Society—and the area was subsequently allocated for the development of ecological restoration processes coordinated between the competent environmental authority and the Indigenous community.

Although the area was subjected to intensive grazing pressure, the resilience of the natural environment - particularly from the soils - has favored both natural regeneration and assisted recovery in this territory, which is framed by the presence of important sacred sites belonging to the Línea Negra﻿.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: Vegetation cover located in a coastal plain in the process of natural and assisted restoration in soils historically affected by intensive cattle ranching, near the mouth of the Don Diego River, in the town of Katunsuma, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. Enrichment with native species of high timber value such algarrobo (Aspidosperma spruceanum), roble (Tabebuia sp), palma amarga (Sabal mauritiformis) and dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), promoted in the planting process. These species are mainly associated with the secondary or transitional vegetation cover, which is dominated by guarumos (Cecropia sp.), balsos (Ochroma pyramidale), algarrobo (Hymanea corubaril), guayabo león (Terminalia amazonica), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia) and varasanta (Triplaris americana), among others. Other crop covers associated with this halobiome currently include species such as: moringa (Moringa oleifera), pear (Syzigium sp.), guanabana (Annona sp.) and mamey (Mammea americana).

Other crop covers associated with this halobiome currently include species such as: moringa (Moringa oleifera), pear (Syzigium sp.), guanabana (Annona sp.) and mamey (Mammea americana).
history_site:
Katunsuma is an Arhuaco community settlement located on the coastal plain, at the foothills of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, between the mouths of the Don Diego River and the Perico Aguao stream. Its physical construction began less than ten years ago as part of the process of territorial recovery and consolidation in the area known as the “exit to the sea” of the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve.

This area has been historically affected by intensive cattle farming, characterized by a matrix of Guinea or Mombaza grass (Panicum maximum) and other weedy grasses in wooded pastures that once supported more than a hundred head of cattle. This livestock activity was discontinued following an asset expropiation process carried out by the now-dissolved National Directorate of Narcotics—currently the Special Assets Society—and the area was subsequently allocated for the development of ecological restoration processes coordinated between the competent environmental authority and the Indigenous community.

Although the area was subjected to intensive grazing pressure, the resilience of the natural environment - particularly from the soils - has favored both natural regeneration and assisted recovery in this territory, which is framed by the presence of important sacred sites belonging to the Línea Negra﻿.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to a mosaic of pastures and/or crops and/or natural spaces located in a coastal plain in the process of natural and assisted restoration, near the mouth of the Don Diego River, in the town of Kutunsama, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. Enrichment with native species such as caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cascarillo (Protium sp. ), roble (Tabebuia sp), palma amarga (Sabal mauritiformis), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guayabo león (Terminalia amazonica), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and, to a lesser extent, campano (Samanea saman). Fragmented forest cover located on an alluvial plain between 10 and 40 meters above sea level, where natural and assisted restoration processes are evident, on soils historically affected by intensive livestock farming, near the mouth of the Don Diego river, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. Enrichment stands out with native species of high timber value, such as: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cascarillo (Protium sp.), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), palma amarga (Sabal mauritiformis) and Roble (Tabebuia sp.). These last two species are among the most promoted in planting processes. The bitter palm is of great importance in the construction of traditional house roofs, and the oak is recognized for the quality of its wood

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to vegetation covers of the Sub-Andean Orobiome, which include secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural spaces in the locality of Muñimake, within the Fundación River basin, western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in the altitudinal range between 1300 and 1700 meters above sea level. Among the representative species of this biome for all covers are: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), walnut (Cordia sp.), and oak (Tabebuia sp.). Common species include: caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum). Occasional elements recorded are pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.), palm, trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), and yaya (Xylopia sp.).﻿It corresponds to vegetation covers of the Sub-Andean Orobiome, which include secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural spaces in the locality of Muñimake, within the Fundación River basin, western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in the altitudinal range between 1300 and 1700 meters above sea level. Among the representative species of this biome for all covers are: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), walnut (Cordia sp.), and oak (Tabebuia sp.). Common species include: caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum). Occasional elements recorded are pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.), palm, trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), and yaya (Xylopia sp.).﻿
history_site:
Muñimake is an Arhuaco community settlement located on an area that divides the Fundación and Ariguaní river basins, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. This territory extends at an average altitude of 1,500 m.a.s.l.,north of the health center, forest cover is moderately interrupted by mosaics of crops, pastures, and natural areas. In contrast, the southern side features a fragmented landscape where patches of pastures and natural spaces alternate with forest clearings dominated by ferns and weedy grasses.

According to the Global Forest Change observatory, the trend of significant forest loss around the populated center has persisted over the past decade. Coffee plantations ranging from 2 to 4 hectares, visible in satellite imagery, are mainly located to the west of the territory, most of them developed without shade. Burned and eroded areas are commonly observed throughout the sub-Andean landscape.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

history_site:
Muñimake is an Arhuaco community settlement located on an area that divides the Fundación and Ariguaní river basins, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. This territory extends at an average altitude of 1,500 m.a.s.l.,north of the health center, forest cover is moderately interrupted by mosaics of crops, pastures, and natural areas. In contrast, the southern side features a fragmented landscape where patches of pastures and natural spaces alternate with forest clearings dominated by ferns and weedy grasses.

According to the Global Forest Change observatory, the trend of significant forest loss around the populated center has persisted over the past decade. Coffee plantations ranging from 2 to 4 hectares, visible in satellite imagery, are mainly located to the west of the territory, most of them developed without shade. Burned and eroded areas are commonly observed throughout the sub-Andean landscape.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This mainly corresponds to a mosaic of pastures and/or crops and/or natural spaces located in the humid tropical zonobiome, in the locality of Seykwanamake, within the mid-altitudinal band between 100 and 200 meters above sea level, in the Palomino River basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this land cover, frequent and high-density enrichment with the following species stands out: avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and oak (Tabebuia sp.). To a lesser extent, but of equal importance, the planting of the following species has been promoted: breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), red ceiba (Pachira quinata), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), mango (Mangifera indica), mastre (Pterygota colombiana), pear (Zyzygium malaccense), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), and varasanta (Triplaris americana), among othersIt corresponds mainly to secondary vegetation cover or in transition, in the humid tropical zone, in the locality of Seykwanamake, in the average altitudinal range between 100 and 250 meters above sea level, in the Palomino river basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, there is an enrichment of vegetation with species of great timber value and constructive use, mainly roble (Tabebuia sp.) and caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum). The following species are planted to a lesser extent: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), aceituno (Vitex cymosa), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla),caracoli (Anacardium excelsum), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guamo (Inga sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). The plantation of other species of importance for the food security of the Arhuaca families has also been promoted, including avocado (Persea americana) and moringa (Moringa oleifera).
history_site:
Located between 200 and 400 m.a.s.l, across the valley and hill landscapes of the Palomino River in the area known as the “exit to the sea” of the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, lies the community of Seykwanamake. This Arhuaco settlement occupies areas historically affected by illicit crop cultivation and extensive cattle farming dating back to the marijuana bonanza period of the late 1990s and early 2000s. These activities resulted in high levels of landscape fragmentation and the loss of native flora and fauna species.

The area was prioritized under Plan Colombia in the early 2000s, which enabled the resettlement of the Arhuaco population. However, progress remains pending in the land regularization processes needed to restore territorial integrity and self-governance for the Indigenous peoples of the Sierra. This zone shows higher levels of degradation in the hilly areas due to soil depletion caused by recurrent burning to renew pastures.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

In this land cover, frequent and high-density enrichment with the following species stands out: avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and oak (Tabebuia sp.). To a lesser extent, but of equal importance, the planting of the following species has been promoted: breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), red ceiba (Pachira quinata), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), mango (Mangifera indica), mastre (Pterygota colombiana), pear (Zyzygium malaccense), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), and varasanta (Triplaris americana), among othersIt corresponds mainly to secondary vegetation cover or in transition, in the humid tropical zone, in the locality of Seykwanamake, in the average altitudinal range between 100 and 250 meters above sea level, in the Palomino river basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, there is an enrichment of vegetation with species of great timber value and constructive use, mainly roble (Tabebuia sp.) and caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum). The following species are planted to a lesser extent: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), aceituno (Vitex cymosa), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla),caracoli (Anacardium excelsum), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guamo (Inga sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). The plantation of other species of importance for the food security of the Arhuaca families has also been promoted, including avocado (Persea americana) and moringa (Moringa oleifera).
history_site:
Located between 200 and 400 m.a.s.l, across the valley and hill landscapes of the Palomino River in the area known as the “exit to the sea” of the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, lies the community of Seykwanamake. This Arhuaco settlement occupies areas historically affected by illicit crop cultivation and extensive cattle farming dating back to the marijuana bonanza period of the late 1990s and early 2000s. These activities resulted in high levels of landscape fragmentation and the loss of native flora and fauna species.

The area was prioritized under Plan Colombia in the early 2000s, which enabled the resettlement of the Arhuaco population. However, progress remains pending in the land regularization processes needed to restore territorial integrity and self-governance for the Indigenous peoples of the Sierra. This zone shows higher levels of degradation in the hilly areas due to soil depletion caused by recurrent burning to renew pastures.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This mainly corresponds to areas covered by clean or weedy pastures, in zones historically affected by extensive cattle ranching, within the humid tropical zonobiome, in the locality of Seykwanamake, within the mid-altitudinal range between 100 and 200 meters above sea level, in the Palomino River basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this land cover, the enrichment with plant species of high timber value and constructive use stands out, including: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), oak (Tabebuia sp.), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp.), and tambor (Schyzolobium parahyba). To a lesser extent, but equally important, the planting of species such as aceituno (Vitex cymosa), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), laurel (Nectandra sp.), mastre (Pterygota colombiana), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia) has been promoted. Similarly, the planting of other species important for food security among Arhuaco families has been promoted, especially avocado (Persea americana) and pear (Syzygium malaccense).It corresponds mainly to secondary vegetation cover or in transition, in the humid tropical zone, in the locality of Seykwanamake, in the average altitudinal range between 100 and 250 meters above sea level, in the Palomino river basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, there is an enrichment of vegetation with species of great timber value and constructive use, mainly roble (Tabebuia sp.) and caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum). The following species are planted to a lesser extent: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), aceituno (Vitex cymosa), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla),caracoli (Anacardium excelsum), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guamo (Inga sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). The plantation of other species of importance for the food security of the Arhuaca families has also been promoted, including avocado (Persea americana) and moringa (Moringa oleifera).

description_site:

In this land cover, frequent and high-density enrichment with the following species stands out: avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and oak (Tabebuia sp.). To a lesser extent, but of equal importance, the planting of the following species has been promoted: breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), red ceiba (Pachira quinata), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), mango (Mangifera indica), mastre (Pterygota colombiana), pear (Zyzygium malaccense), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), and varasanta (Triplaris americana), among othersCorresponds mainly to areas of fragmented forest or relicts of high dense forest in the humid tropical zone, in the locality of Seykwanamake, in the average altitudinal range between 100 and 200 meters above sea level, Palomino river basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, there is an enrichment of vegetation with species of great timber value and constructive use, including species in the threatened category at the regional and local levels, such as: algarrono (Hymenaea corubaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), oak (Tabebuia sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), mastre (Pterygota colombiana) and tambor (Schyzolobium parahyba). The planting of other species of importance for the food security of the Arhuaca families has also been promoted, including: avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis*), guamo (Inga sp.), and mamey (Mammea americana). 

It corresponds to vegetation cover associated with aquatic ecosystems featuring a permanent water body, either static or flowing, in the locality of Kankawarwa, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.

In this hydrobiome, vegetation enrichment is primarily represented by the following species: oak (Tabebuia sp.), avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), guamo (Inga sp.), and orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum).

To a lesser extent, within this hydrobiome, the planting of caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum) and tambor (Schyzolobium parahyba) has been promoted.It corresponds mainly to secondary vegetation cover or in transition, in the humid tropical zone, in the locality of Seykwanamake, in the average altitudinal range between 100 and 250 meters above sea level, in the Palomino river basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, there is an enrichment of vegetation with species of great timber value and constructive use, mainly roble (Tabebuia sp.) and caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum). The following species are planted to a lesser extent: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), aceituno (Vitex cymosa), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla),caracoli (Anacardium excelsum), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guamo (Inga sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). The plantation of other species of importance for the food security of the Arhuaca families has also been promoted, including avocado (Persea americana) and moringa (Moringa oleifera).Corresponde a vegetal cover associated with the river in the locality of Seykwanamake, Don Diego river basin, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. This cover is notable for the enrichment with the following species: oak (Tabebuia rosea), avocado (Persea americana), tambor (Schizolobium parahyba), guamo (Inga sp.) and orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum). Less frequently, individuals of the species algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophyla), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), and pera (Zyzygium malaccense) are reported.It corresponds to vegetation cover associated with aquatic ecosystems featuring a permanent water body, either static or flowing, in the locality of Kankawarwa, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.

In this hydrobiome, vegetation enrichment is primarily represented by the following species: oak (Tabebuia sp.), avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), guamo (Inga sp.), and orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum).

To a lesser extent, within this hydrobiome, the planting of caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum) and tambor (Schyzolobium parahyba) has been promoted.
history_site:
Located between 200 and 400 m.a.s.l, across the valley and hill landscapes of the Palomino River in the area known as the “exit to the sea” of the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, lies the community of Seykwanamake. This Arhuaco settlement occupies areas historically affected by illicit crop cultivation and extensive cattle farming dating back to the marijuana bonanza period of the late 1990s and early 2000s. These activities resulted in high levels of landscape fragmentation and the loss of native flora and fauna species.

The area was prioritized under Plan Colombia in the early 2000s, which enabled the resettlement of the Arhuaco population. However, progress remains pending in the land regularization processes needed to restore territorial integrity and self-governance for the Indigenous peoples of the Sierra. This zone shows higher levels of degradation in the hilly areas due to soil depletion caused by recurrent burning to renew pastures.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This mainly corresponds to areas covered by clean or weedy pastures, in zones historically affected by extensive cattle ranching, within the humid tropical zonobiome, in the locality of Seykwanamake, within the mid-altitudinal range between 100 and 200 meters above sea level, in the Palomino River basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this land cover, the enrichment with plant species of high timber value and constructive use stands out, including: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), oak (Tabebuia sp.), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp.), and tambor (Schyzolobium parahyba). To a lesser extent, but equally important, the planting of species such as aceituno (Vitex cymosa), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), laurel (Nectandra sp.), mastre (Pterygota colombiana), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia) has been promoted. Similarly, the planting of other species important for food security among Arhuaco families has been promoted, especially avocado (Persea americana) and pear (Syzygium malaccense).This mainly corresponds to a mosaic of pastures and/or crops and/or natural spaces located in the humid tropical zonobiome, in the locality of Seykwanamake, within the mid-altitudinal band between 100 and 200 meters above sea level, in the Palomino River basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this land cover, frequent and high-density enrichment with the following species stands out: avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and oak (Tabebuia sp.). To a lesser extent, but of equal importance, the planting of the following species has been promoted: breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), red ceiba (Pachira quinata), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), mango (Mangifera indica), mastre (Pterygota colombiana), pear (Zyzygium malaccense), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), and varasanta (Triplaris americana), among others

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: Corresponds mainly to areas of fragmented forest or relicts of high dense forest in the humid tropical zone, in the locality of Seykwanamake, in the average altitudinal range between 100 and 200 meters above sea level, Palomino river basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, there is an enrichment of vegetation with species of great timber value and constructive use, including species in the threatened category at the regional and local levels, such as: algarrono (Hymenaea corubaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), oak (Tabebuia sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), mastre (Pterygota colombiana) and tambor (Schyzolobium parahyba). The planting of other species of importance for the food security of the Arhuaca families has also been promoted, including: avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis*), guamo (Inga sp.), and mamey (Mammea americana).

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This mainly corresponds to a mosaic of pastures and/or crops and/or natural spaces located within a humid tropical zonobiome, in the locality of Seykwanamake, within the mid-altitudinal band between 650 and 900 meters above sea level, in the Fundación River basin, Arhuaco Reserve of the Sierra, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this land cover, vegetation enrichment is mainly notable for the following species: oak (Tabebuia sp.), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), small-leaf guava (Calophyllum sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), and an unspecified palm. To a lesser extent, though equally important, the following species are also present: avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), camajón (Sterculia apetala), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guayacán (Tabebuia chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), and trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia), among others.This mainly corresponds to a mosaic of pastures and/or crops and/or natural spaces located within a humid tropical zonobiome, in the locality of Seykwanamake, within the mid-altitudinal band between 650 and 900 meters above sea level, in the Fundación River basin, Arhuaco Reserve of the Sierra, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this land cover, vegetation enrichment is mainly notable for the following species: oak (Tabebuia sp.), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), small-leaf guava (Calophyllum sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), and an unspecified palm. history_site:
Singuney is an Arhuaco community located in the Chinchicua micro-basin, within the Ariguaní River basin, between 650 and 1,100 m.a.s.l, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The area shows a clear historical record of localized burning in its northern part and a deforestation pattern concentrated in the southern and western sections of the community. The best-preserved vegetation covers are found to the east of the populated center; however, the landscape—dominated by tall secondary vegetation—is not homogeneous, being interrupted by patches of overgrown pastures and fern thickets that indicate poor and depleted soils.

Overall, landscape fragmentation is closely associated with burning pressure from livestock activities and the expansion of the agricultural frontier. It is necessary to design and implement landscape management tools to reverse the degradation of the forested landscape in the micro-basin, particularly along the right bank, downstream of the Chinchicua stream.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to vegetation covers of the Sub-Andean Orobiome, which include secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural spaces in the locality of Singuney, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The following species are representative in terms of abundance and frequency: oak (Tabebuia sp.), trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Common species with more than 50% frequency in the vegetation covers of this Sub-Andean biome include: mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), achote (Vismia sp.), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guayabito (Calophylon sp.). Less frequently found species include: avocado (Persea americana), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), palm, corazón fino (Platymyscium pinnatum), cuchillito (Senna sp.), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guava (Psidium guajaba), moringa (Moringa oleifera), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), walnut (Cordia sp.), pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.) and Sula (Trema sp.). In some specific polygons, exclusive populations can be found of abarco (Cariniana pyriformis), achote (Vismia sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), lechoso (Brosimum sp.), granadilla (Caesalpinia sp.), and ceiba (Ceiba pentandra).﻿It corresponds to vegetation covers of the Sub-Andean Orobiome, which include secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural spaces in the locality of Singuney, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. Less frequently found species include: avocado (Persea americana), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), palm, corazón fino (Platymyscium pinnatum), cuchillito (Senna sp.), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guava (Psidium guajaba), moringa (Moringa oleifera), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), walnut (Cordia sp.), pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.) and Sula (Trema sp.). In some specific polygons, exclusive populations can be found of abarco (Cariniana pyriformis), achote (Vismia sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), lechoso (Brosimum sp.), granadilla (Caesalpinia sp.), and ceiba (Ceiba pentandra).﻿

description_site: It corresponds to vegetation covers of the Sub-Andean Orobiome, which include secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural spaces in the locality of Singuney, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. Less frequently found species include: avocado (Persea americana), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), palm, corazón fino (Platymyscium pinnatum), cuchillito (Senna sp.), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guava (Psidium guajaba), moringa (Moringa oleifera), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), walnut (Cordia sp.), pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.) and Sula (Trema sp.). In some specific polygons, exclusive populations can be found of abarco (Cariniana pyriformis), achote (Vismia sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), lechoso (Brosimum sp.), granadilla (Caesalpinia sp.), and ceiba (Ceiba pentandra).﻿This mainly corresponds to a mosaic of pastures and/or crops and/or natural spaces located within a humid tropical zonobiome, in the locality of Seykwanamake, within the mid-altitudinal band between 650 and 900 meters above sea level, in the Fundación River basin, Arhuaco Reserve of the Sierra, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this land cover, vegetation enrichment is mainly notable for the following species: oak (Tabebuia sp.), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), small-leaf guava (Calophyllum sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), and an unspecified palm. To a lesser extent, though equally important, the following species are also present: avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), camajón (Sterculia apetala), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guayacán (Tabebuia chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), and trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia), among others.

Less frequently found species include: avocado (Persea americana), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), palm, corazón fino (Platymyscium pinnatum), cuchillito (Senna sp.), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guava (Psidium guajaba), moringa (Moringa oleifera), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), walnut (Cordia sp.), pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.) and Sula (Trema sp.). In some specific polygons, exclusive populations can be found of abarco (Cariniana pyriformis), achote (Vismia sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), lechoso (Brosimum sp.), granadilla (Caesalpinia sp.), and ceiba (Ceiba pentandra).﻿

Common species with more than 50% frequency in the vegetation covers of this Sub-Andean biome include: mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), achote (Vismia sp.), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guayabito (Calophylon sp.). Less frequently found species include: avocado (Persea americana), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), palm, corazón fino (Platymyscium pinnatum), cuchillito (Senna sp.), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guava (Psidium guajaba), moringa (Moringa oleifera), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), walnut (Cordia sp.), pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.) and Sula (Trema sp.). In some specific polygons, exclusive populations can be found of abarco (Cariniana pyriformis), achote (Vismia sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), lechoso (Brosimum sp.), granadilla (Caesalpinia sp.), and ceiba (Ceiba pentandra).﻿It corresponds to vegetation covers of the Sub-Andean Orobiome, which include secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural spaces in the locality of Singuney, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The following species are representative in terms of abundance and frequency: oak (Tabebuia sp.), trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Common species with more than 50% frequency in the vegetation covers of this Sub-Andean biome include: mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), achote (Vismia sp.), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guayabito (Calophylon sp.). Less frequently found species include: avocado (Persea americana), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), palm, corazón fino (Platymyscium pinnatum), cuchillito (Senna sp.), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guava (Psidium guajaba), moringa (Moringa oleifera), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), walnut (Cordia sp.), pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.) and Sula (Trema sp.). In some specific polygons, exclusive populations can be found of abarco (Cariniana pyriformis), achote (Vismia sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), lechoso (Brosimum sp.), granadilla (Caesalpinia sp.), and ceiba (Ceiba pentandra).﻿
history_site:
Singuney is an Arhuaco community located in the Chinchicua micro-basin, within the Ariguaní River basin, between 650 and 1,100 m.a.s.l, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The area shows a clear historical record of localized burning in its northern part and a deforestation pattern concentrated in the southern and western sections of the community. The best-preserved vegetation covers are found to the east of the populated center; however, the landscape—dominated by tall secondary vegetation—is not homogeneous, being interrupted by patches of overgrown pastures and fern thickets that indicate poor and depleted soils.

Overall, landscape fragmentation is closely associated with burning pressure from livestock activities and the expansion of the agricultural frontier. It is necessary to design and implement landscape management tools to reverse the degradation of the forested landscape in the micro-basin, particularly along the right bank, downstream of the Chinchicua stream.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to the vegetation covers of the Orobioma subandino that include secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, dense forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural spaces in the locality of Umake, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The following species are representative in terms of abundance and frequency for all vegetation covers: mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), and oak (Tabebuia sp.). Less than 70% of appearances are followed by species such as guamo (Inga sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and walnut (Cordia aliodora). The latter species shows a high record of abundance. At 50% or less frequency, species such as avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), granadilla (Caesalpinia sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), lechoso (Brosimum sp.), and tabaco (Caesalpinia sp2) are reported. With a frequency lower than 10%, the following are recorded: carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), árbol del pan (Artocarpus altilis), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), ceiba roja (Pachira quinata), corazón fino (Platymyscium pinnatum), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guamo de piedra (Zygia longifolia), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), palma, and varasanta (Triplaris americana). Finally, some species exclusive to specific covers include: achote (Vismia sp), aguacate macho (Persea caerulea), campano (Samanea saman), pera (Zyzygium malaccense), pionío (Erythrina sp.), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia).﻿
history_site:
Umake is an Arhuaco community located in the micro-basin of the Nabusimake River, within the limits and currents of the Fundación River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, between 850 and 1,400 m.a.s.l. This area shows a recurring pattern of historical deforestation, except in the northeastern and southern sectors of the locality, where dense upland forest and secondary vegetation persist. These areas form part of the transition between the Tropical Humid Zonobiome and the Sub-Andean Forest Orobiome.

Subsistence and semi-permanent crops are established in the vecinity of the populated center. The clean and weedy pasture covers that characterize the fragmented landscape range from 1 to 8 hectares and represent the areas with the greatest need for adopting landscape management tools to mitigate environmental degradation.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

Finally, some species exclusive to specific covers include: achote (Vismia sp), aguacate macho (Persea caerulea), campano (Samanea saman), pera (Zyzygium malaccense), pionío (Erythrina sp.), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia).﻿

planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to the vegetation covers of the Orobioma subandino that include secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, dense forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural spaces in the locality of Umake, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The following species are representative in terms of abundance and frequency for all vegetation covers: mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), and oak (Tabebuia sp.). Less than 70% of appearances are followed by species such as guamo (Inga sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and walnut (Cordia aliodora). The latter species shows a high record of abundance. At 50% or less frequency, species such as avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), granadilla (Caesalpinia sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), lechoso (Brosimum sp.), and tabaco (Caesalpinia sp2) are reported. With a frequency lower than 10%, the following are recorded: carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), árbol del pan (Artocarpus altilis), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), ceiba roja (Pachira quinata), corazón fino (Platymyscium pinnatum), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guamo de piedra (Zygia longifolia), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), palma, and varasanta (Triplaris americana). Finally, some species exclusive to specific covers include: achote (Vismia sp), aguacate macho (Persea caerulea), campano (Samanea saman), pera (Zyzygium malaccense), pionío (Erythrina sp.), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia).﻿

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to the vegetation cover present in the Sub-Andean Orobiome, in the locality of Jeywin, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. Within the same landscape unit, which includes secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, dense forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural areas, as well as clean pastures, representative species in terms of abundance and frequency may appear across all vegetation covers, such as mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), guamo (Inga sp.), and oak (Tabebuia sp.). This select group is followed, with a frequency lower than 70%, by species such as algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), and orejero. Less frequently, timber species such as abarco (Cariniana pyriformis) and laurel (Nectandra sp.) can be observed, and only in certain specific covers may species such as red ceiba (Pachira quinata), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.), pera (Syzygium malaccense), tambor (Schyzolobium parahyba), and varasanta (Triplaris americana) appear.It corresponds to the vegetation cover present in the Sub-Andean Orobiome, in the locality of Jeywin, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. Within the same landscape unit, which includes secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, dense forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural areas, as well as clean pastures, representative species in terms of abundance and frequency may appear across all vegetation covers, such as mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), guamo (Inga sp.), and oak (Tabebuia sp.). This select group is followed, with a frequency lower than 70%, by species such as algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), and orejero. Less frequently, timber species such as abarco (Cariniana pyriformis) and laurel (Nectandra sp.) can be observed, and only in certain specific covers may species such as red ceiba (Pachira quinata), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.), pera (Syzygium malaccense), tambor (Schyzolobium parahyba), and varasanta (Triplaris americana) appear.
history_site:
Jeywin is an Arhuaco community located within the micro-basin of the Las Flores stream, a tributary of the Ariguaní River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, between 1,000 and 1,400 m.a.s.l. The area has been affected by historical pressures of deforestation, burning, and livestock farming. Some open areas and overgrown pastures cover between 5 and 7 hectares, while the crop fields near the houses and the populated center usually do not exceed 1 hectare.

Degraded zones are distributed around the settlement, forming a heterogeneous mosaic of pastures, crops, and natural areas. The gallery forest along the Las Flores stream is particularly impacted by land-use dynamics, showing a loss of natural connectivity. It is necessary to work with the community and traditional authorities to review the ancestral land-use and management model, as well as the state of conservation of biodiversity, ecosystem benefits, and the contributions of the different vegetation covers present in the territory. This process would help reframe the environmental sustainability of the area in the medium and long term, considering current and emerging patterns of land use and management.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This corresponds to mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces in the locality of Bunkwimake, within the mid-altitudinal band between 280 and 340 meters above sea level, in the humid tropical zonobiome, Don Diego River basin, Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this land cover, enrichment with plant species of high timber value and construction utility stands out, such as: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), oak (Tabebuia sp.), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), laurel (Nectandra sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). To a lesser extent, but with good frequency, species such as algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), kamaleandra (Calliandra sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), among others, have been associated. Likewise, other species important for food security have been promoted, such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), pear (Syzygium malaccense), guamo (Inga sp.), and moringa (Moringa oleifera).
history_site:
Bunkwimake is an Arhuaco territory located near the Don Dieguito River, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada, in the area known as the “exit to the sea” of the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve. It is currently one of the main consolidated population centers in the northern sector of the Sierra. The area lies between 200 and 500 m.a.s.l and is part of the Tropical Humid Zonobiome, which was severely impacted in the late 20th and early 21st centuries thorugh illicit crops.

Nevertheless, through the Plan Colombia—which promoted manual eradication and aerial control of such crops, along with land legislation in favor of the Indigenous Reserve—progress has been made to natural recovery and productive reconversion. Cocoa farming and other semi-permanent crops have become key strategies to gradually improve ecological connectivity indicators and strengthen the local economy.

Burning and deforestation are other historical drivers of transformation that continue their influence in the region, particularly on the southern side of the populated center. Likewise, areas impacted by deforestation in recent decades are highly noticeable in all four cardinal directions; however, some key remnants of dense forest and tall secondary vegetation remain, especially toward the northeastern sector of the populated area.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: Fragmented forest cover located on an alluvial plain between 10 and 40 meters above sea level, where natural and assisted restoration processes are evident, on soils historically affected by intensive livestock farming, near the mouth of the Don Diego river, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. Enrichment stands out with native species of high timber value, such as: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cascarillo (Protium sp.), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), palma amarga (Sabal mauritiformis) and Roble (Tabebuia sp.). These last two species are among the most promoted in planting processes. The bitter palm is of great importance in the construction of traditional house roofs, and the oak is recognized for the quality of its wood
history_site:
Katunsuma is an Arhuaco community settlement located on the coastal plain, at the foothills of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, between the mouths of the Don Diego River and the Perico Aguao stream. Its physical construction began less than ten years ago as part of the process of territorial recovery and consolidation in the area known as the “exit to the sea” of the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve.

This area has been historically affected by intensive cattle farming, characterized by a matrix of Guinea or Mombaza grass (Panicum maximum) and other weedy grasses in wooded pastures that once supported more than a hundred head of cattle. This livestock activity was discontinued following an asset expropiation process carried out by the now-dissolved National Directorate of Narcotics—currently the Special Assets Society—and the area was subsequently allocated for the development of ecological restoration processes coordinated between the competent environmental authority and the Indigenous community.

Although the area was subjected to intensive grazing pressure, the resilience of the natural environment - particularly from the soils - has favored both natural regeneration and assisted recovery in this territory, which is framed by the presence of important sacred sites belonging to the Línea Negra﻿.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to vegetation covers of the Sub-Andean Orobiome, which include secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural spaces in the locality of Singuney, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The following species are representative in terms of abundance and frequency: oak (Tabebuia sp.), trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Common species with more than 50% frequency in the vegetation covers of this Sub-Andean biome include: mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), achote (Vismia sp.), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guayabito (Calophylon sp.). Less frequently found species include: avocado (Persea americana), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), palm, corazón fino (Platymyscium pinnatum), cuchillito (Senna sp.), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guava (Psidium guajaba), moringa (Moringa oleifera), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), walnut (Cordia sp.), pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.) and Sula (Trema sp.). In some specific polygons, exclusive populations can be found of abarco (Cariniana pyriformis), achote (Vismia sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), lechoso (Brosimum sp.), granadilla (Caesalpinia sp.), and ceiba (Ceiba pentandra).﻿
history_site:
Singuney is an Arhuaco community located in the Chinchicua micro-basin, within the Ariguaní River basin, between 650 and 1,100 m.a.s.l, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The area shows a clear historical record of localized burning in its northern part and a deforestation pattern concentrated in the southern and western sections of the community. The best-preserved vegetation covers are found to the east of the populated center; however, the landscape—dominated by tall secondary vegetation—is not homogeneous, being interrupted by patches of overgrown pastures and fern thickets that indicate poor and depleted soils.

Overall, landscape fragmentation is closely associated with burning pressure from livestock activities and the expansion of the agricultural frontier. It is necessary to design and implement landscape management tools to reverse the degradation of the forested landscape in the micro-basin, particularly along the right bank, downstream of the Chinchicua stream.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters
