project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This mainly corresponds to a mosaic of pastures and/or crops and/or natural spaces located within a humid tropical zonobiome, in the locality of Seykwanamake, within the mid-altitudinal band between 650 and 900 meters above sea level, in the Fundación River basin, Arhuaco Reserve of the Sierra, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this land cover, vegetation enrichment is mainly notable for the following species: oak (Tabebuia sp.), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), small-leaf guava (Calophyllum sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), and an unspecified palm. To a lesser extent, though equally important, the following species are also present: avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), camajón (Sterculia apetala), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guayacán (Tabebuia chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), and trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia), among others.This mainly corresponds to a mosaic of pastures and/or crops and/or natural spaces located within a humid tropical zonobiome, in the locality of Seykwanamake, within the mid-altitudinal band between 650 and 900 meters above sea level, in the Fundación River basin, Arhuaco Reserve of the Sierra, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this land cover, vegetation enrichment is mainly notable for the following species: oak (Tabebuia sp.), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), small-leaf guava (Calophyllum sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), and an unspecified palm. To a lesser extent, though equally important, the following species are also present: avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), camajón (Sterculia apetala), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guayacán (Tabebuia chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), and trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia), among others.
history_site:
Singuney is an Arhuaco community located in the Chinchicua micro-basin, within the Ariguaní River basin, between 650 and 1,100 m.a.s.l, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The area shows a clear historical record of localized burning in its northern part and a deforestation pattern concentrated in the southern and western sections of the community. The best-preserved vegetation covers are found to the east of the populated center; however, the landscape—dominated by tall secondary vegetation—is not homogeneous, being interrupted by patches of overgrown pastures and fern thickets that indicate poor and depleted soils.

Overall, landscape fragmentation is closely associated with burning pressure from livestock activities and the expansion of the agricultural frontier. It is necessary to design and implement landscape management tools to reverse the degradation of the forested landscape in the micro-basin, particularly along the right bank, downstream of the Chinchicua stream.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to vegetation covers of the Sub-Andean Orobiome, which include secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural spaces in the locality of Singuney, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The following species are representative in terms of abundance and frequency: oak (Tabebuia sp.), trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Common species with more than 50% frequency in the vegetation covers of this Sub-Andean biome include: mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), achote (Vismia sp.), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guayabito (Calophylon sp.). Less frequently found species include: avocado (Persea americana), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), palm, corazón fino (Platymyscium pinnatum), cuchillito (Senna sp.), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guava (Psidium guajaba), moringa (Moringa oleifera), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), walnut (Cordia sp.), pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.) and Sula (Trema sp.). In some specific polygons, exclusive populations can be found of abarco (Cariniana pyriformis), achote (Vismia sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), lechoso (Brosimum sp.), granadilla (Caesalpinia sp.), and ceiba (Ceiba pentandra).﻿This mainly corresponds to a mosaic of pastures and/or crops and/or natural spaces located within a humid tropical zonobiome, in the locality of Seykwanamake, within the mid-altitudinal band between 650 and 900 meters above sea level, in the Fundación River basin, Arhuaco Reserve of the Sierra, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this land cover, vegetation enrichment is mainly notable for the following species: oak (Tabebuia sp.), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), small-leaf guava (Calophyllum sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), and an unspecified palm. To a lesser extent, though equally important, the following species are also present: avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), camajón (Sterculia apetala), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guayacán (Tabebuia chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), and trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia), among others.It corresponds mainly to secondary vegetation cover or in transition, located in a humid tropical zone, in the town of Singuney, in the average altitude range between 650 and 900 meters above sea level, in the basin of the Fundación River, Resguardo Arhuaco de la Sierra, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, there is an enrichment of vegetation with species of roble (Tabebuia sp.), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), guayabito (Calophyllum sp.) and unspecified palm.

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This corresponds to areas with mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces, in the locality of Ati Gumake, within the humid tropical zonobiome, in a mid-altitudinal band between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, in the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, Palomino River basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. This land cover has been mainly enriched with timber species such as oak (Tabebuia sp.) and mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla). To a lesser extent, the following species have been promoted: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp.), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Similarly, species important for agro-food security such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), soursop (Annona muricata), and pear (Syzygium malaccense) are also found associated with these land covers.Corresponds to areas with a predominance of secondary vegetation or in transition, in the locality of Atygumake, within the humid tropical zone, in a medium altitudinal range between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, within the Palomino River basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The following species are found in this cover: abarco (Cariniana sp. ), aceituno (Vitex cymosa), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), red kapok (Pachira quinata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), laurel (Nectandra sp. ), roble (Tabebuia rosea) and sambocedron (Guarea guidonia). Likewise, associated with these hedges, the planting of some species of food importance such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), guamo (Inga sp.), wild guamo (Inga edulis) and Moringa (Moringa oleifera) has been promoted. The plant enrichment in terms of abundance of this cover is remarkable through the promotion of species such as the campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla) and in smaller quantities but equally important the planting of the guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum) and the bitter palm (Sabal mauritiformis).
history_site:
The Ati Gumake sector is one of the first Arhuaco territories reestablished on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada, thanks to the cultural and political efforts of the four peoples of the Sierra. This process made possible the partial recovery of the territory known as the “exit to the sea” of the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, located between the Don Diego and Palomino rivers, during the final decades of the twentieth century. The community is situated where the Lucuici River, El Puerco stream, and the Palomino River joint, between 250 and 1000 meters above sea level.

The most affected areas by deforestation in recent decades are concentrated in the northern, central, and western parts of this terriroty. However, it is important to note that this zone was heavily impacted by the presence of illicit crops until the first decade of the 21st century. Fires, cattle ranching and the expansion of the agricultural frontier remain historical drivers of change in the region. Around the populated center, there are areas of clean and weedy pastures, as well as mosaics of crops, pastures, and natural spaces. The presence of large trees to the northwest of the populated area offers an opportunity to establish seed banks of late-successional and pioneer timber species, oriented the ecological restoration of this area with a long-term vision.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site:
It mainly corresponds to a mosaic cover of pastures, crops, and natural areas and/or secondary or transitional vegetation, sometimes associated with remnants of dense forest, clean or weedy pastures, and rivers, within the Orobiome of the Sub-Andean Forest in the Bunkwamake sector, in the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.

The main species recorded in this orobiome include: aguacate macho (Ocotea calophylla), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), palm (Palma sp.), oak (Tabebuia sp.), and tabaco (Pseudosamanea sp.).

Less frequently or in smaller proportions, the following species are associated: campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and lechosa (Nectandra sp. 2).
This corresponds to areas dominated by mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces, in the locality of Bunkwamake, within the mid-altitudinal band between 650 and 800 meters above sea level, in the humid tropical zonobiome, Fundación River basin, western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. This land cover is notable for vegetation enrichment with species such as aguacate macho (Persea caerulea), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), cedar (Cedrela odorata), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), laurel (Nectandra sp.), lechoso (Brosimum sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), an unidentified palm, oak (Tabebuia sp.), and tabaco (Pseudosamanea sp.).It mainly corresponds to a mosaic cover of pastures, crops, and natural areas and/or secondary or transitional vegetation, sometimes associated with remnants of dense forest, clean or weedy pastures, and rivers, within the Orobiome of the Sub-Andean Forest in the Bunkwamake sector, in the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.

The main species recorded in this orobiome include: aguacate macho (Ocotea calophylla), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), palm (Palma sp.), oak (Tabebuia sp.), and tabaco (Pseudosamanea sp.).

Less frequently or in smaller proportions, the following species are associated: campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and lechosa (Nectandra sp. 2).
Corresponds to areas with a predominance of secondary vegetation or in transition, in the town of Bunkwimake, in the average altitudinal strip between 280 and 340 meters above sea level, once affected by the expansion of the agricultural and livestock frontier in the humid tropical zone, in the basin of the Don Diego River, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, there is an enrichment of vegetation with species of great timber value and constructive use, including species that are threatened at the regional and local levels, such as: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum),caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), roble (Tabebuia sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guasimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), laurel (Nectandra sp), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Other species of importance for food security have also been promoted, such as avocado (Persea americana), guamo (Inga sp.), Moringa (Moringa oleifera) and pear (Syzygium malaccense).It mainly corresponds to a mosaic cover of pastures, crops, and natural areas and/or secondary or transitional vegetation, sometimes associated with remnants of dense forest, clean or weedy pastures, and rivers, within the Orobiome of the Sub-Andean Forest in the Bunkwamake sector, in the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.

The main species recorded in this orobiome include: aguacate macho (Ocotea calophylla), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), palm (Palma sp.), oak (Tabebuia sp.), and tabaco (Pseudosamanea sp.).

Less frequently or in smaller proportions, the following species are associated: campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and lechosa (Nectandra sp. 2).
history_site:
Bunkwamuke, also popularly known as Galaxia, is a territory of the Arhuaco Indigenous people located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, near the Nabusimake River, within the larger Fundación River. It lies between 700 and 1,250 meters above sea level and shows high signs of landscape fragmentation caused by cumulative deforestation over recent decades. The creation and expansion of gardens or slash-and-burn plots within forest and secondary vegetation areas, along with vegetation burning events, are among the practices driving the observed fragmentation pattern.

The presence of eroded soils, areas affected by terracing, and overgrown pastures are indicators of the progressive deterioration of the landscape associated with livestock farming impacts. These livestock-use areas generally cover polygons with an average size ranging between 4 and 8 hectares. The best-preserved remnants of vegetation correspond to tall secondary growth located near natural drainage systems, which constitute potential germ-plasm banks that could support ecological restoration processes.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site:
It corresponds to vegetation cover associated with aquatic ecosystems featuring a permanent water body, either static or flowing, in the locality of Aty Gumake﻿, within the cuenca del río Palomino﻿, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿.

In this hydrobiome, vegetation enrichment is characterized by the following species: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guamo (Inga sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), and oak (Tabebuia sp.).

Occasionally associated with this hydrobiome in the locality of Aty Gumake﻿ are species such as: avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cascarillo (Protium sp.), cedar (Cedrela odorata), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and bitter palm (Sabal mauritiformis).
Corresponds to areas of dense forest and/or forests with signs of fragmentation, in the town of Bunkwimake, in the average altitudinal range between 280 and 340 meters above sea level, associated with the expansion of the agricultural and livestock frontier in the humid tropical zone of the Don Diego river basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, plant enrichment with species of great timber value and constructive use stands out, including species that are threatened at the regional and local levels, such as: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), roble (Tabebuia sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), and palma amarga (Sabal mauritiformis). Other species of importance for soil recovery and as food for fauna have also been promoted, including guamo (Inga sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), among others.

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: Corresponds to areas with clean and/or weeded pasture cover in the locality of Ati Gumake, within the humid tropical zone, in an average altitudinal range between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, in the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Reserve, Palomino river basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, the following species stand out for their frequency and density: roble (Tabebuia sp.), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla) and cedro (Cedrela odorata). At lower densities, algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp. ), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), palma amarga (Sabal mauritiformis) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). In some polygons of this vegetation cover, species of agrifood importance for the Arhuaca community have been planted, such as: avocado (Persea americana), árbol del pan (Artocarpus altilis), cañandonga (Cassia grandis), marañon (Anacardium occidentale), moringa (Moringa oleifera) and pera (Syizigyum malaccense). This corresponds to areas with mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces, in the locality of Ati Gumake, within the humid tropical zonobiome, in a mid-altitudinal band between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, in the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, Palomino River basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. This land cover has been mainly enriched with timber species such as oak (Tabebuia sp.) and mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla). To a lesser extent, the following species have been promoted: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp.), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Similarly, species important for agro-food security such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), soursop (Annona muricata), and pear (Syzygium malaccense) are also found associated with these land covers.
history_site:
The Ati Gumake sector is one of the first Arhuaco territories reestablished on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada, thanks to the cultural and political efforts of the four peoples of the Sierra. This process made possible the partial recovery of the territory known as the “exit to the sea” of the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, located between the Don Diego and Palomino rivers, during the final decades of the twentieth century. The community is situated where the Lucuici River, El Puerco stream, and the Palomino River joint, between 250 and 1000 meters above sea level.

The most affected areas by deforestation in recent decades are concentrated in the northern, central, and western parts of this terriroty. However, it is important to note that this zone was heavily impacted by the presence of illicit crops until the first decade of the 21st century. Fires, cattle ranching and the expansion of the agricultural frontier remain historical drivers of change in the region. Around the populated center, there are areas of clean and weedy pastures, as well as mosaics of crops, pastures, and natural spaces. The presence of large trees to the northwest of the populated area offers an opportunity to establish seed banks of late-successional and pioneer timber species, oriented the ecological restoration of this area with a long-term vision.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This corresponds to areas with mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces, in the locality of Ati Gumake, within the humid tropical zonobiome, in a mid-altitudinal band between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, in the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, Palomino River basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. This land cover has been mainly enriched with timber species such as oak (Tabebuia sp.) and mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla). To a lesser extent, the following species have been promoted: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp.), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Similarly, species important for agro-food security such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), soursop (Annona muricata), and pear (Syzygium malaccense) are also found associated with these land covers.Corresponds to areas of dense forest and/or forests with signs of fragmentation, in the town of Bunkwimake, in the average altitudinal range between 280 and 340 meters above sea level, associated with the expansion of the agricultural and livestock frontier in the humid tropical zone of the Don Diego river basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, plant enrichment with species of great timber value and constructive use stands out, including species that are threatened at the regional and local levels, such as: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), roble (Tabebuia sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), and palma amarga (Sabal mauritiformis). Other species of importance for soil recovery and as food for fauna have also been promoted, including guamo (Inga sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), among others. Corresponds to areas with a predominance of secondary vegetation or in transition, in the locality of Atygumake, within the humid tropical zone, in a medium altitudinal range between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, within the Palomino River basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The following species are found in this cover: abarco (Cariniana sp. ), aceituno (Vitex cymosa), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), red kapok (Pachira quinata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), laurel (Nectandra sp. ), roble (Tabebuia rosea) and sambocedron (Guarea guidonia). Likewise, associated with these hedges, the planting of some species of food importance such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), guamo (Inga sp.), wild guamo (Inga edulis) and Moringa (Moringa oleifera) has been promoted. The plant enrichment in terms of abundance of this cover is remarkable through the promotion of species such as the campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla) and in smaller quantities but equally important the planting of the guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum) and the bitter palm (Sabal mauritiformis).It corresponds to riparian vegetation cover associated with rivers in the locality of Aty Gumake, within the Palomino River basin, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The main planted species associated with this cover include avocado (Persea americana), jatobá (Hymenaea courbaril), caney (Aspidosperma polyneuron), pink shower tree (Cassia grandis), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemono (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp.), and oak (Tabebuia sp.). Less frequent and less dense individuals include abarco (Cariniana sp.), aceituno (Vitex cymosa), clementino, laurel (Nectandra sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), campano (Samanea saman), cascariillo (Protium sp.), and red ceiba (Pachira quinata).

However, it is important to note that this zone was heavily impacted by the presence of illicit crops until the first decade of the 21st century. project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This corresponds to mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces in the locality of Bunkwimake, within the mid-altitudinal band between 280 and 340 meters above sea level, in the humid tropical zonobiome, Don Diego River basin, Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this land cover, enrichment with plant species of high timber value and construction utility stands out, such as: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), oak (Tabebuia sp.), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), laurel (Nectandra sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). To a lesser extent, but with good frequency, species such as algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), kamaleandra (Calliandra sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), among others, have been associated. Likewise, other species important for food security have been promoted, such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), pear (Syzygium malaccense), guamo (Inga sp.), and moringa (Moringa oleifera).Corresponds to areas of dense forest and/or forests with signs of fragmentation in the locality of Atygumake, within the humid tropical zone, in an average altitudinal range between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, within the Palomino River basin, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage there is an enrichment of vegetation with species of timber importance, especially with constructive use value, among which stand out: laurel (Nectandra sp. ), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), roble (Tabebuia sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), camapano (Samanea saman). Likewise, in some of these cover crops, the planting of other species of community importance has been promoted, such as avocado (Persea americana) and Moringa (Moringa oleifera), which favor the expectations of the Arhuaca population's own economy and food security.
history_site:
Bunkwimake is an Arhuaco territory located near the Don Dieguito River, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada, in the area known as the “exit to the sea” of the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve. It is currently one of the main consolidated population centers in the northern sector of the Sierra. The area lies between 200 and 500 m.a.s.l and is part of the Tropical Humid Zonobiome, which was severely impacted in the late 20th and early 21st centuries thorugh illicit crops.

Nevertheless, through the Plan Colombia—which promoted manual eradication and aerial control of such crops, along with land legislation in favor of the Indigenous Reserve—progress has been made to natural recovery and productive reconversion. Cocoa farming and other semi-permanent crops have become key strategies to gradually improve ecological connectivity indicators and strengthen the local economy.

Burning and deforestation are other historical drivers of transformation that continue their influence in the region, particularly on the southern side of the populated center. Likewise, areas impacted by deforestation in recent decades are highly noticeable in all four cardinal directions; however, some key remnants of dense forest and tall secondary vegetation remain, especially toward the northeastern sector of the populated area.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds mainly to clean and/or eventually weeded pasture cover in the locality of Bunkwimake, in the average altitudinal strip between 280 and 340 meters above sea level, in the humid tropical zone of the Don Diego river basin, Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco indigenous reservation, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, there is an enrichment of vegetation with species of great timber value and constructive use, including species in the threatened category at the regional and local levels, such as: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracoli (Anacardium excelsum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), roble (Tabebuia sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), and palma amarga (Sabal mauritiformis). There is also the planting of an almost extinct species known locally as Clementino and other key species in the protection of ecosystems such as algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), ceiba roja (Pachira quinata), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), guácimo (GUazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp. ), laurel (Nectandra sp.), perehuetano (Parinari pachyphylla) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). In this coverage, there is an enrichment of vegetation with species of great timber value and constructive use, including species that are threatened at the regional and local levels, such as: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum),caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), roble (Tabebuia sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guasimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), laurel (Nectandra sp), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Other species of importance for food security have also been promoted, such as avocado (Persea americana), guamo (Inga sp.), Moringa (Moringa oleifera) and pear (Syzygium malaccense).

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to vegetation covers of the Sub-Andean Orobiome, which include secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural spaces in the locality of Singuney, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The following species are representative in terms of abundance and frequency: oak (Tabebuia sp.), trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Common species with more than 50% frequency in the vegetation covers of this Sub-Andean biome include: mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), achote (Vismia sp.), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guayabito (Calophylon sp.). Less frequently found species include: avocado (Persea americana), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), palm, corazón fino (Platymyscium pinnatum), cuchillito (Senna sp.), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guava (Psidium guajaba), moringa (Moringa oleifera), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), walnut (Cordia sp.), pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.) and Sula (Trema sp.). In some specific polygons, exclusive populations can be found of abarco (Cariniana pyriformis), achote (Vismia sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), lechoso (Brosimum sp.), granadilla (Caesalpinia sp.), and ceiba (Ceiba pentandra).﻿This mainly corresponds to a mosaic of pastures and/or crops and/or natural spaces located within a humid tropical zonobiome, in the locality of Seykwanamake, within the mid-altitudinal band between 650 and 900 meters above sea level, in the Fundación River basin, Arhuaco Reserve of the Sierra, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this land cover, vegetation enrichment is mainly notable for the following species: oak (Tabebuia sp.), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), small-leaf guava (Calophyllum sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), and an unspecified palm. To a lesser extent, though equally important, the following species are also present: avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), camajón (Sterculia apetala), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guayacán (Tabebuia chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), and trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia), among others.It corresponds mainly to secondary vegetation cover or in transition, located in a humid tropical zone, in the town of Singuney, in the average altitude range between 650 and 900 meters above sea level, in the basin of the Fundación River, Resguardo Arhuaco de la Sierra, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, there is an enrichment of vegetation with species of roble (Tabebuia sp.), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), guayabito (Calophyllum sp.) and unspecified palm.
history_site:
Singuney is an Arhuaco community located in the Chinchicua micro-basin, within the Ariguaní River basin, between 650 and 1,100 m.a.s.l, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The area shows a clear historical record of localized burning in its northern part and a deforestation pattern concentrated in the southern and western sections of the community. The best-preserved vegetation covers are found to the east of the populated center; however, the landscape—dominated by tall secondary vegetation—is not homogeneous, being interrupted by patches of overgrown pastures and fern thickets that indicate poor and depleted soils.

Overall, landscape fragmentation is closely associated with burning pressure from livestock activities and the expansion of the agricultural frontier. It is necessary to design and implement landscape management tools to reverse the degradation of the forested landscape in the micro-basin, particularly along the right bank, downstream of the Chinchicua stream.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

Likewise, other species important for food security have been promoted, such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), pear (Syzygium malaccense), guamo (Inga sp.), and moringa (Moringa oleifera).Corresponds to areas with a predominance of secondary vegetation or in transition, in the town of Bunkwimake, in the average altitudinal strip between 280 and 340 meters above sea level, once affected by the expansion of the agricultural and livestock frontier in the humid tropical zone, in the basin of the Don Diego River, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, there is an enrichment of vegetation with species of great timber value and constructive use, including species that are threatened at the regional and local levels, such as: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum),caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), roble (Tabebuia sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guasimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), laurel (Nectandra sp), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Other species of importance for food security have also been promoted, such as avocado (Persea americana), guamo (Inga sp.), Moringa (Moringa oleifera) and pear (Syzygium malaccense).
history_site:
Bunkwimake is an Arhuaco territory located near the Don Dieguito River, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada, in the area known as the “exit to the sea” of the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve. It is currently one of the main consolidated population centers in the northern sector of the Sierra. The area lies between 200 and 500 m.a.s.l and is part of the Tropical Humid Zonobiome, which was severely impacted in the late 20th and early 21st centuries thorugh illicit crops.

Nevertheless, through the Plan Colombia—which promoted manual eradication and aerial control of such crops, along with land legislation in favor of the Indigenous Reserve—progress has been made to natural recovery and productive reconversion. Cocoa farming and other semi-permanent crops have become key strategies to gradually improve ecological connectivity indicators and strengthen the local economy.

Burning and deforestation are other historical drivers of transformation that continue their influence in the region, particularly on the southern side of the populated center. Likewise, areas impacted by deforestation in recent decades are highly noticeable in all four cardinal directions; however, some key remnants of dense forest and tall secondary vegetation remain, especially toward the northeastern sector of the populated area.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to vegetation covers of the Sub-Andean Orobiome, which include secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural spaces in the locality of Singuney, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The following species are representative in terms of abundance and frequency: oak (Tabebuia sp.), trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Common species with more than 50% frequency in the vegetation covers of this Sub-Andean biome include: mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), achote (Vismia sp.), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guayabito (Calophylon sp.). Less frequently found species include: avocado (Persea americana), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), palm, corazón fino (Platymyscium pinnatum), cuchillito (Senna sp.), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guava (Psidium guajaba), moringa (Moringa oleifera), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), walnut (Cordia sp.), pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.) and Sula (Trema sp.). In some specific polygons, exclusive populations can be found of abarco (Cariniana pyriformis), achote (Vismia sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), lechoso (Brosimum sp.), granadilla (Caesalpinia sp.), and ceiba (Ceiba pentandra).﻿This mainly corresponds to a mosaic of pastures and/or crops and/or natural spaces located within a humid tropical zonobiome, in the locality of Seykwanamake, within the mid-altitudinal band between 650 and 900 meters above sea level, in the Fundación River basin, Arhuaco Reserve of the Sierra, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this land cover, vegetation enrichment is mainly notable for the following species: oak (Tabebuia sp.), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), small-leaf guava (Calophyllum sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), and an unspecified palm. To a lesser extent, though equally important, the following species are also present: avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), camajón (Sterculia apetala), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guayacán (Tabebuia chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), and trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia), among others.It corresponds mainly to secondary vegetation cover or in transition, located in a humid tropical zone, in the town of Singuney, in the average altitude range between 650 and 900 meters above sea level, in the basin of the Fundación River, Resguardo Arhuaco de la Sierra, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, there is an enrichment of vegetation with species of roble (Tabebuia sp.), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), guayabito (Calophyllum sp.) and unspecified palm.
history_site:
Singuney is an Arhuaco community located in the Chinchicua micro-basin, within the Ariguaní River basin, between 650 and 1,100 m.a.s.l, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The area shows a clear historical record of localized burning in its northern part and a deforestation pattern concentrated in the southern and western sections of the community. The best-preserved vegetation covers are found to the east of the populated center; however, the landscape—dominated by tall secondary vegetation—is not homogeneous, being interrupted by patches of overgrown pastures and fern thickets that indicate poor and depleted soils.

Overall, landscape fragmentation is closely associated with burning pressure from livestock activities and the expansion of the agricultural frontier. It is necessary to design and implement landscape management tools to reverse the degradation of the forested landscape in the micro-basin, particularly along the right bank, downstream of the Chinchicua stream.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site:
This corresponds to areas dominated by mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces, in the locality of Bunkwamake, within the mid-altitudinal band between 650 and 800 meters above sea level, in the humid tropical zonobiome, Fundación River basin, western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. This land cover is notable for vegetation enrichment with species such as aguacate macho (Persea caerulea), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), cedar (Cedrela odorata), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), laurel (Nectandra sp.), lechoso (Brosimum sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), an unidentified palm, oak (Tabebuia sp.), and tabaco (Pseudosamanea sp.).It mainly corresponds to a mosaic cover of pastures, crops, and natural areas and/or secondary or transitional vegetation, sometimes associated with remnants of dense forest, clean or weedy pastures, and rivers, within the Orobiome of the Sub-Andean Forest in the Bunkwamake sector, in the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.

The main species recorded in this orobiome include: aguacate macho (Ocotea calophylla), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), palm (Palma sp.), oak (Tabebuia sp.), and tabaco (Pseudosamanea sp.).

Less frequently or in smaller proportions, the following species are associated: campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and lechosa (Nectandra sp. 2).
history_site:
Bunkwamuke, also popularly known as Galaxia, is a territory of the Arhuaco Indigenous people located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, near the Nabusimake River, within the larger Fundación River. It lies between 700 and 1,250 meters above sea level and shows high signs of landscape fragmentation caused by cumulative deforestation over recent decades. The creation and expansion of gardens or slash-and-burn plots within forest and secondary vegetation areas, along with vegetation burning events, are among the practices driving the observed fragmentation pattern.

The presence of eroded soils, areas affected by terracing, and overgrown pastures are indicators of the progressive deterioration of the landscape associated with livestock farming impacts. These livestock-use areas generally cover polygons with an average size ranging between 4 and 8 hectares. The best-preserved remnants of vegetation correspond to tall secondary growth located near natural drainage systems, which constitute potential germ-plasm banks that could support ecological restoration processes.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

The main species recorded in this orobiome include: aguacate macho (Ocotea calophylla), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), palm (Palma sp.), oak (Tabebuia sp.), and tabaco (Pseudosamanea sp.).

Bunkwamuke, also popularly known as Galaxia, is a territory of the Arhuaco Indigenous people located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, near the Nabusimake River, within the larger Fundación River. It lies between 700 and 1,250 meters above sea level and shows high signs of landscape fragmentation caused by cumulative deforestation over recent decades. project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to vegetation covers of the Sub-Andean Orobiome, which include secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural spaces in the locality of Singuney, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The following species are representative in terms of abundance and frequency: oak (Tabebuia sp.), trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Common species with more than 50% frequency in the vegetation covers of this Sub-Andean biome include: mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), achote (Vismia sp.), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guayabito (Calophylon sp.). Less frequently found species include: avocado (Persea americana), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), palm, corazón fino (Platymyscium pinnatum), cuchillito (Senna sp.), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guava (Psidium guajaba), moringa (Moringa oleifera), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), walnut (Cordia sp.), pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.) and Sula (Trema sp.). In some specific polygons, exclusive populations can be found of abarco (Cariniana pyriformis), achote (Vismia sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), lechoso (Brosimum sp.), granadilla (Caesalpinia sp.), and ceiba (Ceiba pentandra).﻿
history_site:
Singuney is an Arhuaco community located in the Chinchicua micro-basin, within the Ariguaní River basin, between 650 and 1,100 m.a.s.l, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The area shows a clear historical record of localized burning in its northern part and a deforestation pattern concentrated in the southern and western sections of the community. The best-preserved vegetation covers are found to the east of the populated center; however, the landscape—dominated by tall secondary vegetation—is not homogeneous, being interrupted by patches of overgrown pastures and fern thickets that indicate poor and depleted soils.

Overall, landscape fragmentation is closely associated with burning pressure from livestock activities and the expansion of the agricultural frontier. It is necessary to design and implement landscape management tools to reverse the degradation of the forested landscape in the micro-basin, particularly along the right bank, downstream of the Chinchicua stream.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

Less frequently or in smaller proportions, the following species are associated: campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and lechosa (Nectandra sp. 2).
history_site:
Bunkwamuke, also popularly known as Galaxia, is a territory of the Arhuaco Indigenous people located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, near the Nabusimake River, within the larger Fundación River. It lies between 700 and 1,250 meters above sea level and shows high signs of landscape fragmentation caused by cumulative deforestation over recent decades. The creation and expansion of gardens or slash-and-burn plots within forest and secondary vegetation areas, along with vegetation burning events, are among the practices driving the observed fragmentation pattern.

The presence of eroded soils, areas affected by terracing, and overgrown pastures are indicators of the progressive deterioration of the landscape associated with livestock farming impacts. These livestock-use areas generally cover polygons with an average size ranging between 4 and 8 hectares. The best-preserved remnants of vegetation correspond to tall secondary growth located near natural drainage systems, which constitute potential germ-plasm banks that could support ecological restoration processes.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to vegetation covers of the Sub-Andean Orobiome, which include secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural spaces in the locality of Singuney, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The following species are representative in terms of abundance and frequency: oak (Tabebuia sp.), trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Common species with more than 50% frequency in the vegetation covers of this Sub-Andean biome include: mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), achote (Vismia sp.), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guayabito (Calophylon sp.). Less frequently found species include: avocado (Persea americana), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), palm, corazón fino (Platymyscium pinnatum), cuchillito (Senna sp.), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guava (Psidium guajaba), moringa (Moringa oleifera), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), walnut (Cordia sp.), pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.) and Sula (Trema sp.). In some specific polygons, exclusive populations can be found of abarco (Cariniana pyriformis), achote (Vismia sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), lechoso (Brosimum sp.), granadilla (Caesalpinia sp.), and ceiba (Ceiba pentandra).﻿It corresponds to vegetation covers of the Sub-Andean Orobiome, which include secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural spaces in the locality of Singuney, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. Less frequently found species include: avocado (Persea americana), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), palm, corazón fino (Platymyscium pinnatum), cuchillito (Senna sp.), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guava (Psidium guajaba), moringa (Moringa oleifera), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), walnut (Cordia sp.), pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.) and Sula (Trema sp.). In some specific polygons, exclusive populations can be found of abarco (Cariniana pyriformis), achote (Vismia sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), lechoso (Brosimum sp.), granadilla (Caesalpinia sp.), and ceiba (Ceiba pentandra).﻿
history_site:
Singuney is an Arhuaco community located in the Chinchicua micro-basin, within the Ariguaní River basin, between 650 and 1,100 m.a.s.l, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The area shows a clear historical record of localized burning in its northern part and a deforestation pattern concentrated in the southern and western sections of the community. The best-preserved vegetation covers are found to the east of the populated center; however, the landscape—dominated by tall secondary vegetation—is not homogeneous, being interrupted by patches of overgrown pastures and fern thickets that indicate poor and depleted soils.

Overall, landscape fragmentation is closely associated with burning pressure from livestock activities and the expansion of the agricultural frontier. It is necessary to design and implement landscape management tools to reverse the degradation of the forested landscape in the micro-basin, particularly along the right bank, downstream of the Chinchicua stream.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This mainly corresponds to a mosaic of pastures and/or crops and/or natural spaces located within a humid tropical zonobiome, in the locality of Seykwanamake, within the mid-altitudinal band between 650 and 900 meters above sea level, in the Fundación River basin, Arhuaco Reserve of the Sierra, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this land cover, vegetation enrichment is mainly notable for the following species: oak (Tabebuia sp.), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), small-leaf guava (Calophyllum sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), and an unspecified palm. To a lesser extent, though equally important, the following species are also present: avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), camajón (Sterculia apetala), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guayacán (Tabebuia chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), and trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia), among others.

Bunkwamuke, also popularly known as Galaxia, is a territory of the Arhuaco Indigenous people located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, near the Nabusimake River, within the larger Fundación River. It lies between 700 and 1,250 meters above sea level and shows high signs of landscape fragmentation caused by cumulative deforestation over recent decades. The creation and expansion of gardens or slash-and-burn plots within forest and secondary vegetation areas, along with vegetation burning events, are among the practices driving the observed fragmentation pattern.

The presence of eroded soils, areas affected by terracing, and overgrown pastures are indicators of the progressive deterioration of the landscape associated with livestock farming impacts. These livestock-use areas generally cover polygons with an average size ranging between 4 and 8 hectares. The best-preserved remnants of vegetation correspond to tall secondary growth located near natural drainage systems, which constitute potential germ-plasm banks that could support ecological restoration processes.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to vegetation covers of the Sub-Andean Orobiome, which include secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural spaces in the locality of Singuney, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The following species are representative in terms of abundance and frequency: oak (Tabebuia sp.), trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Common species with more than 50% frequency in the vegetation covers of this Sub-Andean biome include: mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), achote (Vismia sp.), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guayabito (Calophylon sp.). Less frequently found species include: avocado (Persea americana), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), palm, corazón fino (Platymyscium pinnatum), cuchillito (Senna sp.), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guava (Psidium guajaba), moringa (Moringa oleifera), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), walnut (Cordia sp.), pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.) and Sula (Trema sp.). In some specific polygons, exclusive populations can be found of abarco (Cariniana pyriformis), achote (Vismia sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), lechoso (Brosimum sp.), granadilla (Caesalpinia sp.), and ceiba (Ceiba pentandra).﻿It corresponds to vegetation covers of the Sub-Andean Orobiome, which include secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural spaces in the locality of Singuney, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. history_site:
Singuney is an Arhuaco community located in the Chinchicua micro-basin, within the Ariguaní River basin, between 650 and 1,100 m.a.s.l, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The area shows a clear historical record of localized burning in its northern part and a deforestation pattern concentrated in the southern and western sections of the community. The best-preserved vegetation covers are found to the east of the populated center; however, the landscape—dominated by tall secondary vegetation—is not homogeneous, being interrupted by patches of overgrown pastures and fern thickets that indicate poor and depleted soils.

Overall, landscape fragmentation is closely associated with burning pressure from livestock activities and the expansion of the agricultural frontier. It is necessary to design and implement landscape management tools to reverse the degradation of the forested landscape in the micro-basin, particularly along the right bank, downstream of the Chinchicua stream.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site:
It mainly corresponds to a mosaic cover of pastures, crops, and natural areas and/or secondary or transitional vegetation, sometimes associated with remnants of dense forest, clean or weedy pastures, and rivers, within the Orobiome of the Sub-Andean Forest in the Bunkwamake sector, in the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.

The main species recorded in this orobiome include: aguacate macho (Ocotea calophylla), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), palm (Palma sp.), oak (Tabebuia sp.), and tabaco (Pseudosamanea sp.).

Less frequently or in smaller proportions, the following species are associated: campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and lechosa (Nectandra sp. 2).

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to the vegetation covers of the Orobioma subandino that include secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, dense forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural spaces in the locality of Umake, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The following species are representative in terms of abundance and frequency for all vegetation covers: mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), and oak (Tabebuia sp.). Less than 70% of appearances are followed by species such as guamo (Inga sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and walnut (Cordia aliodora). The latter species shows a high record of abundance. At 50% or less frequency, species such as avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), granadilla (Caesalpinia sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), lechoso (Brosimum sp.), and tabaco (Caesalpinia sp2) are reported. With a frequency lower than 10%, the following are recorded: carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), árbol del pan (Artocarpus altilis), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), ceiba roja (Pachira quinata), corazón fino (Platymyscium pinnatum), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guamo de piedra (Zygia longifolia), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), palma, and varasanta (Triplaris americana). Finally, some species exclusive to specific covers include: achote (Vismia sp), aguacate macho (Persea caerulea), campano (Samanea saman), pera (Zyzygium malaccense), pionío (Erythrina sp.), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia).﻿
history_site:
Umake is an Arhuaco community located in the micro-basin of the Nabusimake River, within the limits and currents of the Fundación River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, between 850 and 1,400 m.a.s.l. This area shows a recurring pattern of historical deforestation, except in the northeastern and southern sectors of the locality, where dense upland forest and secondary vegetation persist. These areas form part of the transition between the Tropical Humid Zonobiome and the Sub-Andean Forest Orobiome.

Subsistence and semi-permanent crops are established in the vecinity of the populated center. The clean and weedy pasture covers that characterize the fragmented landscape range from 1 to 8 hectares and represent the areas with the greatest need for adopting landscape management tools to mitigate environmental degradation.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site:
It mainly corresponds to a mosaic coverage of pastures, crops, and natural areas and/or secondary or transitional vegetation, sometimes associated with remnants of dense forest, clean or weedy pastures, and rivers within the Sub-Andean Forest orobiome of the Gunmaku sector, bordering the Aracataca and Tucurinca river basins on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.

The main species associated with this orobiome include: aguacatillo (Persea caerulea), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), guamo (Inga sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), laurel (Nectandra sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), oak (Tabebuia sp.), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia).

With moderate representativeness, one can also find species such as Brosimum alicastrum (breadnut), Jacaranda sp. (gualanday), Zygia longifolia (stone guamo), Moringa oleifera (moringa), and various palms. Less commonly associated species include Aspidosperma polyneuron (carreto), Erythrina edulis (mountain immortelle or chachafruto), Ochroma pyramidale (balsa), Senna sp. (cuchillito), Persea americana (avocado), Handroanthus chrysantha (yellow ipe or guayacán), Calophyllum sp. (guayabito), Cordia sp. (nogal), Lafoensia punicifolia (trompito), Miconia sp. (tuno), and Nectandra sp. (pepa de loro), among others.
history_site:
Gunmaku is an Arhuaco Indigenous settlement located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, between the Tucurinca River and the Tres Vueltas stream. This territory lies between 350 and 600 ma.s.l, with a significant presence of areas degraded by overgrazing, particularly north of the populated center, on the right bank—downstream—of the Tucurinca River, where a polygon of more than 100 hectares with bare and degraded soils, as well as open grasslands with scattered trees can be observed.

The historical intensity of livestock activity in this area is evident from the terracing scars visible on the hillside and hilltop landscapes. Although scarce, secondary vegetation is mainly found to the south and southeast of the populated center. The abundance of wine palm (Attalea butyracea) standing out in the landscape on the western side of Gunmaku suggests that these areas have been historically subjected to disturbance through burning.

The gallery forest belt is moderately interrupted by the presence of agricultural crops; however, it maintains an average width of 30 to 50 meters in the best-preserved corridors.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters
