Finally, some species exclusive to specific covers include: achote (Vismia sp), aguacate macho (Persea caerulea), campano (Samanea saman), pera (Zyzygium malaccense), pionío (Erythrina sp.), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia).﻿It corresponds to the vegetation covers of the Orobioma subandino that include secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, dense forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural spaces in the locality of Umake, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The following species are representative in terms of abundance and frequency for all vegetation covers: mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), and oak (Tabebuia sp.). Less than 70% of appearances are followed by species such as guamo (Inga sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and walnut (Cordia aliodora). The latter species shows a high record of abundance. At 50% or less frequency, species such as avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), granadilla (Caesalpinia sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), lechoso (Brosimum sp.), and tabaco (Caesalpinia sp2) are reported. With a frequency lower than 10%, the following are recorded: carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), árbol del pan (Artocarpus altilis), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), ceiba roja (Pachira quinata), corazón fino (Platymyscium pinnatum), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guamo de piedra (Zygia longifolia), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), palma, and varasanta (Triplaris americana). Finally, some species exclusive to specific covers include: achote (Vismia sp), aguacate macho (Persea caerulea), campano (Samanea saman), pera (Zyzygium malaccense), pionío (Erythrina sp.), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia).﻿
history_site:
Umake is an Arhuaco community located in the micro-basin of the Nabusimake River, within the limits and currents of the Fundación River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, between 850 and 1,400 m.a.s.l. This area shows a recurring pattern of historical deforestation, except in the northeastern and southern sectors of the locality, where dense upland forest and secondary vegetation persist. These areas form part of the transition between the Tropical Humid Zonobiome and the Sub-Andean Forest Orobiome.

Subsistence and semi-permanent crops are established in the vecinity of the populated center. The clean and weedy pasture covers that characterize the fragmented landscape range from 1 to 8 hectares and represent the areas with the greatest need for adopting landscape management tools to mitigate environmental degradation.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to areas dominated by clean pastures in the locality of Gunmaku, on the boundaries of the Tucurinca and Aracataca river basins, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, within a mid-altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this land cover, vegetation enrichment with species of timber importance stands out, especially those with constructive uses, among which the following are notable: aguacatillo (Persea sp.), campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), cuchillito (Senna sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), fruto de mico (unspecified), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), guamito de piedra (Zygia longifolia), guamo (Inga sp.), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.), oak (Tabebuia sp.), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), and trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia). A remarkable feature in this land cover is the planting of a species considered almost exclusive to this area of the Sierra, locally known as pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.).Corresponds to areas with a predominance of secondary vegetation in the locality of Gunmaku, in the limits of the Tucurinca and Aracataca river basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this coverage, there are important timber species such as: aguacatillo (Persea caerulea), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedro (Cedrela odorata), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), fruta de mico (Bursera simaruba), guamo de piedra (Zygia longifolia), guasimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), roble (Tabebuia sp.), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia) and granadillo (Lafoensia punicifolia).
history_site:
Gunmaku is an Arhuaco Indigenous settlement located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, between the Tucurinca River and the Tres Vueltas stream. This territory lies between 350 and 600 ma.s.l, with a significant presence of areas degraded by overgrazing, particularly north of the populated center, on the right bank—downstream—of the Tucurinca River, where a polygon of more than 100 hectares with bare and degraded soils, as well as open grasslands with scattered trees can be observed.

The historical intensity of livestock activity in this area is evident from the terracing scars visible on the hillside and hilltop landscapes. Although scarce, secondary vegetation is mainly found to the south and southeast of the populated center. The abundance of wine palm (Attalea butyracea) standing out in the landscape on the western side of Gunmaku suggests that these areas have been historically subjected to disturbance through burning.

The gallery forest belt is moderately interrupted by the presence of agricultural crops; however, it maintains an average width of 30 to 50 meters in the best-preserved corridors.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to the vegetation cover present in the Sub-Andean Orobiome, in the locality of Jeywin, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. Within the same landscape unit, which includes secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, dense forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural areas, as well as clean pastures, representative species in terms of abundance and frequency may appear across all vegetation covers, such as mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), guamo (Inga sp.), and oak (Tabebuia sp.). This select group is followed, with a frequency lower than 70%, by species such as algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), and orejero. Less frequently, timber species such as abarco (Cariniana pyriformis) and laurel (Nectandra sp.) can be observed, and only in certain specific covers may species such as red ceiba (Pachira quinata), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.), pera (Syzygium malaccense), tambor (Schyzolobium parahyba), and varasanta (Triplaris americana) appear.It corresponds to the vegetation cover present in the Sub-Andean Orobiome, in the locality of Jeywin, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. Within the same landscape unit, which includes secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, dense forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural areas, as well as clean pastures, representative species in terms of abundance and frequency may appear across all vegetation covers, such as mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), guamo (Inga sp.), and oak (Tabebuia sp.). This select group is followed, with a frequency lower than 70%, by species such as algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), and orejero. Less frequently, timber species such as abarco (Cariniana pyriformis) and laurel (Nectandra sp.) can be observed, and only in certain specific covers may species such as red ceiba (Pachira quinata), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.), pera (Syzygium malaccense), tambor (Schyzolobium parahyba), and varasanta (Triplaris americana) appear.
history_site:
Jeywin is an Arhuaco community located within the micro-basin of the Las Flores stream, a tributary of the Ariguaní River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, between 1,000 and 1,400 m.a.s.l. The area has been affected by historical pressures of deforestation, burning, and livestock farming. Some open areas and overgrown pastures cover between 5 and 7 hectares, while the crop fields near the houses and the populated center usually do not exceed 1 hectare.

Degraded zones are distributed around the settlement, forming a heterogeneous mosaic of pastures, crops, and natural areas. The gallery forest along the Las Flores stream is particularly impacted by land-use dynamics, showing a loss of natural connectivity. It is necessary to work with the community and traditional authorities to review the ancestral land-use and management model, as well as the state of conservation of biodiversity, ecosystem benefits, and the contributions of the different vegetation covers present in the territory. This process would help reframe the environmental sustainability of the area in the medium and long term, considering current and emerging patterns of land use and management.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This corresponds to areas dominated by mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces, in the locality of Gunmaku﻿, at the boundaries of the basins of the ríos Tucurinca y Aracataca﻿, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿, within a mid-altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this land cover, vegetation enrichment stands out with species among which are notable: algarrobo (Samanea saman)﻿, campano (Samanea saman)﻿, caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum)﻿, caoba (Swietenia macrophylla)﻿, caracolí (Anacardium excelsum)﻿, cedro (Cedrela odorata)﻿, ceiba roja (Pachira quinata)﻿, cuchillito (Senna sp.)﻿, dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria)﻿, dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria)﻿, fruto de mico﻿, guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum)﻿, guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia)﻿, gusanero (Astronium graveolens)﻿, laulel (Nectandra sp.)﻿, malambo (Croton malambo)﻿, orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum)﻿, pepa de loro (Nectandra sp2)﻿, roble (Tabebuia sp.)﻿, trompito (Lafoensia puncifolia)﻿, and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia)﻿. In the crops, species of agro-food importance such as: aguacate (Persea americana)﻿, cañandonga (Cassia grandis)﻿, pera (Zyzygium malaccense)﻿, guamo (Inga sp.)﻿, gualanday (Jacaranda sp.)﻿, and moringa (Moringa oleifera)﻿ have been associated.Corresponds to areas with a predominance of gallery forest cover in the locality of Gunmaku, in the limits of the Tucurinca and Aracataca river basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this coverage, the vegetation is enriched with important timber species, especially with constructive use value, among which stand out: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril),caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedro (Cedrela odorata), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guacimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), roble (Tabebuia sp.) and trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia). In addition, other species of community importance such as avocado (Persea americana) and Moringa (Moringa oleifera) have been planted in association with these cover crops, which favor the Arhuaca population's expectations for their own economy and food security.

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This corresponds to areas dominated by mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces in the locality of Kankawarwa﻿, in the cuenca del río Fundación﻿, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿, within a mid-altitudinal band between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In this land cover, vegetation enrichment is notable with timber species of constructive value, among which the following stand out: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril)﻿, campano (Samanea saman)﻿, caoba (Swietenia macrophylla)﻿, carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron)﻿, cedro (Cedrela odorata)﻿, ceiba (Ceiba pentandra)﻿, ceiba roja (Pachira quinata)﻿, cuchillito (Senna sp.)﻿, dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria)﻿, dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria)﻿, guácimo (Guazuma ulmofolia)﻿, guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus)﻿, gusanero (Astronium graveolens)﻿, orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum)﻿, roble (Tabebuia sp.)﻿, and tabaco (Pseudosamanea sp.)﻿. Similarly, the planting of other species of agro-food importance has been promoted, such as aguacate (Persea americana)﻿, pera (Zyzygium malaccense)﻿, zapote (Pouteria zapota)﻿, and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum)﻿, which support the economic expectations and food security of the población arhuaca﻿. In these land covers, the planting of an unspecified palm and another species locally known as cachimbo (Erythrina sp.)﻿ has also been promoted.This corresponds to areas dominated by mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces in the locality of Kankawarwa﻿, in the cuenca del río Fundación﻿, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿, within a mid-altitudinal band between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In this land cover, vegetation enrichment is notable with timber species of constructive value, among which the following stand out: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril)﻿, campano (Samanea saman)﻿, caoba (Swietenia macrophylla)﻿, carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron)﻿, cedro (Cedrela odorata)﻿, ceiba (Ceiba pentandra)﻿, ceiba roja (Pachira quinata)﻿, cuchillito (Senna sp.)﻿, dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria)﻿, dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria)﻿, guácimo (Guazuma ulmofolia)﻿, guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus)﻿, gusanero (Astronium graveolens)﻿, orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum)﻿, roble (Tabebuia sp.)﻿, and tabaco (Pseudosamanea sp.)﻿. Similarly, the planting of other species of agro-food importance has been promoted, such as aguacate (Persea americana)﻿, pera (Zyzygium malaccense)﻿, zapote (Pouteria zapota)﻿, and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum)﻿, which support the economic expectations and food security of the población arhuaca﻿. In these land covers, the planting of an unspecified palm and another species locally known as cachimbo (Erythrina sp.)﻿ has also been promoted.Corresponds to areas with a predominance of secondary vegetation cover or in transition, in the locality of Kankawarwa, in the basin of the Fundación River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In this coverage, the vegetation is enriched with important timber species, including: carob (Hymenaea courbaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), carob (Aspidosperma polyneuron), cedar (Cedrela odorata), kapok (Ceiba pentandra), red kapok (Pachira quinata), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guacimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and oak (Tabebuia sp.). In the same way, the planting of important food crops such as avocado (Persea americana) and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum) has been promoted, which favors the Arhuaca population's expectations for their own economy and food security. The planting of an unspecified palm has been promoted in these areas.
history_site:
Kankawarwa is located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, in the Fundación River basin, within the lower La Cristalina area, between 250 and 500 m.a.s.l. This village was founded in 2009 on a 114-hectare property purchased by the Governor’s Office of Magdalena as part of the establishment of the so-called "pueblos talanquera", within the strategic project known as the “Environmental and Traditional Belt of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.”

It is an area of environmental and cultural importance situated in the lower part of the Sierra Nevada, between La Cristalina stream and the Nabusimake River, where the Arhuaco people have designated one sector for community services and another for traditional living. The region has been affected by historical colonization processes that have led to high levels of landscape fragmentation, mainly linked to cattle farming activities. The relictual state of original forest cover and the loss of native, high-value timber species are some of the visible outcomes of this colonization.

The northern part of the populated center was particularly deforested between 2013 and 2017, according to data from the Global Forest Change observatory and geoportal.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

This select group is followed, with a frequency lower than 70%, by species such as algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), and orejero. Less frequently, timber species such as abarco (Cariniana pyriformis) and laurel (Nectandra sp.) can be observed, and only in certain specific covers may species such as red ceiba (Pachira quinata), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.), pera (Syzygium malaccense), tambor (Schyzolobium parahyba), and varasanta (Triplaris americana) appear.
history_site:
Jeywin is an Arhuaco community located within the micro-basin of the Las Flores stream, a tributary of the Ariguaní River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, between 1,000 and 1,400 m.a.s.l. The area has been affected by historical pressures of deforestation, burning, and livestock farming. Some open areas and overgrown pastures cover between 5 and 7 hectares, while the crop fields near the houses and the populated center usually do not exceed 1 hectare.

Degraded zones are distributed around the settlement, forming a heterogeneous mosaic of pastures, crops, and natural areas. The gallery forest along the Las Flores stream is particularly impacted by land-use dynamics, showing a loss of natural connectivity. It is necessary to work with the community and traditional authorities to review the ancestral land-use and management model, as well as the state of conservation of biodiversity, ecosystem benefits, and the contributions of the different vegetation covers present in the territory. This process would help reframe the environmental sustainability of the area in the medium and long term, considering current and emerging patterns of land use and management.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This corresponds to areas dominated by mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces in the locality of Kankawarwa﻿, in the cuenca del río Fundación﻿, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿, within a mid-altitudinal band between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In this land cover, vegetation enrichment is notable with timber species of constructive value, among which the following stand out: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril)﻿, campano (Samanea saman)﻿, caoba (Swietenia macrophylla)﻿, carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron)﻿, cedro (Cedrela odorata)﻿, ceiba (Ceiba pentandra)﻿, ceiba roja (Pachira quinata)﻿, cuchillito (Senna sp.)﻿, dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria)﻿, dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria)﻿, guácimo (Guazuma ulmofolia)﻿, guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus)﻿, gusanero (Astronium graveolens)﻿, orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum)﻿, roble (Tabebuia sp.)﻿, and tabaco (Pseudosamanea sp.)﻿. Similarly, the planting of other species of agro-food importance has been promoted, such as aguacate (Persea americana)﻿, pera (Zyzygium malaccense)﻿, zapote (Pouteria zapota)﻿, and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum)﻿, which support the economic expectations and food security of the población arhuaca﻿. In these land covers, the planting of an unspecified palm and another species locally known as cachimbo (Erythrina sp.)﻿ has also been promoted.This corresponds to areas dominated by mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces in the locality of Kankawarwa﻿, in the cuenca del río Fundación﻿, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿, within a mid-altitudinal band between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In this coverage, the vegetation is enriched with important timber species, including: carob (Hymenaea courbaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), carob (Aspidosperma polyneuron), cedar (Cedrela odorata), kapok (Ceiba pentandra), red kapok (Pachira quinata), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guacimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and oak (Tabebuia sp.). The planting of an unspecified palm has been promoted in these areas.
history_site:
Kankawarwa is located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, in the Fundación River basin, within the lower La Cristalina area, between 250 and 500 m.a.s.l. This village was founded in 2009 on a 114-hectare property purchased by the Governor’s Office of Magdalena as part of the establishment of the so-called "pueblos talanquera", within the strategic project known as the “Environmental and Traditional Belt of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.”

It is an area of environmental and cultural importance situated in the lower part of the Sierra Nevada, between La Cristalina stream and the Nabusimake River, where the Arhuaco people have designated one sector for community services and another for traditional living. The region has been affected by historical colonization processes that have led to high levels of landscape fragmentation, mainly linked to cattle farming activities. The relictual state of original forest cover and the loss of native, high-value timber species are some of the visible outcomes of this colonization.

The northern part of the populated center was particularly deforested between 2013 and 2017, according to data from the Global Forest Change observatory and geoportal.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This refers to areas predominantly covered by clean or weedy pastures in the locality of Kankawarwa, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in a mid-altitudinal strip ranging between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In this land cover, the enrichment with timber species is notable, especially those valued for construction uses, among which the following stand out: mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), and oak (Tabebuia sp.). To a lesser extent, but equally important, the planting of abarco (Cariniana sp.), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), and orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) has been promoted. Likewise, associated with these land covers, the planting of other species of community importance has been encouraged, such as avocado (Persea americana), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), caimito (Pouteria caimito), and pear (Syzygium malaccense), which supports the Arhuaco population's expectations for self-sustained economy and food security. In these land covers, the planting of a species locally known as cachimbo (Erythrina sp.) has also been promoted.This corresponds to areas dominated by mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces in the locality of Kankawarwa﻿, in the cuenca del río Fundación﻿, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿, within a mid-altitudinal band between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. Similarly, the planting of other species of agro-food importance has been promoted, such as aguacate (Persea americana)﻿, pera (Zyzygium malaccense)﻿, zapote (Pouteria zapota)﻿, and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum)﻿, which support the economic expectations and food security of the población arhuaca﻿. In these land covers, the planting of an unspecified palm and another species locally known as cachimbo (Erythrina sp.)﻿ has also been promoted.

description_site: This corresponds to areas dominated by mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces in the locality of Kankawarwa﻿, in the cuenca del río Fundación﻿, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿, within a mid-altitudinal band between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. Similarly, the planting of other species of agro-food importance has been promoted, such as aguacate (Persea americana)﻿, pera (Zyzygium malaccense)﻿, zapote (Pouteria zapota)﻿, and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum)﻿, which support the economic expectations and food security of the población arhuaca﻿. In these land covers, the planting of an unspecified palm and another species locally known as cachimbo (Erythrina sp.)﻿ has also been promoted.It mainly corresponds to a cover mosaic of pastures, crops, and natural spaces and/or secondary or transitional vegetation, eventually associated with remnants of dense forest, clean or weedy pastures, and rivers in the Sub-Andean rainforest orobiome of the Kankawarwa sector, Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The representative species associated with the covers of this Orobiome include: cedar (Cedrela odorata) and oak (Tabebuia sp.). Common species include: avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), and mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla). Occasionally associated species include: cachimbo (Erythrina sp.), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), red ceiba (Pachira quinata), cuchillito (Senna sp.), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guáimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guamo (Inga sp.), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), palm, and perehuétano (Parinari pachyphylla).﻿

In this cover, plant enrichment stands out with timber species of importance, especially with constructive use value, including notable species such as: caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), cuchillito (Senna sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guacimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), oak (Tabebuia sp.), tambor (Schizolobium parahyba) and totumo (Crescentia cujete). Similarly associated with these covers, the planting of other species of community importance such as avocado (Persea americana) and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum) has been promoted, which favor the expectations of the Arhuaco population's own economy and food security. In these covers, the planting of an unspecified palm and another species locally known as cachimbo (Erythrina sp) has also been promoted.

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: Corresponds to areas with a predominance of secondary vegetation cover or in transition, in the town of Kantinurwa, in the basin of the Fundación River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this coverage, the vegetation is enriched with important timber species, including: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril),  caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), cedro (Cedrela odorata), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), ceiba roja (Pachira quinata), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guacimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and oak (Tabebuia sp.). In the same way, the planting of important food crops such as avocado (Persea americana) and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum) has been promoted, which favors the Arhuaca population's expectations for their own economy and food security. The planting of an unspecified palm has been promoted in these areas.
history_site:
Kantinurwa is a populated Arhuaco settlement located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, at the confluence of the Ariguaní River and the Los Curos stream, between 350 and 750 m.a.s.l. This settlement was founded as a pueblo talanquera in 2009, within the framework of the strategic project known as the “Environmental and Traditional Belt of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.”

The areas most affected by environmental degradation due to vegetation loss are found to the north and west of the populated center, while forested zones with low to minimal intervention are located toward the south and east of the territory. On the right bank—downstream—of the Ariguaní River, north of the settlement, there are degraded and/or clean lands with a history of significant overgrazing pressure.

Meanwhile, agricultural production areas (crops) are located in valley or floodplain zones near the Ariguaní River, within the community’s area of influence. Some areas affected by slash-and-burn practices, located farther from the main settlement, impact areas ranging from 3 to 5 hectares.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to areas with a predominance of crop and/or pasture mosaics and/or natural spaces, in the town of Kantinurwa, in the basin of the Fundación River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this coverage, the vegetation is enriched with important timber species, including: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cañaguate (Handroanthus chrysanthus), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedro (Cedrela odorata), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), wormwood (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), roble (Tabebuia sp.), socano, tobacco (Pseudosamanea sp.) and tambor (Schyzolobium parahyba).  In some of these coverages, the planting of an unspecified palm has been promoted. In one of the polygons, priority was given to planting the carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), a species categorized as endangered at the regional level. It corresponds to the vegetation cover associated with the river in the locality of Kantinurwa, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this cover, vegetation enrichment stands out with the following species: mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), palm, oak (Tabebuia sp.), socano, and tobacco (Pseudosamanea sp.). In smaller proportions but equally important are the following species: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), cananeo (Peltogyne purpurea), cañaguate (Handroanthus chrysanthus), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cuchillito (Senna sp.), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), moringa (Moringa oleifera), and orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum). The most promoted species in this polygon is cedar (Cedrela odorata).

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: Corresponds to areas with a predominance of secondary vegetation cover or in transition, in the town of Kantinurwa, in the basin of the Fundación River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this coverage, the vegetation is enriched with important timber species, including: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril),  caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), cedro (Cedrela odorata), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), ceiba roja (Pachira quinata), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guacimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and oak (Tabebuia sp.). In the same way, the planting of important food crops such as avocado (Persea americana) and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum) has been promoted, which favors the Arhuaca population's expectations for their own economy and food security. The planting of an unspecified palm has been promoted in these areas.
history_site:
Kantinurwa is a populated Arhuaco settlement located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, at the confluence of the Ariguaní River and the Los Curos stream, between 350 and 750 m.a.s.l. This settlement was founded as a pueblo talanquera in 2009, within the framework of the strategic project known as the “Environmental and Traditional Belt of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.”

The areas most affected by environmental degradation due to vegetation loss are found to the north and west of the populated center, while forested zones with low to minimal intervention are located toward the south and east of the territory. On the right bank—downstream—of the Ariguaní River, north of the settlement, there are degraded and/or clean lands with a history of significant overgrazing pressure.

Meanwhile, agricultural production areas (crops) are located in valley or floodplain zones near the Ariguaní River, within the community’s area of influence. Some areas affected by slash-and-burn practices, located farther from the main settlement, impact areas ranging from 3 to 5 hectares.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to areas with a predominance of crop and/or pasture mosaics and/or natural spaces, in the town of Kantinurwa, in the basin of the Fundación River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this coverage, the vegetation is enriched with important timber species, including: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cañaguate (Handroanthus chrysanthus), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedro (Cedrela odorata), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), wormwood (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), roble (Tabebuia sp.), socano, tobacco (Pseudosamanea sp.) and tambor (Schyzolobium parahyba).  In some of these coverages, the planting of an unspecified palm has been promoted. In one of the polygons, priority was given to planting the carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), a species categorized as endangered at the regional level. project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: Vegetation cover located in a coastal plain in the process of natural and assisted restoration in soils historically affected by intensive cattle ranching, near the mouth of the Don Diego River, in the town of Katunsuma, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. Enrichment with native species of high timber value such algarrobo (Aspidosperma spruceanum), roble (Tabebuia sp), palma amarga (Sabal mauritiformis) and dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), promoted in the planting process. These species are mainly associated with the secondary or transitional vegetation cover, which is dominated by guarumos (Cecropia sp.), balsos (Ochroma pyramidale), algarrobo (Hymanea corubaril), guayabo león (Terminalia amazonica), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia) and varasanta (Triplaris americana), among others. Other crop covers associated with this halobiome currently include species such as: moringa (Moringa oleifera), pear (Syzigium sp.), guanabana (Annona sp.) and mamey (Mammea americana).
history_site:
Katunsuma is an Arhuaco community settlement located on the coastal plain, at the foothills of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, between the mouths of the Don Diego River and the Perico Aguao stream. Its physical construction began less than ten years ago as part of the process of territorial recovery and consolidation in the area known as the “exit to the sea” of the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve.

This area has been historically affected by intensive cattle farming, characterized by a matrix of Guinea or Mombaza grass (Panicum maximum) and other weedy grasses in wooded pastures that once supported more than a hundred head of cattle. This livestock activity was discontinued following an asset expropiation process carried out by the now-dissolved National Directorate of Narcotics—currently the Special Assets Society—and the area was subsequently allocated for the development of ecological restoration processes coordinated between the competent environmental authority and the Indigenous community.

Although the area was subjected to intensive grazing pressure, the resilience of the natural environment - particularly from the soils - has favored both natural regeneration and assisted recovery in this territory, which is framed by the presence of important sacred sites belonging to the Línea Negra﻿.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This mainly corresponds to a mosaic of pastures and/or crops and/or natural spaces located in the humid tropical zonobiome, in the locality of Seykwanamake, within the mid-altitudinal band between 100 and 200 meters above sea level, in the Palomino River basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this land cover, frequent and high-density enrichment with the following species stands out: avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and oak (Tabebuia sp.). To a lesser extent, but of equal importance, the planting of the following species has been promoted: breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), red ceiba (Pachira quinata), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), mango (Mangifera indica), mastre (Pterygota colombiana), pear (Zyzygium malaccense), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), and varasanta (Triplaris americana), among othersIt corresponds mainly to secondary vegetation cover or in transition, in the humid tropical zone, in the locality of Seykwanamake, in the average altitudinal range between 100 and 250 meters above sea level, in the Palomino river basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, there is an enrichment of vegetation with species of great timber value and constructive use, mainly roble (Tabebuia sp.) and caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum). The following species are planted to a lesser extent: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), aceituno (Vitex cymosa), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla),caracoli (Anacardium excelsum), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guamo (Inga sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). The plantation of other species of importance for the food security of the Arhuaca families has also been promoted, including avocado (Persea americana) and moringa (Moringa oleifera).
history_site:
Located between 200 and 400 m.a.s.l, across the valley and hill landscapes of the Palomino River in the area known as the “exit to the sea” of the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, lies the community of Seykwanamake. This Arhuaco settlement occupies areas historically affected by illicit crop cultivation and extensive cattle farming dating back to the marijuana bonanza period of the late 1990s and early 2000s. These activities resulted in high levels of landscape fragmentation and the loss of native flora and fauna species.

The area was prioritized under Plan Colombia in the early 2000s, which enabled the resettlement of the Arhuaco population. However, progress remains pending in the land regularization processes needed to restore territorial integrity and self-governance for the Indigenous peoples of the Sierra. This zone shows higher levels of degradation in the hilly areas due to soil depletion caused by recurrent burning to renew pastures.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

The following species are planted to a lesser extent: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), aceituno (Vitex cymosa), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla),caracoli (Anacardium excelsum), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guamo (Inga sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). The plantation of other species of importance for the food security of the Arhuaca families has also been promoted, including avocado (Persea americana) and moringa (Moringa oleifera).
history_site:
Located between 200 and 400 m.a.s.l, across the valley and hill landscapes of the Palomino River in the area known as the “exit to the sea” of the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, lies the community of Seykwanamake. This Arhuaco settlement occupies areas historically affected by illicit crop cultivation and extensive cattle farming dating back to the marijuana bonanza period of the late 1990s and early 2000s. These activities resulted in high levels of landscape fragmentation and the loss of native flora and fauna species.

The area was prioritized under Plan Colombia in the early 2000s, which enabled the resettlement of the Arhuaco population. However, progress remains pending in the land regularization processes needed to restore territorial integrity and self-governance for the Indigenous peoples of the Sierra. This zone shows higher levels of degradation in the hilly areas due to soil depletion caused by recurrent burning to renew pastures.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This corresponds to areas with mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces, in the locality of Ati Gumake, within the humid tropical zonobiome, in a mid-altitudinal band between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, in the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, Palomino River basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. This land cover has been mainly enriched with timber species such as oak (Tabebuia sp.) and mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla). To a lesser extent, the following species have been promoted: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp.), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Similarly, species important for agro-food security such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), soursop (Annona muricata), and pear (Syzygium malaccense) are also found associated with these land covers.Corresponds to areas of dense forest and/or forests with signs of fragmentation, in the town of Bunkwimake, in the average altitudinal range between 280 and 340 meters above sea level, associated with the expansion of the agricultural and livestock frontier in the humid tropical zone of the Don Diego river basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, plant enrichment with species of great timber value and constructive use stands out, including species that are threatened at the regional and local levels, such as: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), roble (Tabebuia sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), and palma amarga (Sabal mauritiformis). Other species of importance for soil recovery and as food for fauna have also been promoted, including guamo (Inga sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), among others.
history_site:
The Ati Gumake sector is one of the first Arhuaco territories reestablished on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada, thanks to the cultural and political efforts of the four peoples of the Sierra. This process made possible the partial recovery of the territory known as the “exit to the sea” of the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, located between the Don Diego and Palomino rivers, during the final decades of the twentieth century. The community is situated where the Lucuici River, El Puerco stream, and the Palomino River joint, between 250 and 1000 meters above sea level.

The most affected areas by deforestation in recent decades are concentrated in the northern, central, and western parts of this terriroty. However, it is important to note that this zone was heavily impacted by the presence of illicit crops until the first decade of the 21st century. Fires, cattle ranching and the expansion of the agricultural frontier remain historical drivers of change in the region. Around the populated center, there are areas of clean and weedy pastures, as well as mosaics of crops, pastures, and natural spaces. The presence of large trees to the northwest of the populated area offers an opportunity to establish seed banks of late-successional and pioneer timber species, oriented the ecological restoration of this area with a long-term vision.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada

In this coverage, the following species stand out for their frequency and density: roble (Tabebuia sp.), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla) and cedro (Cedrela odorata). project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This corresponds to mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces in the locality of Bunkwimake, within the mid-altitudinal band between 280 and 340 meters above sea level, in the humid tropical zonobiome, Don Diego River basin, Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this land cover, enrichment with plant species of high timber value and construction utility stands out, such as: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), oak (Tabebuia sp.), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), laurel (Nectandra sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). To a lesser extent, but with good frequency, species such as algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), kamaleandra (Calliandra sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), among others, have been associated. Likewise, other species important for food security have been promoted, such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), pear (Syzygium malaccense), guamo (Inga sp.), and moringa (Moringa oleifera).Corresponds to areas of dense forest and/or forests with signs of fragmentation in the locality of Atygumake, within the humid tropical zone, in an average altitudinal range between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, within the Palomino River basin, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage there is an enrichment of vegetation with species of timber importance, especially with constructive use value, among which stand out: laurel (Nectandra sp. ), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), roble (Tabebuia sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), camapano (Samanea saman). Likewise, in some of these cover crops, the planting of other species of community importance has been promoted, such as avocado (Persea americana) and Moringa (Moringa oleifera), which favor the expectations of the Arhuaca population's own economy and food security.
history_site:
Bunkwimake is an Arhuaco territory located near the Don Dieguito River, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada, in the area known as the “exit to the sea” of the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve. It is currently one of the main consolidated population centers in the northern sector of the Sierra. The area lies between 200 and 500 m.a.s.l and is part of the Tropical Humid Zonobiome, which was severely impacted in the late 20th and early 21st centuries thorugh illicit crops.

Nevertheless, through the Plan Colombia—which promoted manual eradication and aerial control of such crops, along with land legislation in favor of the Indigenous Reserve—progress has been made to natural recovery and productive reconversion. Cocoa farming and other semi-permanent crops have become key strategies to gradually improve ecological connectivity indicators and strengthen the local economy.

Burning and deforestation are other historical drivers of transformation that continue their influence in the region, particularly on the southern side of the populated center. Likewise, areas impacted by deforestation in recent decades are highly noticeable in all four cardinal directions; however, some key remnants of dense forest and tall secondary vegetation remain, especially toward the northeastern sector of the populated area.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to areas dominated by clean pastures in the locality of Gunmaku, on the boundaries of the Tucurinca and Aracataca river basins, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, within a mid-altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this land cover, vegetation enrichment with species of timber importance stands out, especially those with constructive uses, among which the following are notable: aguacatillo (Persea sp.), campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), cuchillito (Senna sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), fruto de mico (unspecified), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), guamito de piedra (Zygia longifolia), guamo (Inga sp.), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.), oak (Tabebuia sp.), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), and trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia). A remarkable feature in this land cover is the planting of a species considered almost exclusive to this area of the Sierra, locally known as pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.).
history_site:
Gunmaku is an Arhuaco Indigenous settlement located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, between the Tucurinca River and the Tres Vueltas stream. This territory lies between 350 and 600 ma.s.l, with a significant presence of areas degraded by overgrazing, particularly north of the populated center, on the right bank—downstream—of the Tucurinca River, where a polygon of more than 100 hectares with bare and degraded soils, as well as open grasslands with scattered trees can be observed.

The historical intensity of livestock activity in this area is evident from the terracing scars visible on the hillside and hilltop landscapes. Although scarce, secondary vegetation is mainly found to the south and southeast of the populated center. The abundance of wine palm (Attalea butyracea) standing out in the landscape on the western side of Gunmaku suggests that these areas have been historically subjected to disturbance through burning.

The gallery forest belt is moderately interrupted by the presence of agricultural crops; however, it maintains an average width of 30 to 50 meters in the best-preserved corridors.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This corresponds to areas dominated by mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces in the locality of Kankawarwa﻿, in the cuenca del río Fundación﻿, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿, within a mid-altitudinal band between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In this land cover, vegetation enrichment is notable with timber species of constructive value, among which the following stand out: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril)﻿, campano (Samanea saman)﻿, caoba (Swietenia macrophylla)﻿, carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron)﻿, cedro (Cedrela odorata)﻿, ceiba (Ceiba pentandra)﻿, ceiba roja (Pachira quinata)﻿, cuchillito (Senna sp.)﻿, dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria)﻿, dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria)﻿, guácimo (Guazuma ulmofolia)﻿, guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus)﻿, gusanero (Astronium graveolens)﻿, orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum)﻿, roble (Tabebuia sp.)﻿, and tabaco (Pseudosamanea sp.)﻿. Similarly, the planting of other species of agro-food importance has been promoted, such as aguacate (Persea americana)﻿, pera (Zyzygium malaccense)﻿, zapote (Pouteria zapota)﻿, and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum)﻿, which support the economic expectations and food security of the población arhuaca﻿. In these land covers, the planting of an unspecified palm and another species locally known as cachimbo (Erythrina sp.)﻿ has also been promoted.This corresponds to areas dominated by mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces in the locality of Kankawarwa﻿, in the cuenca del río Fundación﻿, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿, within a mid-altitudinal band between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In these land covers, the planting of an unspecified palm and another species locally known as cachimbo (Erythrina sp.)﻿ has also been promoted.Corresponds to areas with a predominance of secondary vegetation cover or in transition, in the locality of Kankawarwa, in the basin of the Fundación River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In this coverage, the vegetation is enriched with important timber species, including: carob (Hymenaea courbaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), carob (Aspidosperma polyneuron), cedar (Cedrela odorata), kapok (Ceiba pentandra), red kapok (Pachira quinata), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guacimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and oak (Tabebuia sp.). In the same way, the planting of important food crops such as avocado (Persea americana) and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum) has been promoted, which favors the Arhuaca population's expectations for their own economy and food security. The planting of an unspecified palm has been promoted in these areas.
history_site:
Kankawarwa is located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, in the Fundación River basin, within the lower La Cristalina area, between 250 and 500 m.a.s.l. This village was founded in 2009 on a 114-hectare property purchased by the Governor’s Office of Magdalena as part of the establishment of the so-called "pueblos talanquera", within the strategic project known as the “Environmental and Traditional Belt of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.”

It is an area of environmental and cultural importance situated in the lower part of the Sierra Nevada, between La Cristalina stream and the Nabusimake River, where the Arhuaco people have designated one sector for community services and another for traditional living. The region has been affected by historical colonization processes that have led to high levels of landscape fragmentation, mainly linked to cattle farming activities. The relictual state of original forest cover and the loss of native, high-value timber species are some of the visible outcomes of this colonization.

The northern part of the populated center was particularly deforested between 2013 and 2017, according to data from the Global Forest Change observatory and geoportal.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This refers to areas predominantly covered by clean or weedy pastures in the locality of Kankawarwa, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in a mid-altitudinal strip ranging between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In this land cover, the enrichment with timber species is notable, especially those valued for construction uses, among which the following stand out: mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), and oak (Tabebuia sp.). To a lesser extent, but equally important, the planting of abarco (Cariniana sp.), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), and orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) has been promoted. Likewise, associated with these land covers, the planting of other species of community importance has been encouraged, such as avocado (Persea americana), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), caimito (Pouteria caimito), and pear (Syzygium malaccense), which supports the Arhuaco population's expectations for self-sustained economy and food security. In these land covers, the planting of a species locally known as cachimbo (Erythrina sp.) has also been promoted.It mainly corresponds to a cover mosaic of pastures, crops, and natural spaces and/or secondary or transitional vegetation, eventually associated with remnants of dense forest, clean or weedy pastures, and rivers in the Sub-Andean rainforest orobiome of the Kankawarwa sector, Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The representative species associated with the covers of this Orobiome include: cedar (Cedrela odorata) and oak (Tabebuia sp.). Common species include: avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), and mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla). Occasionally associated species include: cachimbo (Erythrina sp.), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), red ceiba (Pachira quinata), cuchillito (Senna sp.), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guáimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guamo (Inga sp.), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), palm, and perehuétano (Parinari pachyphylla).﻿Corresponds to areas with a predominance of secondary vegetation cover or in transition, in the locality of Kankawarwa, in the basin of the Fundación River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In the same way, the planting of important food crops such as avocado (Persea americana) and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum) has been promoted, which favors the Arhuaca population's expectations for their own economy and food security. The planting of an unspecified palm has been promoted in these areas.

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to areas with a predominance of crop and/or pasture mosaics and/or natural spaces, in the town of Kantinurwa, in the basin of the Fundación River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this coverage, the vegetation is enriched with important timber species, including: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cañaguate (Handroanthus chrysanthus), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedro (Cedrela odorata), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), wormwood (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), roble (Tabebuia sp.), socano, tobacco (Pseudosamanea sp.) and tambor (Schyzolobium parahyba).  In some of these coverages, the planting of an unspecified palm has been promoted. In one of the polygons, priority was given to planting the carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), a species categorized as endangered at the regional level.
history_site:
Kantinurwa is a populated Arhuaco settlement located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, at the confluence of the Ariguaní River and the Los Curos stream, between 350 and 750 m.a.s.l. This settlement was founded as a pueblo talanquera in 2009, within the framework of the strategic project known as the “Environmental and Traditional Belt of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.”

The areas most affected by environmental degradation due to vegetation loss are found to the north and west of the populated center, while forested zones with low to minimal intervention are located toward the south and east of the territory. On the right bank—downstream—of the Ariguaní River, north of the settlement, there are degraded and/or clean lands with a history of significant overgrazing pressure.

Meanwhile, agricultural production areas (crops) are located in valley or floodplain zones near the Ariguaní River, within the community’s area of influence. Some areas affected by slash-and-burn practices, located farther from the main settlement, impact areas ranging from 3 to 5 hectares.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: Corresponds to secondary vegetation, in transition or with the presence of pasture mosaic with natural spaces associated with the Sub-Andean Orobioma, in the locality of Kantinurwa, Fundación river basin. Eventually they are associated with clean or weeded pasture cover. Among the representative species of this biome for all covers are: algarrobo (Swietenia macrophylla), caracoli (Anacardium excelsum), cedro (Cedrela odorata), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), palm, moringa (Moringa oleifera),roble (Tabebuia sp. ), tobacco (Pseudosamanea sp.), tambor (Schyzolobium parahyba) and trébol (Platymyscium pinnatum). In smaller porportion the following species can be found in association: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), camajón (Sterculia apetala), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), cuchillito (Senna sp.), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), laurel (Nectandra sp. ), achotillo (Vismia sp.), avocado (Persea americana), cananeo (Peltogyne purpurea), cañaguate (Handroanthus chrysantha), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), jobo (Spondias mombim) and socano. It corresponds to areas with a predominance of crop and/or pasture mosaics and/or natural spaces, in the town of Kantinurwa, in the basin of the Fundación River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this coverage, the vegetation is enriched with important timber species, including: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cañaguate (Handroanthus chrysanthus), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedro (Cedrela odorata), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), wormwood (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), roble (Tabebuia sp.), socano, tobacco (Pseudosamanea sp.) and tambor (Schyzolobium parahyba).  In some of these coverages, the planting of an unspecified palm has been promoted. In one of the polygons, priority was given to planting the carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), a species categorized as endangered at the regional level. Corresponds to areas with a predominance of secondary vegetation cover or in transition, in the town of Kantinurwa, in the basin of the Fundación River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this coverage, the vegetation is enriched with important timber species, including: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril),  caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), cedro (Cedrela odorata), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), ceiba roja (Pachira quinata), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guacimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and oak (Tabebuia sp.). In the same way, the planting of important food crops such as avocado (Persea americana) and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum) has been promoted, which favors the Arhuaca population's expectations for their own economy and food security. The planting of an unspecified palm has been promoted in these areas.
history_site:

planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to vegetation covers of the Sub-Andean Orobiome, which include secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural spaces in the locality of Muñimake, within the Fundación River basin, western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in the altitudinal range between 1300 and 1700 meters above sea level. Among the representative species of this biome for all covers are: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), walnut (Cordia sp.), and oak (Tabebuia sp.). Common species include: caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum). Occasional elements recorded are pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.), palm, trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), and yaya (Xylopia sp.).﻿
history_site:
Muñimake is an Arhuaco community settlement located on an area that divides the Fundación and Ariguaní river basins, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. This territory extends at an average altitude of 1,500 m.a.s.l.,north of the health center, forest cover is moderately interrupted by mosaics of crops, pastures, and natural areas. In contrast, the southern side features a fragmented landscape where patches of pastures and natural spaces alternate with forest clearings dominated by ferns and weedy grasses.

According to the Global Forest Change observatory, the trend of significant forest loss around the populated center has persisted over the past decade. Coffee plantations ranging from 2 to 4 hectares, visible in satellite imagery, are mainly located to the west of the territory, most of them developed without shade. Burned and eroded areas are commonly observed throughout the sub-Andean landscape.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

description_site: It corresponds to vegetation covers of the Sub-Andean Orobiome, which include secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural spaces in the locality of Muñimake, within the Fundación River basin, western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in the altitudinal range between 1300 and 1700 meters above sea level. Among the representative species of this biome for all covers are: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), walnut (Cordia sp.), and oak (Tabebuia sp.).
