project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to vegetation covers of the Sub-Andean Orobiome, which include secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural spaces in the locality of Singuney, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The following species are representative in terms of abundance and frequency: oak (Tabebuia sp.), trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Common species with more than 50% frequency in the vegetation covers of this Sub-Andean biome include: mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), achote (Vismia sp.), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guayabito (Calophylon sp.). Less frequently found species include: avocado (Persea americana), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), palm, corazón fino (Platymyscium pinnatum), cuchillito (Senna sp.), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guava (Psidium guajaba), moringa (Moringa oleifera), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), walnut (Cordia sp.), pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.) and Sula (Trema sp.). In some specific polygons, exclusive populations can be found of abarco (Cariniana pyriformis), achote (Vismia sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), lechoso (Brosimum sp.), granadilla (Caesalpinia sp.), and ceiba (Ceiba pentandra).﻿This mainly corresponds to a mosaic of pastures and/or crops and/or natural spaces located within a humid tropical zonobiome, in the locality of Seykwanamake, within the mid-altitudinal band between 650 and 900 meters above sea level, in the Fundación River basin, Arhuaco Reserve of the Sierra, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this land cover, vegetation enrichment is mainly notable for the following species: oak (Tabebuia sp.), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), small-leaf guava (Calophyllum sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), and an unspecified palm. To a lesser extent, though equally important, the following species are also present: avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), camajón (Sterculia apetala), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guamo (Inga sp.), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guayacán (Tabebuia chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), and trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia), among others.It corresponds mainly to secondary vegetation cover or in transition, located in a humid tropical zone, in the town of Singuney, in the average altitude range between 650 and 900 meters above sea level, in the basin of the Fundación River, Resguardo Arhuaco de la Sierra, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, there is an enrichment of vegetation with species of roble (Tabebuia sp.), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), guayabito (Calophyllum sp.) and unspecified palm.
history_site:
Singuney is an Arhuaco community located in the Chinchicua micro-basin, within the Ariguaní River basin, between 650 and 1,100 m.a.s.l, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The area shows a clear historical record of localized burning in its northern part and a deforestation pattern concentrated in the southern and western sections of the community. The best-preserved vegetation covers are found to the east of the populated center; however, the landscape—dominated by tall secondary vegetation—is not homogeneous, being interrupted by patches of overgrown pastures and fern thickets that indicate poor and depleted soils.

Overall, landscape fragmentation is closely associated with burning pressure from livestock activities and the expansion of the agricultural frontier. It is necessary to design and implement landscape management tools to reverse the degradation of the forested landscape in the micro-basin, particularly along the right bank, downstream of the Chinchicua stream.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to the vegetation covers of the Orobioma subandino that include secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, dense forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural spaces in the locality of Umake, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The following species are representative in terms of abundance and frequency for all vegetation covers: mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), and oak (Tabebuia sp.). Less than 70% of appearances are followed by species such as guamo (Inga sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and walnut (Cordia aliodora). The latter species shows a high record of abundance. At 50% or less frequency, species such as avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), granadilla (Caesalpinia sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), lechoso (Brosimum sp.), and tabaco (Caesalpinia sp2) are reported. With a frequency lower than 10%, the following are recorded: carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), árbol del pan (Artocarpus altilis), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), ceiba roja (Pachira quinata), corazón fino (Platymyscium pinnatum), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), guamo de piedra (Zygia longifolia), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), palma, and varasanta (Triplaris americana). Finally, some species exclusive to specific covers include: achote (Vismia sp), aguacate macho (Persea caerulea), campano (Samanea saman), pera (Zyzygium malaccense), pionío (Erythrina sp.), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia).﻿
history_site:
Umake is an Arhuaco community located in the micro-basin of the Nabusimake River, within the limits and currents of the Fundación River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, between 850 and 1,400 m.a.s.l. This area shows a recurring pattern of historical deforestation, except in the northeastern and southern sectors of the locality, where dense upland forest and secondary vegetation persist. These areas form part of the transition between the Tropical Humid Zonobiome and the Sub-Andean Forest Orobiome.

Subsistence and semi-permanent crops are established in the vecinity of the populated center. The clean and weedy pasture covers that characterize the fragmented landscape range from 1 to 8 hectares and represent the areas with the greatest need for adopting landscape management tools to mitigate environmental degradation.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: Corresponds to areas with clean and/or weeded pasture cover in the locality of Ati Gumake, within the humid tropical zone, in an average altitudinal range between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, in the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Reserve, Palomino river basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, the following species stand out for their frequency and density: roble (Tabebuia sp.), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla) and cedro (Cedrela odorata). At lower densities, algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp. ), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), palma amarga (Sabal mauritiformis) and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). In some polygons of this vegetation cover, species of agrifood importance for the Arhuaca community have been planted, such as: avocado (Persea americana), árbol del pan (Artocarpus altilis), cañandonga (Cassia grandis), marañon (Anacardium occidentale), moringa (Moringa oleifera) and pera (Syizigyum malaccense). This corresponds to areas with mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces, in the locality of Ati Gumake, within the humid tropical zonobiome, in a mid-altitudinal band between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, in the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, Palomino River basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. This land cover has been mainly enriched with timber species such as oak (Tabebuia sp.) and mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla). To a lesser extent, the following species have been promoted: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp.), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Similarly, species important for agro-food security such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), soursop (Annona muricata), and pear (Syzygium malaccense) are also found associated with these land covers.Corresponds to areas of dense forest and/or forests with signs of fragmentation, in the town of Bunkwimake, in the average altitudinal range between 280 and 340 meters above sea level, associated with the expansion of the agricultural and livestock frontier in the humid tropical zone of the Don Diego river basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage, plant enrichment with species of great timber value and constructive use stands out, including species that are threatened at the regional and local levels, such as: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), roble (Tabebuia sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), and palma amarga (Sabal mauritiformis). Other species of importance for soil recovery and as food for fauna have also been promoted, including guamo (Inga sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), among others.
history_site:
The Ati Gumake sector is one of the first Arhuaco territories reestablished on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada, thanks to the cultural and political efforts of the four peoples of the Sierra. This process made possible the partial recovery of the territory known as the “exit to the sea” of the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, located between the Don Diego and Palomino rivers, during the final decades of the twentieth century. The community is situated where the Lucuici River, El Puerco stream, and the Palomino River joint, between 250 and 1000 meters above sea level.

The most affected areas by deforestation in recent decades are concentrated in the northern, central, and western parts of this terriroty. However, it is important to note that this zone was heavily impacted by the presence of illicit crops until the first decade of the 21st century. Fires, cattle ranching and the expansion of the agricultural frontier remain historical drivers of change in the region. Around the populated center, there are areas of clean and weedy pastures, as well as mosaics of crops, pastures, and natural spaces. The presence of large trees to the northwest of the populated area offers an opportunity to establish seed banks of late-successional and pioneer timber species, oriented the ecological restoration of this area with a long-term vision.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site:
It corresponds to vegetation cover associated with aquatic ecosystems featuring a permanent water body, either static or flowing, in the locality of Aty Gumake﻿, within the cuenca del río Palomino﻿, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿.

In this hydrobiome, vegetation enrichment is characterized by the following species: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guamo (Inga sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), and oak (Tabebuia sp.).

Occasionally associated with this hydrobiome in the locality of Aty Gumake﻿ are species such as: avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cascarillo (Protium sp.), cedar (Cedrela odorata), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and bitter palm (Sabal mauritiformis).
This corresponds to areas with mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces, in the locality of Ati Gumake, within the humid tropical zonobiome, in a mid-altitudinal band between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, in the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, Palomino River basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. This land cover has been mainly enriched with timber species such as oak (Tabebuia sp.) and mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla). To a lesser extent, the following species have been promoted: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedar (Cedrela odorata), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guamo (Inga sp.), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). Similarly, species important for agro-food security such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), soursop (Annona muricata), and pear (Syzygium malaccense) are also found associated with these land covers.

description_site: Corresponds to areas with clean and/or weeded pasture cover in the locality of Ati Gumake, within the humid tropical zone, in an average altitudinal range between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, in the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Reserve, Palomino river basin, northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This corresponds to mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces in the locality of Bunkwimake, within the mid-altitudinal band between 280 and 340 meters above sea level, in the humid tropical zonobiome, Don Diego River basin, Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this land cover, enrichment with plant species of high timber value and construction utility stands out, such as: caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), oak (Tabebuia sp.), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), laurel (Nectandra sp.), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), and sambocedro (Guarea guidonia). To a lesser extent, but with good frequency, species such as algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), campano (Samanea saman), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), kamaleandra (Calliandra sp.), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), among others, have been associated. Likewise, other species important for food security have been promoted, such as avocado (Persea americana), breadfruit (Artocarpus altilis), pear (Syzygium malaccense), guamo (Inga sp.), and moringa (Moringa oleifera).Corresponds to areas of dense forest and/or forests with signs of fragmentation in the locality of Atygumake, within the humid tropical zone, in an average altitudinal range between 200 and 300 meters above sea level, within the Palomino River basin, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. In this coverage there is an enrichment of vegetation with species of timber importance, especially with constructive use value, among which stand out: laurel (Nectandra sp. ), caney (Aspidosperma spruceanum), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cedro (Cedrela odorata), roble (Tabebuia sp.), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), camapano (Samanea saman). Likewise, in some of these cover crops, the planting of other species of community importance has been promoted, such as avocado (Persea americana) and Moringa (Moringa oleifera), which favor the expectations of the Arhuaca population's own economy and food security.
history_site:
Bunkwimake is an Arhuaco territory located near the Don Dieguito River, on the northern slope of the Sierra Nevada, in the area known as the “exit to the sea” of the Kogui-Malayo-Arhuaco Indigenous Reserve. It is currently one of the main consolidated population centers in the northern sector of the Sierra. The area lies between 200 and 500 m.a.s.l and is part of the Tropical Humid Zonobiome, which was severely impacted in the late 20th and early 21st centuries thorugh illicit crops.

Nevertheless, through the Plan Colombia—which promoted manual eradication and aerial control of such crops, along with land legislation in favor of the Indigenous Reserve—progress has been made to natural recovery and productive reconversion. Cocoa farming and other semi-permanent crops have become key strategies to gradually improve ecological connectivity indicators and strengthen the local economy.

Burning and deforestation are other historical drivers of transformation that continue their influence in the region, particularly on the southern side of the populated center. Likewise, areas impacted by deforestation in recent decades are highly noticeable in all four cardinal directions; however, some key remnants of dense forest and tall secondary vegetation remain, especially toward the northeastern sector of the populated area.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

Likewise, areas impacted by deforestation in recent decades are highly noticeable in all four cardinal directions; however, some key remnants of dense forest and tall secondary vegetation remain, especially toward the northeastern sector of the populated area.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This corresponds to areas dominated by mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces in the locality of Kankawarwa﻿, in the cuenca del río Fundación﻿, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿, within a mid-altitudinal band between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In this land cover, vegetation enrichment is notable with timber species of constructive value, among which the following stand out: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril)﻿, campano (Samanea saman)﻿, caoba (Swietenia macrophylla)﻿, carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron)﻿, cedro (Cedrela odorata)﻿, ceiba (Ceiba pentandra)﻿, ceiba roja (Pachira quinata)﻿, cuchillito (Senna sp.)﻿, dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria)﻿, dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria)﻿, guácimo (Guazuma ulmofolia)﻿, guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus)﻿, gusanero (Astronium graveolens)﻿, orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum)﻿, roble (Tabebuia sp.)﻿, and tabaco (Pseudosamanea sp.)﻿. Similarly, the planting of other species of agro-food importance has been promoted, such as aguacate (Persea americana)﻿, pera (Zyzygium malaccense)﻿, zapote (Pouteria zapota)﻿, and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum)﻿, which support the economic expectations and food security of the población arhuaca﻿. In these land covers, the planting of an unspecified palm and another species locally known as cachimbo (Erythrina sp.)﻿ has also been promoted.This corresponds to areas dominated by mosaics of crops and/or pastures and/or natural spaces in the locality of Kankawarwa﻿, in the cuenca del río Fundación﻿, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta﻿, within a mid-altitudinal band between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. Similarly, the planting of other species of agro-food importance has been promoted, such as aguacate (Persea americana)﻿, pera (Zyzygium malaccense)﻿, zapote (Pouteria zapota)﻿, and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum)﻿, which support the economic expectations and food security of the población arhuaca﻿. In these land covers, the planting of an unspecified palm and another species locally known as cachimbo (Erythrina sp.)﻿ has also been promoted.Corresponds to areas with a predominance of secondary vegetation cover or in transition, in the locality of Kankawarwa, in the basin of the Fundación River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In this coverage, the vegetation is enriched with important timber species, including: carob (Hymenaea courbaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), carob (Aspidosperma polyneuron), cedar (Cedrela odorata), kapok (Ceiba pentandra), red kapok (Pachira quinata), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guacimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and oak (Tabebuia sp.). In the same way, the planting of important food crops such as avocado (Persea americana) and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum) has been promoted, which favors the Arhuaca population's expectations for their own economy and food security. The planting of an unspecified palm has been promoted in these areas.
history_site:
Kankawarwa is located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, in the Fundación River basin, within the lower La Cristalina area, between 250 and 500 m.a.s.l. This village was founded in 2009 on a 114-hectare property purchased by the Governor’s Office of Magdalena as part of the establishment of the so-called "pueblos talanquera", within the strategic project known as the “Environmental and Traditional Belt of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.”

It is an area of environmental and cultural importance situated in the lower part of the Sierra Nevada, between La Cristalina stream and the Nabusimake River, where the Arhuaco people have designated one sector for community services and another for traditional living. The region has been affected by historical colonization processes that have led to high levels of landscape fragmentation, mainly linked to cattle farming activities. The relictual state of original forest cover and the loss of native, high-value timber species are some of the visible outcomes of this colonization.

The northern part of the populated center was particularly deforested between 2013 and 2017, according to data from the Global Forest Change observatory and geoportal.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: This refers to areas predominantly covered by clean or weedy pastures in the locality of Kankawarwa, within the Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in a mid-altitudinal strip ranging between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In this land cover, the enrichment with timber species is notable, especially those valued for construction uses, among which the following stand out: mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), and oak (Tabebuia sp.). To a lesser extent, but equally important, the planting of abarco (Cariniana sp.), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), and orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) has been promoted. Likewise, associated with these land covers, the planting of other species of community importance has been encouraged, such as avocado (Persea americana), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), caimito (Pouteria caimito), and pear (Syzygium malaccense), which supports the Arhuaco population's expectations for self-sustained economy and food security. In these land covers, the planting of a species locally known as cachimbo (Erythrina sp.) has also been promoted.Corresponds to areas with a predominance of secondary vegetation cover or in transition, in the locality of Kankawarwa, in the basin of the Fundación River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 300 and 400 meters above sea level. In this coverage, the vegetation is enriched with important timber species, including: carob (Hymenaea courbaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), carob (Aspidosperma polyneuron), cedar (Cedrela odorata), kapok (Ceiba pentandra), red kapok (Pachira quinata), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guacimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and oak (Tabebuia sp.). In the same way, the planting of important food crops such as avocado (Persea americana) and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum) has been promoted, which favors the Arhuaca population's expectations for their own economy and food security. The planting of an unspecified palm has been promoted in these areas.

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It mainly corresponds to a cover mosaic of pastures, crops, and natural spaces and/or secondary or transitional vegetation, eventually associated with remnants of dense forest, clean or weedy pastures, and rivers in the Sub-Andean rainforest orobiome of the Kankawarwa sector, Fundación River basin, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. The representative species associated with the covers of this Orobiome include: cedar (Cedrela odorata) and oak (Tabebuia sp.). Common species include: avocado (Persea americana), algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), and mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla). Occasionally associated species include: cachimbo (Erythrina sp.), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), red ceiba (Pachira quinata), cuchillito (Senna sp.), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guáimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guamo (Inga sp.), guásimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), palm, and perehuétano (Parinari pachyphylla).﻿

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: Corresponds to secondary vegetation, in transition or with the presence of pasture mosaic with natural spaces associated with the Sub-Andean Orobioma, in the locality of Kantinurwa, Fundación river basin. Eventually they are associated with clean or weeded pasture cover. Among the representative species of this biome for all covers are: algarrobo (Swietenia macrophylla), caracoli (Anacardium excelsum), cedro (Cedrela odorata), guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), palm, moringa (Moringa oleifera),roble (Tabebuia sp. ), tobacco (Pseudosamanea sp.), tambor (Schyzolobium parahyba) and trébol (Platymyscium pinnatum). In smaller porportion the following species can be found in association: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), camajón (Sterculia apetala), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), cuchillito (Senna sp.), dindemoro (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), laurel (Nectandra sp. ), achotillo (Vismia sp.), avocado (Persea americana), cananeo (Peltogyne purpurea), cañaguate (Handroanthus chrysantha), gualanday (Jacaranda sp.), guácimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), jobo (Spondias mombim) and socano. It corresponds to areas with a predominance of crop and/or pasture mosaics and/or natural spaces, in the town of Kantinurwa, in the basin of the Fundación River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this coverage, the vegetation is enriched with important timber species, including: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), cañaguate (Handroanthus chrysanthus), caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), cedro (Cedrela odorata), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), wormwood (Astronium graveolens), moringa (Moringa oleifera), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum), roble (Tabebuia sp.), socano, tobacco (Pseudosamanea sp.) and tambor (Schyzolobium parahyba).  In some of these coverages, the planting of an unspecified palm has been promoted. In one of the polygons, priority was given to planting the carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), a species categorized as endangered at the regional level. Corresponds to areas with a predominance of secondary vegetation cover or in transition, in the town of Kantinurwa, in the basin of the Fundación River, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in an average altitudinal range between 350 and 450 meters above sea level. In this coverage, the vegetation is enriched with important timber species, including: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril),  caoba (Swietenia macrophylla), carreto (Aspidosperma polyneuron), cedro (Cedrela odorata), ceiba (Ceiba pentandra), ceiba roja (Pachira quinata), cuchillito (Senna sp. ), dindemora (Maclura tinctoria), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guacimo (Guazuma ulmifolia), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysanthus), gusanero (Astronium graveolens), orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) and oak (Tabebuia sp.). In the same way, the planting of important food crops such as avocado (Persea americana) and guaimaro (Brosimum alicastrum) has been promoted, which favors the Arhuaca population's expectations for their own economy and food security. The planting of an unspecified palm has been promoted in these areas.
history_site:
Kantinurwa is a populated Arhuaco settlement located on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada, at the confluence of the Ariguaní River and the Los Curos stream, between 350 and 750 m.a.s.l. This settlement was founded as a pueblo talanquera in 2009, within the framework of the strategic project known as the “Environmental and Traditional Belt of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta.”

The areas most affected by environmental degradation due to vegetation loss are found to the north and west of the populated center, while forested zones with low to minimal intervention are located toward the south and east of the territory. On the right bank—downstream—of the Ariguaní River, north of the settlement, there are degraded and/or clean lands with a history of significant overgrazing pressure.

Meanwhile, agricultural production areas (crops) are located in valley or floodplain zones near the Ariguaní River, within the community’s area of influence. Some areas affected by slash-and-burn practices, located farther from the main settlement, impact areas ranging from 3 to 5 hectares.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters

project_name: Restoring culturally and environmentally strategic areas with indigenous communities in the Sierra Nevada
description_site: It corresponds to vegetation covers of the Sub-Andean Orobiome, which include secondary or transitional vegetation, fragmented forest, mosaic of pastures and/or crops, and natural spaces in the locality of Muñimake, within the Fundación River basin, western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in the altitudinal range between 1300 and 1700 meters above sea level. Among the representative species of this biome for all covers are: algarrobo (Hymenaea courbaril), mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), cedar (Cedrela odorata), walnut (Cordia sp.), and oak (Tabebuia sp.). Common species include: caracolí (Anacardium excelsum), dividivi (Caesalpinia coriaria), guayacán (Handroanthus chrysantha), laurel (Nectandra sp.), and orejero (Enterolobium cyclocarpum). Occasional elements recorded are pepa de loro (Nectandra sp.), palm, trompito (Lafoensia punicifolia), sambocedro (Guarea guidonia), and yaya (Xylopia sp.).﻿
history_site:
Muñimake is an Arhuaco community settlement located on an area that divides the Fundación and Ariguaní river basins, on the western slope of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. This territory extends at an average altitude of 1,500 m.a.s.l.,north of the health center, forest cover is moderately interrupted by mosaics of crops, pastures, and natural areas. In contrast, the southern side features a fragmented landscape where patches of pastures and natural spaces alternate with forest clearings dominated by ferns and weedy grasses.

According to the Global Forest Change observatory, the trend of significant forest loss around the populated center has persisted over the past decade. Coffee plantations ranging from 2 to 4 hectares, visible in satellite imagery, are mainly located to the west of the territory, most of them developed without shade. Burned and eroded areas are commonly observed throughout the sub-Andean landscape.
planting_pattern_site: The trees were planted with a spacing of 4 x 3 meters
